  • Appraisal contingency - Property must appraise at or above purchase price
  • Sale of existing home - Buyer must sell current property first

Earnest Money

Earnest money demonstrates the buyer's good faith. In Florida, earnest money must be deposited within the time specified in the contract (usually 3 business days) into an escrow account.

Contract Status

  • Executed contract - All parties have performed their obligations
  • Executory contract - Some obligations remain to be performed

Key Points to Remember

  • Purchase agreements must include all essential terms
  • Contingencies protect buyers during the transaction
  • Earnest money goes into escrow, not to the seller

lessons.title: Contract Remedies
lessons.content:
Contract Remedies and Performance

In this final lesson, we examine what happens when contracts are performed, breached, or terminated.

Contract Performance

  • Complete performance - All terms fulfilled; contract is executed
  • Substantial performance - Minor deviations but main purpose achieved
  • Partial performance - Only some obligations completed

Breach of Contract

A breach occurs when a party fails to perform contractual obligations. Types include:

  • Material breach - Significant failure that defeats the contract purpose
  • Minor breach - Slight deviation that doesn't defeat the purpose
  • Anticipatory breach - One party announces they will not perform

Remedies for Breach

  • Compensatory damages - Money to cover actual losses
  • Liquidated damages - Pre-agreed amount (often the earnest money)
  • Specific performance - Court orders completion of the contract; common in real estate because each property is unique
  • Rescission - Contract is cancelled and parties returned to original positions

Contract Termination

Contracts may terminate by:

  • Performance (completion)
  • Mutual agreement
  • Operation of law (impossibility, death, bankruptcy)
  • Breach
  • Expiration of contingency period

Key Points to Remember

  • Specific performance is common in real estate due to unique properties
  • Liquidated damages are often set at the earnest money amount
  • Rescission returns parties to their pre-contract positions

lessons.title: Mortgage Instruments
lessons.content:
Mortgage Instruments

This lesson covers the mortgage document and its legal requirements.

The Mortgage Document

The mortgage is the security instrument that pledges the property as collateral. It gives the lender the right to foreclose if the borrower defaults.

Recording Requirements

Mortgages should be recorded in public records to provide constructive notice of the lender's lien. Recording protects the lender's priority position.

Mortgage Priority

Priority is generally determined by recording date ("first in time, first in right"). However, property taxes and special assessments have priority over all mortgages.

Loan-to-Value Ratio (LTV)

LTV = Loan Amount / Property Value. Example: $240,000 loan / $300,000 value = 80% LTV. Lower LTV means less risk for the lender.

Discount Points

One discount point = 1% of the loan amount. Points are paid upfront to reduce the interest rate. One point typically lowers the rate by about 1/8 percent.

Key Points to Remember

  • Recording protects lender's priority
  • Property taxes have priority over mortgages
  • One point = 1% of loan amount

lessons.title: Mortgage Basics
lessons.content:
Mortgage Basics

Welcome to Unit 12 of the FoundationCE Florida Sales Associate Pre-Licensing Course. This unit explains how residential mortgage financing works.

Lien Theory vs Title Theory

Florida is a lien theory state. In lien theory, the borrower holds legal title, and the lender has a lien on the property as security for the debt. The lien is removed once the loan is paid in full.

Components of a Mortgage Loan

Mortgage financing involves two separate documents:

  • Promissory note - The promise to repay the loan. It specifies the loan amount, interest rate, payment schedule, and repayment terms.
  • Mortgage - The security instrument. It pledges the property as collateral for the debt. If the borrower defaults, the lender may foreclose.

Important Mortgage Clauses

  • Acceleration clause - Allows the lender to demand full repayment if the borrower defaults
  • Right to reinstate - Allows the borrower to bring the loan current
  • Due on sale clause - Requires the loan to be paid off if the property is transferred
  • Prepayment clause - May impose penalties for early payoff

Key Points to Remember

  • Florida is a lien theory state - borrower holds title
  • Promissory note is the promise to pay; mortgage is the security
  • Acceleration clause allows lender to demand full payment after default

lessons.title: Promissory Notes
lessons.content:
Promissory Notes

In this lesson, we examine the promissory note and its key elements.

What is a Promissory Note?

The promissory note is the borrower's written promise to repay the loan. It is the evidence of the debt and is a negotiable instrument that can be bought and sold.

Key Elements of a Note

  • Principal amount - The loan amount borrowed
  • Interest rate - The cost of borrowing (fixed or adjustable)
  • Payment schedule - Monthly payments, due dates
  • Maturity date - When the loan must be paid in full
  • Maker - The borrower who signs the note
  • Payee - The lender who receives payments

Types of Interest Rates

  • Fixed rate - Same rate for the entire loan term
  • Adjustable rate (ARM) - Rate changes based on an index plus margin

Amortization

Amortization refers to the repayment of a loan through regular payments. Early payments consist mostly of interest. As time passes, more goes toward principal.

Key Points to Remember

  • The note is the evidence of debt; the mortgage is the security
  • Fixed rates stay constant; ARMs change with market conditions
  • Early payments are mostly interest

lessons.title: Conventional Loans
lessons.content:
Conventional Loan Programs

Welcome to Unit 13 of the FoundationCE Florida Sales Associate Pre-Licensing Course. This unit explores various loan programs and financing options.

Conforming vs Non-Conforming Loans

Conforming loans meet the standards set by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, including loan limits. Non-conforming loans (jumbo loans) exceed these limits or don't meet other standards.

Private Mortgage Insurance (PMI)

Conventional loans with less than 20% down payment typically require PMI to protect the lender against default.

Key Points to Remember

  • Conforming loans meet Fannie Mae/Freddie Mac standards
  • Jumbo loans exceed conforming limits
  • PMI is required for low down payment conventional loans

lessons.title: Creative Financing
lessons.content:
Creative Financing Options

This lesson explores alternative financing methods.

Seller Financing

The seller acts as the lender, allowing the buyer to make payments directly to the seller. This can help buyers who cannot qualify for traditional financing.

Assumable Loans

Some loans can be assumed by a new buyer. FHA and VA loans may be assumable. Most conventional loans have due-on-sale clauses preventing assumption.

Lease Option

A lease with an option to purchase allows a tenant to rent with the right to buy the property later at a predetermined price.

Key Points to Remember

  • Seller financing allows the seller to be the lender
  • FHA and VA loans may be assumable
  • Due-on-sale clauses prevent most loan assumptions

lessons.title: Government Loans
lessons.content:
Government Loan Programs

This lesson covers government-backed loan programs in detail.

FHA Loan Features

  • Low down payment (as low as 3.5%)
  • Mortgage insurance premium required
  • Property must meet FHA standards
  • Loan limits vary by county

VA Loan Features

  • No down payment required for eligible veterans
  • No monthly mortgage insurance
  • Funding fee may be required
  • Certificate of eligibility needed

USDA Rural Development Loans

USDA loans assist buyers in rural areas with low or moderate income. No down payment required for eligible properties and borrowers.

Key Points to Remember

  • FHA requires mortgage insurance; VA does not
  • VA loans are for eligible veterans only
  • USDA loans are for rural areas

lessons.title: RESPA Requirements
lessons.content:
RESPA Requirements

This lesson covers the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) and its requirements for residential mortgage transactions.

What is RESPA?

RESPA is a federal law that protects consumers in the home-buying process. It requires disclosures about settlement costs and prohibits certain practices that increase costs to consumers.

Key RESPA Requirements

  • Loan Estimate - Must be provided within 3 business days of loan application
  • Closing Disclosure - Must be provided at least 3 business days before closing
  • Affiliated Business Disclosure - Required when referring to affiliated service providers

Prohibited Practices

  • Kickbacks - Payments for referrals of settlement services are illegal
  • Fee splitting - Splitting fees for services not actually performed is prohibited
  • Seller-required title insurance - Sellers cannot require buyers to use a specific title company

Escrow Account Rules

RESPA limits the amount lenders can require for escrow accounts. Lenders may collect:

  • Two months cushion above the amount needed for annual taxes and insurance
  • Must provide annual escrow account statements

Key Points to Remember

  • Loan Estimate within 3 days of application
  • Closing Disclosure at least 3 days before closing
  • Kickbacks for referrals are illegal under RESPA

lessons.title: Settlement Statements
lessons.content:
Prorations, Prepaid Items, Accrued Items

In this lesson, we work through prorations. Prorations allocate expenses or income between the buyer and seller based on the date of closing.

Prepaid vs Accrued Items

  • Prepaid items are paid in advance. Examples: rent collected for future periods, insurance premiums. Prepaid items are credited to the seller and debited to the buyer.
  • Accrued items are expenses incurred but not yet paid. Example: property taxes in Florida are usually accrued. Accrued items are credited to the buyer and debited to the seller.

Proration Methods

  • 365-day method - Divides yearly amount by 365
  • 360-day method - Divides yearly amount by 360 (using 30-day months)

If not specified, the 365-day method is standard for Florida.

Proration Example

Annual taxes are $3,600. Closing occurs October 15. Taxes are paid in arrears.

  1. Daily rate: $3,600 / 365 = $9.86 per day
  2. Seller's days (Jan 1 - Oct 15): 288 days
  3. Seller owes: 288 x $9.86 = $2,838.08 (seller debit, buyer credit)

Key Points to Remember

  • Prepaid = seller credit, buyer debit
  • Accrued = buyer credit, seller debit
  • Florida taxes are typically paid in arrears

lessons.title: Closing Procedures
lessons.content:
Florida Transfer Taxes, Doc Stamps, Intangible Tax

In this final lesson, we apply Florida's state transfer taxes. These are tested frequently and must be memorized.

Documentary Stamp Tax on Deeds

Rate: $0.70 per $100 of consideration in most counties. To calculate: round up to nearest $100, divide by 100, multiply by $0.70. This is typically a seller debit.

Documentary Stamp Tax on Notes

Rate: $0.35 per $100 of loan amount. This is typically a buyer debit.

Intangible Tax on Mortgages

Rate: 2 mills ($2 per $1,000 borrowed) or multiply loan amount by 0.002. Applies to new mortgages only. This is a buyer debit.

Example Calculation

Home sells for $250,000 with a $200,000 new mortgage:

  • Doc stamps on deed: $250,000 / 100 x $0.70 = $1,750 (seller)
  • Doc stamps on note: $200,000 / 100 x $0.35 = $700 (buyer)
  • Intangible tax: $200,000 x 0.002 = $400 (buyer)

Key Points to Remember

  • Deed stamps: $0.70 per $100 - paid by seller
  • Note stamps: $0.35 per $100 - paid by buyer
  • Intangible tax: $2 per $1,000 - paid by buyer on new mortgages only

lessons.title: Proration Calculations
lessons.content:
Closing Statements, Debits and Credits

Welcome to Unit 14 of the FoundationCE Florida Sales Associate Pre-Licensing Course. In this unit, we learn how to prepare closing statements, calculate prorations, and apply Florida transfer taxes.

Understanding Closing Statements

A closing statement summarizes the financial details of a real estate transaction. It shows what the buyer must pay and what the seller will receive.

Debits and Credits

  • Debit - An amount owed or paid. It increases the amount a party must bring to closing.
  • Credit - An amount received or owed to the party. It reduces the amount required at closing.

Common Buyer Debits

Purchase price, recording fees, loan origination fees, documentary stamps on the note, intangible tax, and prepaid expenses.

Common Seller Debits

Real estate commission, documentary stamps on the deed, and prorated rent or taxes owed to the buyer.

Common Buyer Credits

Earnest money deposits and new loan proceeds.

Key Points to Remember

  • Debits increase what a party owes; credits reduce it
  • Earnest money is a buyer credit
  • Purchase price is a buyer debit

lessons.title: Comparative Market Analysis
lessons.content:
Comparative Market Analysis

This lesson covers how agents analyze the market to help clients price properties correctly.

What is a CMA?

A Comparative Market Analysis (CMA) is a report prepared by a real estate agent to help determine a property's market value by comparing it to similar recently sold properties.

CMA Components

  • Subject property - The property being analyzed
  • Comparable sales - Recently sold similar properties (comps)
  • Active listings - Currently listed similar properties (competition)
  • Expired listings - Properties that didn't sell (overpriced examples)

Selecting Comparables

Ideal comparables should be:

  • Sold within the past 3-6 months
  • Within 1 mile of the subject (or same neighborhood)
  • Similar in size, age, and condition
  • Same property type (single-family, condo, etc.)

Making Adjustments

When comparables differ from the subject:

  • Adjust the comparable's price, not the subject
  • Add value if comparable is inferior
  • Subtract value if comparable is superior

Key Points to Remember

  • CMA is not an appraisal (agents cannot "appraise")
  • Use 3-6 comparable sales for best accuracy
  • Recent sales are more reliable than older ones

lessons.title: Market Supply and Demand
lessons.content:
Market Supply and Demand

Welcome to Unit 15 of the FoundationCE Florida Sales Associate Pre-Licensing Course. This unit covers real estate markets and market analysis.

Understanding Supply and Demand

Real estate markets are governed by the basic economic principles of supply and demand. When demand exceeds supply, prices rise. When supply exceeds demand, prices fall.

Factors Affecting Demand

  • Population growth - More people means more housing demand
  • Employment rates - Jobs bring buyers to an area
  • Interest rates - Lower rates increase buying power
  • Consumer confidence - Optimism encourages home purchases
  • Local amenities - Schools, parks, and services attract buyers

Factors Affecting Supply

  • Construction costs - Higher costs reduce new development
  • Land availability - Limited land restricts supply
  • Government regulations - Zoning and permits affect development
  • Labor availability - Worker shortages slow construction

Market Equilibrium

Market equilibrium occurs when supply equals demand. At this point, prices stabilize and properties sell within typical timeframes.

Key Points to Remember

  • High demand + low supply = rising prices (seller's market)
  • Low demand + high supply = falling prices (buyer's market)
  • Interest rates significantly impact buyer purchasing power

lessons.title: Market Cycles
lessons.content:
Market Cycles

In this lesson, we examine real estate market cycles and how they affect property values.

The Four Phases of Real Estate Cycles

  • Recovery - Market begins to improve after a downturn; vacancies decline slowly
  • Expansion - Demand increases; prices rise; new construction begins
  • Hyper-supply - Too much construction; supply exceeds demand
  • Recession - Prices decline; vacancies increase; construction slows

Characteristics of Each Phase

Recovery: Bargain prices, cautious buyers, low construction activity

Expansion: Rising prices, increasing confidence, new development starts

Hyper-supply: Peak prices, speculative building, first signs of oversupply

Recession: Declining prices, high vacancies, foreclosures increase

Indicators to Watch

  • Days on market
  • Inventory levels (months of supply)
  • Price trends
  • Building permits issued
  • Foreclosure rates

Key Points to Remember

  • Real estate markets are cyclical
  • Each phase presents different opportunities and risks
  • 6 months of inventory is considered balanced

lessons.title: Appraisal Approaches
lessons.content:
Purpose of Appraisal, USPAP, Value Concepts, Principles of Value

Welcome to Unit 16 of the FoundationCE Florida Sales Associate Pre-Licensing Course. Appraisal concepts appear heavily on both state and national portions of the exam.

What is an Appraisal?

Appraisals are professional opinions of value developed by licensed appraisers. Lenders require appraisals to ensure property provides sufficient collateral for the loan.

USPAP

Appraisers must follow the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice (USPAP), which establishes ethical conduct, confidentiality, impartiality, and reporting standards.

Four Characteristics of Value

  • Scarcity - Supply is limited
  • Utility - Property is useful
  • Demand - People want and can afford it
  • Transferability - Ownership rights can be conveyed

Principles of Value

  • Substitution - Buyers won't pay more than cost of acquiring a similar property
  • Conformity - Value is maximized when property fits surroundings
  • Contribution - How much a feature adds to overall value
  • Highest and best use - Most productive legal use of the property

Key Points to Remember

  • USPAP sets ethical standards for appraisers
  • Value requires DUST (Demand, Utility, Scarcity, Transferability)
  • Substitution: buyers compare alternatives

lessons.title: USPAP Standards
lessons.content:
Depreciation, GRM, GIM, Reconciliation, Exam Strategy

In this final lesson of Unit 16, we focus on depreciation, income multipliers, and reconciliation.

Types of Depreciation

  • Physical deterioration - Wear and tear
  • Functional obsolescence - Out-of-date features or poor design
  • External obsolescence - Negative influences outside the property (noise, pollution)

Depreciation can be curable (cost-effective to repair) or incurable (costs more to fix than value gained).

Income Multipliers

  • GRM (Gross Rent Multiplier) - Uses gross monthly rent for small residential income properties
  • GIM (Gross Income Multiplier) - Uses annual income for commercial and larger properties

Reconciliation

The final step where the appraiser reviews reliability of each approach and gives weight to the most appropriate one to reach the final opinion of value.

  • Sales comparison is most reliable for homes
  • Income approach is most reliable for income properties
  • Cost approach is most reliable for new/special-use properties

Key Points to Remember

  • External obsolescence is caused by factors outside the property
  • GRM uses monthly rent; GIM uses annual income
  • Reconciliation produces the final value opinion

lessons.title: Value Principles
lessons.content:
Sales Comparison, Cost Approach, Income Approach

In this lesson, we analyze the three approaches used by appraisers to estimate value.

Sales Comparison Approach

Compares subject property to similar recently sold properties. Adjustments made for differences in size, condition, location, and amenities.

Key rule: If comparable is SUPERIOR, SUBTRACT. If comparable is INFERIOR, ADD.

Most reliable for: residential properties and vacant lots.

Cost Approach

Estimates land value plus cost to reproduce/replace improvements, minus depreciation.

Steps:

  1. Estimate land value
  2. Estimate reproduction/replacement cost
  3. Subtract depreciation
  4. Add land value to depreciated cost

Most reliable for: new construction, special purpose properties, properties with few comparables.

Income Approach

Values property based on income it produces. Uses gross rent multiplier (GRM) or capitalization rate.

  • GRM = Price / Gross Monthly Rent (for 1-4 unit residential)
  • Value using IRV = NOI / Cap Rate

Most reliable for: income-producing properties.

Key Points to Remember

  • Sales comparison: adjust from comparable to subject
  • Cost approach starts with land value
  • Income approach uses NOI and cap rate

lessons.title: Business Brokerage
lessons.content:
Business Brokerage, Financial Statements, Goodwill, Going Concern

In this final lesson, we explore business brokerage concepts.

Business Brokerage

Involves the sale of an ongoing enterprise. Unlike real property brokerage, business brokerage deals with intangible assets, goodwill, and operational performance.

Key Terms

  • Going concern - A business that continues operations with measurable cash flow, inventory, equipment, contracts, and customer relationships
  • Goodwill - Intangible value including reputation, brand awareness, and customer loyalty. May increase purchase price beyond asset value.

Financial Statements

  • Balance sheet - Lists assets, liabilities, and equity
  • Income statement - Shows revenue, expenses, and net profit
  • Cash flow statement - Tracks inflows and outflows of cash

Asset Sale vs Stock Sale

  • Asset sale - Buyer purchases equipment, inventory, and other assets without corporate stock
  • Stock sale - Buyer purchases ownership of the corporation itself, including liabilities

Key Points to Remember

  • Goodwill is intangible value
  • Balance sheet: assets, liabilities, equity
  • Florida requires a real estate license for business brokerage

lessons.title: ROI Calculations
lessons.content:
Cash Flow, Cap Rate, IRV, Cash on Cash, Equity Buildup

In this lesson we apply investment math. These formulas are critical for exam success.

Key Formulas

  • NOI = Effective Gross Income - Operating Expenses (debt service NOT included)
  • Cash Flow = NOI - Debt Service

The IRV Formula

Used for income property valuation:

  • I = Net Operating Income
  • R = Capitalization Rate
  • V = Value

Formulas:

  • Value = I / R
  • NOI = V x R
  • Cap Rate = I / V

Cash on Cash Return

Annual cash flow divided by initial cash invested. Shows return on actual dollars invested.

Equity Buildup

Occurs when loan principal is reduced over time. As mortgage is paid down, investor's equity increases.

Key Points to Remember

  • NOI excludes debt service
  • Value = NOI / Cap Rate
  • Cash on cash = Cash flow / Cash invested

lessons.title: Investment Analysis
lessons.content:
Investment Fundamentals, Risk, Leverage, Return

Welcome to Unit 17 of the FoundationCE Florida Sales Associate Pre-Licensing Course. In this unit we explore real estate as an investment.

Advantages of Real Estate Investment

  • Leverage - Control large assets with limited capital by borrowing
  • Appreciation - Value increases over time
  • Income - Cash flow from rent
  • Tax benefits - Depreciation and interest deductions

Disadvantages

  • Not highly liquid
  • Risk of vacancies and market swings
  • Unexpected expenses

Risk and Return

Risk is the chance that actual return will differ from expected return. Higher risk often accompanies higher potential reward.

Leverage magnifies gains but also magnifies losses. High leverage increases risk because debt payments must be made even when income declines.

Key Points to Remember

  • Leverage allows control with limited capital
  • Real estate is not liquid
  • Higher leverage = higher risk

lessons.title: Tax Liens
lessons.content:
1031 Exchange, Save Our Homes, Non-Deductible Items

In this final lesson, we examine tax-deferred exchanges and Save Our Homes.

1031 Exchange

Allows investors to defer capital gains tax by exchanging one investment property for another. Requirements:

  • Properties must be like-kind
  • Strict time limits for identification and closing
  • Tax is deferred, not forgiven

Save Our Homes

Florida's amendment limits annual increases in assessed value for homesteaded property to the lesser of 3% or the change in CPI. Protects homeowners from large tax increases.

Non-Deductible Items

For homeowners and investors:

  • Principal payments
  • Personal expenses
  • Improvements to primary residence (not deductible but add to basis)

Exam Rules to Remember

  • Homeowners deduct interest and property taxes only
  • Investors deduct a wide range of expenses including depreciation
  • 1031 exchanges defer but do not eliminate tax
  • Capital gain = Selling price - Adjusted basis

Key Points to Remember

  • 1031 exchange defers tax, doesn't eliminate it
  • Save Our Homes limits annual assessment increases to 3% or CPI
  • Principal payments are never deductible

lessons.title: Property Taxes
lessons.content:
Property Taxes, Assessed Value, Exemptions, Taxable Value

Welcome to Unit 18 of the FoundationCE Florida Sales Associate Pre-Licensing Course. This unit explains property taxes, exemptions, and federal tax rules.

Ad Valorem Taxes

Florida real estate taxes are ad valorem taxes, meaning "based on value."

Assessed Value

The county property appraiser determines assessed value. Market value is what the property would sell for. Assessed value is market value minus assessment limitations.

Florida Homestead Exemption

A Florida resident who owns and occupies property as primary residence may receive up to $50,000 exemption:

  • First $25,000 applies to all property taxes
  • Second $25,000 applies only to non-school taxes

Calculating Property Tax

Taxable value = Assessed value - Exemptions

Property tax = Taxable value x Millage rate

Millage is expressed as dollars per thousand dollars of taxable value.

Example: $100,000 taxable value x 20 mills = $2,000 tax

Key Points to Remember

  • Ad valorem means based on value
  • Homestead exemption is up to $50,000
  • Millage = dollars per $1,000 of value

lessons.title: Special Assessments
lessons.content:
Depreciation, Basis, Capital Gains, Federal Taxation

In this lesson, we study federal income tax rules for homeowners and investors.

Homeowner Deductions

Homeowners may deduct mortgage interest and property taxes. They cannot deduct repairs or improvements.

Investor Deductions

Investors may deduct operating expenses, mortgage interest, property taxes, insurance, repairs, maintenance, management fees, and depreciation.

Depreciation

Cost recovery for income-producing property. Land cannot be depreciated.

Residential rental property is depreciated over 27.5 years using straight-line depreciation.

Annual depreciation = (Purchase price - Land value + Improvements) / 27.5

Capital Gains

Capital gain = Selling price - Adjusted basis

Adjusted basis = Original cost + Improvements - Depreciation taken

Homeowner Exclusion

Homeowners may exclude up to $250,000 of capital gains (single) or $500,000 (married filing jointly) if they owned and occupied the home for 2 of the previous 5 years.

Key Points to Remember

  • Land cannot be depreciated
  • Residential rental: 27.5 year depreciation
  • Capital gain = Selling price - Adjusted basis

lessons.title: Comprehensive Planning
lessons.content:
Environmental Hazards, CERCLA, Disclosure, Flood Zones

In this final lesson, we focus on environmental hazards and disclosure requirements.

Common Environmental Hazards

  • Asbestos - Found in older buildings; dangerous when disturbed; removal requires licensed professionals
  • Radon - Naturally occurring radioactive gas in soil; Florida requires radon disclosure
  • Lead-based paint - Banned after 1978; homes built before require federal disclosure and pamphlet
  • Mold - Grows in moist environments; may create health concerns

CERCLA (Superfund)

The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act created the Superfund program. Property owners, operators, and even lenders may be liable for cleanup. Liability is joint and several - one party may be held accountable for the entire cleanup.

Flood Zones

Designated by FEMA. Buyers with federally backed loans must carry flood insurance if in a special flood hazard area.

Wetlands

Protected areas requiring special permits for development.

Disclosure Requirements

Florida requires disclosure of known environmental defects. Lead paint disclosure required for pre-1978 homes.

Key Points to Remember

  • Lead paint disclosure for homes built before 1978
  • CERCLA liability is joint and several
  • Flood insurance required in special flood hazard areas
  • Radon disclosure required in Florida

lessons.title: Zoning Regulations
lessons.content:
Planning Authority, Zoning, Land Use Controls

Welcome to Unit 19 of the FoundationCE Florida Sales Associate Pre-Licensing Course. This unit explains planning, zoning, and environmental issues impacting real estate.

Police Power

Local governments regulate land use through police power, which includes zoning, building codes, subdivision regulations, and environmental protection.

Comprehensive Plans

Guide long-term development including goals for population growth, land use, transportation, utilities, and environmental protection.

Zoning Classifications

  • Residential - Regulates density, building height, lot size, setbacks, parking
  • Commercial - Regulates signage, traffic flow, intensity of use
  • Industrial - Controls hazardous activities, noise, truck routes
  • Agricultural - Preserves farmland, limits non-agricultural uses
  • Special purpose - Schools, hospitals, parks, government buildings

Key Points to Remember

  • Police power includes zoning and building codes
  • Comprehensive plans guide long-term development
  • Industrial zoning controls hazardous activities

lessons.title: Land Use Controls
lessons.content:
Variances, Exceptions, Nonconforming Use, Subdivisions

In this lesson, we examine how property owners obtain relief from zoning rules and how land is developed.

Nonconforming Use

A property use that existed before new zoning rules were adopted. Allowed to continue because it was legal when established. Cannot expand or intensify beyond what existed originally.

Variance

Permission to deviate from specific zoning requirements due to hardship. Does not change the zoning classification. Examples: reduced setback, modified height requirement.

Special Exception (Conditional Use)

Allows a use that is permitted only under certain conditions after public review. Examples: churches or day care centers in residential zones.

Subdivision Process

  1. Developer submits preliminary plat showing lot lines, streets, easements, drainage, utilities
  2. Review and approval
  3. Final plat recorded in public records

Building Permits and Certificates

Building permits required before construction. Inspections occur throughout building process. Certificate of occupancy issued when structure meets code requirements.

Key Points to Remember

  • Nonconforming use was legal when established
  • Variance allows deviation due to hardship
  • Certificate of occupancy confirms code compliance

lessons.title: MORTGAGE FUNDAMENTALS
lessons.content:
The Mortgage Transaction

When a buyer finances a real estate purchase, two primary documents create the lending relationship: the promissory note and the mortgage (or deed of trust in some states).

The Promissory Note:

The promissory note is the borrower's personal promise to repay the debt. It creates personal liability for the borrower and contains the essential terms of the loan.

Essential Elements of the Note:

Amount Borrowed (Principal): The original loan amount. This is the starting point for calculating payments and the basis for interest charges.

Interest Rate: The cost of borrowing money, expressed as an annual percentage. May be fixed for the loan term or adjustable based on market indices.

Payment Terms:

Payment amount

Payment frequency (typically monthly)

Payment due date

Where payments are sent

Loan Term: The time period for repayment, commonly 15 or 30 years for residential mortgages.

Default Provisions: What constitutes default and the consequences, including acceleration of the full balance.

Prepayment Terms: Whether the borrower may pay off the loan early and any penalties for doing so.

The Mortgage (Security Instrument):

The mortgage pledges the property as collateral for the debt. If the borrower defaults, the lender can foreclose and sell the property to recover the debt.

Key Mortgage Provisions:

Property Description: Legal description of the property being pledged as security.

Covenants (Borrower's Promises):

Make timely payments

Maintain property insurance

Pay property taxes

Keep property in good condition

Not commit waste

Occupy as principal residence (if required)

Acceleration Clause: Allows lender to demand full payment if borrower defaults on any term.

Due-on-Sale Clause (Alienation Clause): Requires full payment if property is sold or transferred, preventing assumption without lender approval.

Defeasance Clause: Provides that the mortgage is void upon full payment of the debt.

Parties to the Mortgage:

Mortgagor: The borrower who pledges property as security Mortgagee: The lender who receives the security interest

Lien Theory vs. Title Theory:

Florida is a lien theory state, meaning the borrower retains title to the property while the lender holds a lien against it. In title theory states, the lender holds title until the loan is paid.

Types of Mortgages by Payment Structure

Fully Amortizing Fixed-Rate Mortgage:

The most traditional mortgage structure with equal monthly payments throughout the loan term. Each payment includes principal and interest, with early payments being mostly interest and later payments being mostly principal.

Characteristics:

Fixed interest rate for entire term

Equal monthly payments

Predictable and stable

Common terms: 15, 20, 30 years

Fully paid at term end

Advantages:

Payment predictability

Protection from rate increases

Builds equity steadily

Simple to understand

Disadvantages:

Higher initial rate than ARMs

No benefit if rates decline (without refinancing)

Early payments mostly interest

Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (ARM):

An ARM has an interest rate that changes periodically based on a specified index plus a margin.

Components:

Index: A published interest rate used as the basis for adjustments. Common indices include:

Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR)

Treasury securities

Cost of Funds Index (COFI)

Margin: The lender's markup added to the index to determine the loan rate. Typically 2-3 percentage points.

Adjustment Period: How often the rate changes. Common structures:

5/1 ARM: Fixed for 5 years, then adjusts annually

7/1 ARM: Fixed for 7 years, then adjusts annually

3/1 ARM: Fixed for 3 years, then adjusts annually

Caps: Limits on how much the rate can change:

Periodic Cap: Maximum change per adjustment (e.g., 2%)

Lifetime Cap: Maximum change over loan life (e.g., 6%)

Payment Cap: Maximum payment change (less common)

Example ARM Calculation: Index: 4.5% Margin: 2.5% Fully Indexed Rate: 7.0% Initial Rate: 5.5% (discounted) Periodic Cap: 2% Lifetime Cap: 6%

After fixed period, rate adjusts to index plus margin, subject to caps.

Interest-Only Mortgage:

Borrower pays only interest for a specified period (typically 5-10 years), then begins paying principal and interest.

Characteristics:

Lower initial payments

No principal reduction during I/O period

Higher payments after I/O period ends

No equity build-up initially

Higher risk for borrowers

Balloon Mortgage:

A loan with payments based on a long amortization schedule but with the remaining balance due in full at a specified earlier date.

Example: $200,000 loan Payments calculated on 30-year amortization Balloon payment due in 7 years After 7 years of payments, remaining balance (approximately $175,000) is due in full

Uses:

Borrowers expecting to sell before balloon

Investors with planned exit strategy

Bridge financing situations

Graduated Payment Mortgage (GPM):

Payments start lower and increase over time, usually over 5-10 years, then level off.

Characteristics:

Initial payments may not cover interest (negative amortization)

Designed for borrowers expecting income growth

Higher total interest cost

Less common today

Loan-to-Value Ratio

The loan-to-value (LTV) ratio measures the loan amount relative to property value, indicating the lender's risk exposure.

Calculation: LTV = Loan Amount  Property Value (or Purchase Price, whichever is less)

Example: Purchase Price: $400,000 Loan Amount: $320,000 LTV: $320,000  $400,000 = 80%

LTV Significance:

Lower LTV (more equity):

Lower lender risk

Better interest rates

May avoid mortgage insurance

Easier approval

Higher LTV (less equity):

Higher lender risk

Higher interest rates

Mortgage insurance required (conventional over 80%)

Stricter qualification

Common LTV Thresholds:

LTV

Typical Requirements

80% or less

No PMI required (conventional)

80.01-95%

PMI required (conventional)

96.5%

FHA minimum (3.5% down)

100%

VA, USDA (no down payme

lessons.title: GOVERNMENT-BACKED LOANS
lessons.content:
FHA Loans (Federal Housing Administration)

FHA loans are insured by the Federal Housing Administration, part of HUD. The government insurance protects lenders against loss if borrowers default.

Key Characteristics:

Down Payment:

Minimum 3.5% with credit score 580+

Minimum 10% with credit score 500-579

Gift funds permitted for entire down payment

Credit Requirements:

Minimum score 500 (580 for 3.5% down)

More flexible than conventional

Manual underwriting available for lower scores

Debt Ratios:

Standard: 31% housing, 43% total DTI

May exceed with compensating factors

Energy-efficient homes may qualify for higher ratios

Property Requirements:

Must be owner-occupied primary residence

1-4 unit properties eligible

Condominiums must be FHA-approved

Minimum property standards enforced

FHA Mortgage Insurance:

Upfront Mortgage Insurance Premium (UFMIP):

1.75% of loan amount

May be financed into loan

Required on all FHA loans

Annual Mortgage Insurance Premium (MIP):

Varies based on loan term, LTV, and loan amount

Typically 0.55% annually for loans over 15 years

Paid monthly as part of payment

Required for life of loan (most cases since 2013)

FHA Loan Limits:

Loan limits vary by county based on median home prices:

Floor: $472,030 (2024, most areas)

Ceiling: $1,089,300 (2024, high-cost areas)

Florida limits vary by county

VA Loans (Department of Veterans Affairs)

VA loans are guaranteed by the Department of Veterans Affairs for eligible service members, veterans, and surviving spouses.

Eligibility:

Active Duty: Currently serving with 90+ continuous days

Veterans:

90+ days during wartime

181+ days during peacetime

Discharge other than dishonorable

National Guard/Reserves:

6+ years of service, or

90+ days active duty during wartime

Surviving Spouses: Spouse of service member who died in service or from service-connected disability

Certificate of Eligibility (COE): Document proving VA loan eligibility; obtained through VA or lender.

Key Characteristics:

Down Payment:

No down payment required (100% financing)

No maximum loan amount (lender discretion for amounts over county limit)

Credit Requirements:

No VA minimum, but lenders typically require 620+

Flexible underwriting

Residual income analysis required

Debt Ratios:

41% DTI guideline

Residual income more important than ratios

Compensating factors considered

VA Funding Fee:

One-time fee varying by:

Down payment amount

First-time vs. subsequent use

Regular military vs. Reserves/Guard

2024 Funding Fees (First Use):

0% down: 2.15%

5-10% down: 1.5%

10%+ down: 1.25%

Exemptions:

Veterans receiving VA disability compensation

Surviving spouses

Purple Heart recipients on active duty

VA Loan Benefits:

No PMI or MIP

No prepayment penalty

Assumable (with VA approval)

Limited closing costs

VA assistance if borrower has difficulty paying

USDA Loans (Rural Development)

USDA loans are guaranteed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture for rural and suburban homebuyers.

Eligibility:

Property Location: Must be in USDA-eligible rural area (many suburban areas qualify)

Income Limits: Household income cannot exceed 115% of area median income

Property Use: Primary residence only; no working farms

Key Characteristics:

Down Payment:

No down payment required (100% financing)

Credit Requirements:

Typically 640+ for automated approval

Manual underwriting available for lower scores

Debt Ratios:

29% housing ratio

41% total DTI

May exceed with compensating factors

USDA Fees:

Upfront Guarantee Fee: 1% of loan amount (may be financed)

Annual Fee: 0.35% of loan balance (paid monthly)

USDA Advantages:

Zero down payment

Lower fees than FHA

Competitive interest rates

Flexible credit guidelines

lessons.title: LOAN QUALIFICATION AND UNDERWRITING
lessons.content:
The Loan Application Process

Pre-Qualification vs. Pre-Approval:

Pre-Qualification:

Informal estimate of borrowing capacity

Based on borrower-provided information

No verification of income or assets

Not a commitment to lend

Useful for initial planning

Pre-Approval:

Formal underwriting review

Income, assets, and credit verified

Conditional commitment to lend

Subject to property appraisal and title

Stronger position when making offers

Loan Application (Form 1003):

The Uniform Residential Loan Application collects comprehensive borrower information:

Personal information and identification

Employment history (2 years)

Income details

Asset information

Liabilities and debts

Property information

Transaction details

Declarations and authorizations

The Three C's of Underwriting

Underwriters evaluate loan applications based on three primary factors:

1. Credit (Credit History and Score)

Credit Score: FICO scores range from 300-850, with higher scores indicating lower risk.

Score Range

Rating

Loan Impact

760+

Excellent

Best rates available

700-759

Good

Favorable rates

660-699

Fair

Higher rates

620-659

Poor

Limited options, high rates

Below 620

Very Poor

Difficult to qualify

Credit Report Review:

Payment history (35% of score)

Amounts owed (30%)

Length of credit history (15%)

New credit (10%)

Credit mix (10%)

Red Flags:

Late payments

Collections

Bankruptcies

Foreclosures

Judgments

High credit utilization

2. Capacity (Ability to Repay)

Income Verification:

Pay stubs (most recent 30 days)

W-2s (past 2 years)

Tax returns (past 2 years)

Bank statements

Employment verification

Income Types:

Salary/wages

Self-employment income (averaged over 2 years)

Commissions and bonuses (averaged, with history)

Rental income (typically 75% counted)

Investment income

Retirement income

Alimony/child support (if consistent)

Qualification Ratios:

Housing Ratio (Front-End): Monthly Housing Expense  Gross Monthly Income

Housing expense includes PITI:

Principal

Interest

Taxes

Insurance

HOA dues (if applicable)

Mortgage insurance (if applicable)

Typical maximum: 28% (conventional), 31% (FHA)

Debt-to-Income Ratio (Back-End): Total Monthly Debt Payments  Gross Monthly Income

Includes housing expense plus:

Car payments

Student loans

Credit card minimums

Other installment debt

Child support/alimony

Typical maximum: 36-43% (conventional), 43% (FHA standard), up to 50% with compensating factors

Example Qualification:

Gross Monthly Income: $8,000



Housing Expense:

  Principal & Interest: $1,400

  Property Taxes: $350

  Insurance: $100

  PMI: $150

  Total PITI: $2,000



Housing Ratio: $2,000  $8,000 = 25%  (under 28%)



Other Monthly Debts:

  Car Payment: $450

  Student Loan: $300

  Credit Cards: $150

  Total Other Debt: $900



Total Monthly Obligations: $2,000 + $900 = $2,900

DTI Ratio: $2,900  $8,000 = 36.25%  (under 43%)

3. Collateral (Property Value and Condition)

Appraisal Requirements:

Independent appraisal required

Value must support loan amount

Property must meet condition standards

Appraisal valid for limited time

Property Requirements:

Marketable title

Adequate access

Habitable condition

No health/safety hazards

Conforming use

Compensating Factors

When borrowers don't meet standard guidelines, compensating factors may allow approval:

Large cash reserves (6+ months PITI)

Substantial down payment (20%+)

Minimal payment increase from current housing

Long employment history with same employer

Excellent credit history

Conservative debt levels

Potential for increased income

Automated Underwriting Systems (AUS)

Most loans are initially evaluated by automated systems:

Desktop Underwriter (DU): Fannie Mae's system Loan Prospector (LP): Freddie Mac's system

These systems analyze application data and provide:

Approve/Eligible

Refer with Caution

Refer/Ineligible

Automated approvals streamline processing; referrals require manual underwriting.

lessons.title: EDUCATION AND EXPERIENCE REQUIREMENTS
lessons.content:
Pre-License Education: The 72-Hour Broker Course

The broker pre-license course (FREC Course II) is mandatory for all broker applicants except those qualifying under specific exemptions. This comprehensive course covers advanced topics in real estate brokerage, management, and compliance.

Course Content Requirements:

The 72-hour broker course must include instruction in:

Part I: Brokerage Business Operations (20 hours)

Broker licensure requirements

Opening and registering a real estate office

Business structures and entity registration

Office management and supervision

Escrow account management

Office inspections and compliance

Disciplinary procedures

Real Estate Recovery Fund

Part II: Property Valuation (12 hours)

Appraisal principles and practices

Sales comparison approach

Cost-depreciation approach

Income capitalization approach

Comparative market analysis (CMA)

Business valuation methods

Part III: Listing and Selling (20 hours)

Agency relationships and disclosure requirements

Contract preparation and review

Real estate financing

Closing procedures and documentation

Federal income tax implications

Investment analysis

Part IV: Specialty Topics (20 hours)

Investment real estate

Zoning, planning, and land development

Environmental issues

Property management

Course Delivery Methods:

Florida approves several formats for broker pre-license education:

Classroom Instruction: Traditional in-person classes

Distance Education: Online courses through approved providers

Live Interactive Distance: Virtual classroom with real-time instructor interaction

Blended Format: Combination of online and classroom instruction

Attendance and Completion Requirements:

Must complete all 72 hours of instruction

No attendance credit for arriving late or leaving early

Distance education tracks time actually spent on materials

Must pass course final examination (typically 100 questions, 75% passing score)

Course completion certificate valid for two years from completion date

Must apply for license within two-year validity period

Exceptions to Pre-License Education

Florida law provides limited exceptions to the broker pre-license course requirement:

1. Mutual Recognition Exception:

Applicants from mutual recognition states

Must still complete 40-hour Florida law course

Must pass Florida broker examination

Does NOT waive all education requirements

2. Attorney Exception:

Active members of The Florida Bar in good standing

Must have practiced law in Florida for at least five years

Exemption applies to pre-license course only

Must still pass broker examination

Must still meet experience requirements

No exemption from continuing education

3. Four-Year Degree in Real Estate:

Bachelor's degree with major in real estate from accredited institution

Degree must include substantially similar course content

FREC must approve degree program as equivalent

Very few programs qualify for this exemption

Must still pass broker examination

Important Notes on Exceptions:

Exceptions are narrowly construed

Burden of proof on applicant to demonstrate qualification

Most applicants must complete full 72-hour course

No exceptions for prior business experience or other professional licenses

Experience Requirement

All broker applicants must demonstrate practical experience in real estate sales:

Basic Experience Requirement:

Must hold active sales associate license for 24 months during preceding five years

License must have been in active status (not inactive)

Time spent on inactive status does not count toward requirement

Experience must be as sales associate, not as unlicensed assistant

Qualifying Experience:

Acceptable experience includes:

Active sales associate license in Florida

Active salesperson license from another state (if equivalent)

Time working as licensed sales associate

Full-time or part-time activity (no minimum hours required)

Non-Qualifying Experience:

The following do NOT satisfy the experience requirement:

Time spent in broker pre-license education

Time as unlicensed personal assistant

Time as property manager without license

Time on inactive license status

Experience prior to initial licensure

Non-real estate business experience

Documentation of Experience:

DBPR verifies experience through:

License status verification system

Computer records of license history

Applicant's sworn statement on application

Contact with prior employing brokers if questions arise

Special Situations:

Expired License:

If license expired during qualifying period, time does not count

Must reactivate license to continue accumulating experience

Gap in licensure does not disqualify if 24 months accumulated

Multiple State Licenses:

Can combine experience from multiple states

Must provide verification from each state

All licenses must have been in good standing

Active Military Service:

Special provisions for interrupted experience

Contact DBPR for specific guidance on military service interruptions

Broker License Examination

After completing education and experience requirements, applicants must pass the state broker examination:

Examination Format:

100 multiple-choice questions

3.5 hours to complete

Computer-based testing at approved centers

Passing score: 75% (75 correct answers)

Two portions: general real estate law and broker-specific content

Examination Content Areas:

Real Estate Law and Rules (approximately 30%)

Chapter 475, Florida Statutes

Chapter 61J2, Florida Administrative Code

License law violations and penalties

FREC regulations and procedures

Brokerage Operations (approximately 25%)

Office management

Supervision of associates

Business entity registration

Escrow account management

Record-keeping requirements

Property Valuation (approximately 15%)

Appraisal approaches

Market analysis

Investment analysis

Contracts and Transactions (approximately 20%)

Agency relationships

Contract requirements

Disclosure obligations

lessons.title: NONRESIDENT APPLICANTS AND MUTUAL RECOGNITION
lessons.content:
Defining Residency for Licensing Purposes

Florida law establishes specific criteria for determining residency status for real estate licensing:

Florida Resident Defined: A person is considered a Florida resident for licensing purposes if they have resided in Florida for at least four consecutive months within the preceding year. This definition applies specifically to real estate licensing and may differ from other legal definitions of residency.

Nonresident Defined: Any person who does not meet the Florida resident criteria is classified as a nonresident for licensing purposes, regardless of property ownership or other connections to Florida.

Importance of Classification: Residency status affects:

License application procedures

Continuing education requirements

Service of process requirements

License renewal procedures

Nonresident Broker Applications

Nonresident applicants must meet the same basic requirements as Florida residents but with additional considerations:

Educational Requirements:

Must complete Florida's 72-hour Broker Pre-License Course

Online education acceptable if approved by FREC

Out-of-state courses do not satisfy Florida requirements

No exceptions to course requirement for nonresidents

Experience Requirements:

Must document 24 months of active licensure as a sales associate

Experience can be from any state with equivalent licensing

License must have been active (not inactive) during qualifying period

DBPR verifies experience through interstate databases

Additional Nonresident Requirements:

Consent to Service of Process:

Nonresidents must file consent with DBPR

Designates Florida Secretary of State as agent for service

Ensures legal documents can be served in disciplinary matters

Remains in effect for duration of licensure

Physical Office Location:

May maintain office in another state

Must register Florida office address with DBPR

Office must meet minimum Florida requirements if conducting Florida business

Branch offices must comply with Florida regulations

Continuing Education:

Must complete Florida-specific continuing education

No substitution of other states' courses

Must include Florida core law component

Same renewal cycle as Florida residents

Mutual Recognition Agreements

Florida has established mutual recognition agreements with certain states to facilitate interstate licensure. These agreements provide streamlined application processes for qualified licensees.

States with Mutual Recognition: As of 2025, Florida maintains mutual recognition with:

Alabama

Arkansas

Connecticut

Georgia

Illinois

Kentucky

Massachusetts

Mississippi

Nebraska

Oklahoma

Pennsylvania

Rhode Island

West Virginia

Benefits of Mutual Recognition:

Waiver of pre-license education requirement

Waiver of experience requirement

Streamlined application process

Reduced application fees in some cases

Qualifying for Mutual Recognition:

Applicants must meet ALL the following criteria:

Hold active broker license in mutual recognition state

License must be in good standing (no disciplinary actions)

Must have passed that state's broker examination

Must have been actively licensed for minimum period (typically 12 months)

Must complete Florida-specific law course (typically 40 hours)

Important Limitations:

Mutual recognition does NOT waive the Florida law course requirement

Does NOT waive the Florida examination requirement

Does NOT provide automatic licensure (must still apply)

Subject to background check and character review

Application Process Under Mutual Recognition:

Complete mutual recognition application form

Provide certified license history from home state

Submit to background check and fingerprinting

Complete 40-hour Florida broker law course

Pass Florida broker law examination

Pay required fees

Receive Florida broker license upon approval

Interstate Practice Considerations

Brokers licensed in multiple states must understand jurisdictional limitations:

Where License Required:

Where property is located

Where buyer/seller physically signs documents

Where negotiations primarily occur

Where advertising is directed

Multi-State Transactions:

Referral fees may require both states' licenses

Virtual transactions require careful analysis

Advertising across state lines requires compliance with both states

lessons.title: BROKER LICENSE APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS
lessons.content:
Application Process Overview

Becoming a licensed real estate broker in Florida requires meeting specific statutory requirements established by Chapter 475, Florida Statutes. The broker license represents the highest level of real estate licensure in the state and carries significant responsibilities for supervision, management, and compliance.

Basic Eligibility Requirements

To qualify for a broker license in Florida, an applicant must:

Age Requirement: Be at least 18 years old

Citizenship/Legal Status: Be a United States citizen, legal permanent resident, or have legal authorization to work in the United States

Education: Complete the required 72-hour Broker Pre-License Course (FREC Course II)

Experience: Hold an active sales associate license for at least 24 months during the preceding five years

Examination: Pass the state broker license examination

Character: Demonstrate good moral character and fitness to practice

Application Fees

The Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR) establishes fees for broker licensure:

Initial Application Fee: Currently $89

Initial Licensure Fee: $89

Total Initial Cost: $178 (subject to change)

These fees are non-refundable once the application is processed, regardless of approval or denial.

Fee Waivers for Specific Groups

Florida law provides fee waivers for certain applicants:

Low-Income Applicants:

Must demonstrate financial hardship

Annual household income at or below 130% of federal poverty guidelines

Must provide documentation of income status

Waiver applies to application and initial licensure fees

Military Personnel and Spouses:

Active duty members of U.S. Armed Forces stationed in Florida

Spouses of active duty military members

Must provide military identification and documentation

Expedited processing available

Military Veterans and Spouses:

Honorably discharged veterans within 60 months of discharge

Spouses of such veterans

Must provide DD Form 214 or equivalent documentation

One-time waiver for initial application

Background Checks and Fingerprinting

All broker applicants must undergo comprehensive background screening:

Fingerprinting Requirements:

Electronic fingerprinting through approved vendor

FBI and FDLE criminal history check

Additional fee approximately $75-$100

Results valid for five years

Criminal History Review: The DBPR reviews all criminal history including:

Felony convictions

Misdemeanor convictions involving moral turpitude

Pending criminal charges

Prior disciplinary actions in any profession

Consequences of Failing to Disclose

Failure to disclose required information on the application constitutes grounds for denial or disciplinary action. Specifically:

Disclosure Requirements:

All criminal convictions (felonies and misdemeanors)

Pending criminal charges

Prior license denials, suspensions, or revocations

Civil judgments relating to professional conduct

Bankruptcy filings within the past ten years

Penalties for Non-Disclosure:

Automatic denial of application

Permanent bar from licensure for fraudulent applications

Criminal prosecution for providing false information

Civil penalties up to $5,000

Revocation of license if non-disclosure discovered after licensure

Important Note: Even minor offenses must be disclosed. The DBPR considers honesty more important than the offense itself. Many applicants with criminal history are approved if fully disclosed and explained.

Self-Reporting Requirement

Licensed brokers must report certain events within 30 days:

Criminal convictions

Pleas of guilty or nolo contendere

Administrative actions by other regulatory agencies

Civil judgments relating to professional practice

Failure to self-report within the required timeframe constitutes a separate violation subject to disciplinary action.

lessons.title: BUSINESS STRUCTURES FOR BROKERAGE ENTITIES
lessons.content:
Overview of Brokerage Business Structures

Florida law permits real estate brokerages to operate under various business structures. Each structure has distinct characteristics, advantages, disadvantages, and registration requirements. Brokers must understand these differences to select the appropriate structure for their business goals.

Sole Proprietorship

The sole proprietorship is the simplest and most common business structure for individual brokers starting their first real estate office.

Characteristics:

Single Owner:

Business owned and operated by one person

Owner is the broker

No separate legal entity from owner

Simplest form of business organization

Unlimited Personal Liability:

Owner personally liable for all business debts

No legal separation between personal and business assets

Creditors can pursue owner's personal property

Significant financial risk for owner

Taxation:

Business income taxed as personal income

Report on Schedule C of Form 1040

No separate business tax return

Self-employment tax applies

Management:

Owner makes all decisions

No board of directors or partners

Complete control over operations

Owner performs all broker duties

Registration Requirements:

When operating as sole proprietorship:

Broker's individual license serves as the qualifying broker license

If operating under broker's own legal name (e.g., "John Smith, Real Estate Broker"), no trade name registration required

If using any other name (e.g., "Sunshine Realty"), must register trade name with DBPR and comply with Fictitious Name Act

Must register office address with DBPR

Dissolution:

Sole proprietorship automatically dissolves when:

Owner ceases business operations

Owner dies

Owner's broker license suspended or revoked

No formal dissolution procedure required for simple closure

Must notify DBPR of closure and return license

Advantages:

Easy and inexpensive to establish

Complete control by owner

Simple tax reporting

All profits belong to owner

Disadvantages:

Unlimited personal liability

Difficult to raise capital

Business dies with owner

All responsibility on one person

General Partnership

A general partnership involves two or more persons carrying on a business for profit. This structure allows brokers to pool resources and share responsibilities.

Characteristics:

Multiple Owners:

Two or more partners

At least one partner must be a licensed broker

Each partner contributes capital, labor, or expertise

Partners share profits and losses

Unlimited Joint and Several Liability:

Each partner personally liable for all partnership debts

Liability extends to actions of other partners

One partner can bind entire partnership

Creditors can pursue any partner's personal assets

Taxation:

Partnership itself does not pay income tax

Pass-through taxation to individual partners

Each partner reports share of income/loss on personal return

Partnership files informational Form 1065

Management:

Unless otherwise agreed, all partners have equal management rights

Major decisions typically require unanimous consent

Day-to-day decisions may be delegated

Partnership agreement governs management structure

Forming a General Partnership:

Under Florida law, general partnerships may be formed:

Express Agreement: Written or oral partnership agreement

Implied by Conduct: Actions suggesting partnership relationship

Formal Documents: Partnership agreement recommended but not required

Registration Requirements:

For real estate brokerage partnerships:

At least one partner must hold active Florida broker license

Register partnership as brokerage entity with DBPR

File trade name if not using partners' surnames

Active broker serves as qualifying broker

If multiple broker-partners, designate one as qualifying broker

All broker-partners must be registered

Register partnership office address

Dissolution:

General partnerships dissolve upon:

Death of a partner

Withdrawal of a partner

Expiration of partnership term (if specified)

Mutual agreement of partners

Bankruptcy of partnership or partner

Court order

Revocation of qualifying broker's license

Ostensible Partnership (Quasi-Partnership):

Florida law recognizes "ostensible partnerships" - situations where persons hold themselves out as partners even without formal partnership:

Created by appearance and public perception

Results when persons represent themselves as partners

Can create liability even without formal agreement

Persons who appear to be partners may be held liable as such

Important to clearly define business relationships

Partnership Agreements:

While not required by law, written partnership agreements are strongly recommended and should address:

Capital contributions of each partner

Profit and loss sharing ratios

Management responsibilities

Decision-making procedures

Admission of new partners

Withdrawal procedures

Dissolution terms

Dispute resolution

Advantages:

Easier to raise capital than sole proprietorship

Shared management responsibilities

Combined expertise and resources

Relatively simple to form

Disadvantages:

Unlimited joint and several liability

Potential for partner disputes

Difficulty removing problem partners

Partnership dissolves upon partner's death or withdrawal

Limited Partnership

A limited partnership provides a structure where some investors can have limited liability while others actively manage the business.

Characteristics:

Two Types of Partners:

General Partners: Manage business, unlimited liability

Limited Partners: Passive investors, liability limited to investment

Management:

General partners control daily operations

Limited partners cannot participate in management

If limited partner participates in management, may lose limited liability protection

Liability:

General partners: Unlimited personal liability

Limited partners: Liability limited to amount invested

Limited partners protected from partnership debts beyond investment

Tax

lessons.title: TRADE NAMES AND FICTITIOUS NAME ACT
lessons.content:
Trade Names in Real Estate

A trade name (also called a fictitious name or "DBA" - doing business as) is any name under which a business operates that differs from the legal name of the owner or entity.

Examples:

John Smith (sole proprietor) operating as "Coastal Realty" - "Coastal Realty" is trade name

ABC Properties, Inc. operating as "Premier Real Estate Group" - "Premier" is trade name

Smith & Jones Partnership operating as "Sunshine Realty" - "Sunshine" is trade name

Registering Trade Names with DBPR

Florida requires all real estate brokerage trade names to be registered with DBPR before use.

When Registration Required:

Trade name registration with DBPR is required when:

Operating under any name other than broker's legal name (sole proprietor)

Corporate name differs from name used in advertising

Any variation from registered entity name

Using a shortened version of legal entity name

When Registration NOT Required:

No trade name registration needed when:

Sole proprietor using own legal name (e.g., "John Smith, Real Estate Broker")

Partnership using all partners' surnames

Corporation using exact corporate name as registered

LLC using exact LLC name as registered

DBPR Trade Name Registration Procedure:

Check Name Availability:

Search DBPR database for conflicting names

Name must be distinguishable from existing registered names

Cannot be deceptively similar to existing broker names

Complete Application:

Submit trade name registration application to DBPR

Provide qualifying broker license number

Provide brokerage entity registration number

Include all variations of trade name to be used

Pay Fee:

Registration fee required (currently included in entity registration)

Renews with broker's license

Receive Approval:

DBPR reviews for conflicts

Approves or denies registration

If approved, trade name registered to brokerage entity

Restrictions on Trade Names:

DBPR prohibits trade names that:

Are deceptively similar to existing registered names

Include words implying government affiliation unless authorized

Suggest services not provided

Violate trademark rights

Are misleading to public

Include "Realty" or "Real Estate" without including broker designation

Florida Fictitious Name Act

In addition to DBPR registration, Florida's Fictitious Name Act (Chapter 865, F.S.) governs use of trade names.

Purpose: The Fictitious Name Act protects public by requiring:

Disclosure of true ownership of businesses operating under trade names

Public record of who is behind each trade name

Transparency in business operations

Registration Requirements:

Who Must Register: Any person or entity conducting business under a fictitious name must register with Florida Division of Corporations.

Registration Procedure:

Prepare Application:

Fictitious Name Registration form

List legal name of owner(s)

Provide business address

Describe nature of business

Publish Notice (if required):

Some counties require publication in newspaper

Publication must occur before registration

Proof of publication submitted with application

File with Division of Corporations:

Submit application online or by mail

Pay filing fee ($50)

File within 30 days of first use of fictitious name

Renew Registration:

Renew every five years

Failure to renew results in cancellation

Exemptions from Fictitious Name Act:

The following are exempt from Fictitious Name Act registration:

Corporations using corporate name as registered

Limited partnerships using name as registered

Professional associations using members' names

Persons or entities selling only their own property (not in business)

Non-profit organizations

Important Note for Real Estate Brokers:

Even if exempt from Fictitious Name Act, real estate brokers still must register trade names with DBPR. The two registration requirements are separate:

DBPR Registration: Required for all brokerage trade names (regulatory)

Fictitious Name Act Registration: Required unless exempt (corporate transparency)

Consequences of Non-Compliance:

Failure to register fictitious name under Chapter 865:

Cannot maintain lawsuit in Florida courts using fictitious name

Cannot enforce contracts entered under unregistered name

Subject to civil penalties

No effect on validity of contracts, but limits enforcement

Professional Associations and Trade Names

Sales Associates Forming Professional Associations:

A sales associate or broker associate may form a professional association (PA) or corporation in the associate's legal name for tax purposes, but:

Restrictions:

PA or corporation cannot engage in real estate brokerage

Cannot hold brokerage license

Used only for receiving compensation from employing broker

Associate still registers under employing broker, not PA

PA name cannot be used in advertising except as required by IRS

Cannot give appearance of being separate brokerage

Example: Jane Doe, sales associate, forms "Jane Doe, P.A." for tax purposes. She still registers under ABC Realty as "Jane Doe." She cannot advertise as "Jane Doe, P.A., Real Estate." The PA is merely a tax entity, not a real estate brokerage.

lessons.title: BUSINESS FORMS THAT CANNOT REGISTER
lessons.content:
Prohibited Business Structures

Florida law specifically prohibits certain business forms from registering as real estate brokerage entities. Understanding these limitations prevents improper structuring.

Corporation Sole

Definition: A corporation sole is a legal entity consisting of a single incorporated office occupied by a single person (typically a religious leader or public official).

Characteristics:

Perpetual succession through office holder

Historically used by churches

Single individual constitutes the corporation

Office, not person, is the legal entity

Why Prohibited:

Incompatible with broker supervision requirements

Difficult to maintain continuity

Unclear liability structure

Not designed for commercial business

Joint Venture (Joint Adventure)

Definition: A joint venture is a business relationship created for a single transaction or limited series of transactions.

Characteristics:

Temporary business relationship

Formed for specific purpose

Similar to partnership but limited duration

Dissolves when purpose accomplished

Why Prohibited:

Temporary nature incompatible with ongoing brokerage operations

Broker supervision requires continuity

Difficult to maintain regulatory oversight

Consumer protection concerns with temporary entities

Example: Two brokers forming a joint venture to develop and sell a single property cannot register as a brokerage entity. Each broker must operate through their own separately registered brokerage.

Business Trust

Definition: A business trust is an unincorporated business organization created by a legal document (declaration of trust) where trustees hold legal title to property for benefit of beneficiaries.

Characteristics:

Trustees manage assets

Beneficiaries receive profits

Separation between management and ownership

Historically used for holding real property

Why Prohibited:

Complex governance structure

Unclear lines of authority and responsibility

Difficult to determine qualifying broker

Incompatible with broker supervision requirements

Consumer protection concerns

Associations

Definition: An unincorporated association is a group of persons acting together for a common purpose without creating a formal business entity.

Characteristics:

Informal organization

No legal entity separate from members

Members may have personal liability

Typically used for clubs, advocacy groups

Why Prohibited:

No formal legal structure

Cannot properly register as entity

Unclear liability

Inadequate consumer protection

Cannot maintain continuous operations

Examples of Prohibited Association Structures:

Group of brokers operating as "XYZ Realty Association"

Informal collective of licensees

Cooperative arrangements without formal entity

Summary of Acceptable Entity Types

To operate a real estate brokerage in Florida, must use one of these structures:

Sole proprietorship

General partnership

Limited partnership

Limited liability partnership

Corporation

Limited liability company

lessons.title: CAPITAL REQUIREMENTS AND START-UP COSTS
lessons.content:
Capital Requirements for Starting a Brokerage

Opening a real estate brokerage requires substantial initial capital investment and ongoing financial resources. Understanding capital requirements is essential for successful business launch and sustainability.

Categories of Capital Needs:

Initial Start-Up Capital:

One-time expenses to establish the business

Equipment, furniture, and technology purchases

Legal and professional fees

Initial marketing and promotion

Deposits and advance payments

Working Capital:

Funds to cover operating expenses during ramp-up period

Bridge period before commission income becomes consistent

Typically need 6-12 months of operating expenses

Buffer for unexpected expenses or slow periods

Reserve Capital:

Emergency funds for unforeseen circumstances

Equipment replacement reserves

Economic downturn protection

Opportunity funds for growth

Determining Sufficient Capital:

New brokers should calculate:

Total start-up costs (one-time expenses)

Monthly operating expenses

Personal living expenses during start-up

Multiply monthly expenses by 12 months (minimum 6 months recommended)

Add 20% contingency for unexpected expenses

Formula: Total Capital Needed = Start-Up Costs + (Monthly Operating Expenses  12) + Contingency

Example Calculation:

Start-up costs: $25,000

Monthly operating expenses: $8,000

Personal living expenses: $5,000

Coverage period: 12 months

Total operating for 12 months: ($8,000 + $5,000)  12 = $156,000

Contingency (20%): $31,200

Total Capital Needed: $212,200

Initial Start-Up Costs

1. Attorney and Accountant Fees:

Attorney Services:

Business entity formation: $500-$2,500

Partnership or operating agreements: $1,000-$5,000

Contract review and templates: $1,000-$3,000

Employment agreements: $500-$2,000

Trademark/name searches: $500-$1,500

Estimated Total: $3,500-$14,000

Accountant Services:

Business structure consultation: $500-$1,500

Accounting system setup: $1,000-$3,000

Tax planning and registration: $500-$1,500

Bookkeeping system training: $500-$1,000

Estimated Total: $2,500-$7,000

Why Professional Services Essential:

Proper legal structure protects personal assets

Compliance with tax laws prevents costly penalties

Professional agreements prevent future disputes

Expert advice avoids expensive mistakes

2. Office Space:

Option A: Purchase Office Building

Advantages:

Build equity rather than paying rent

Fixed long-term housing costs

Appreciation potential

Tax benefits of ownership

Control over property modifications

Can rent excess space to generate income

Initial Costs:

Down payment (typically 20-30%): $40,000-$150,000+ depending on market

Closing costs (2-5% of purchase): $4,000-$15,000+

Immediate repairs/improvements: $5,000-$50,000+

Estimated Total: $49,000-$215,000+

Ongoing Costs:

Mortgage payment (principal and interest)

Property taxes

Property insurance

Maintenance and repairs

Utilities

Property management (if needed)

Option B: Lease Office Space

Advantages:

Much lower initial capital requirement

Flexibility to relocate or expand

No maintenance responsibility (typically)

Predictable monthly costs

Can start smaller and grow

Landlord handles major repairs

Initial Costs:

Security deposit (1-3 months): $2,000-$9,000

First and last month's rent: $4,000-$12,000

Leasehold improvements: $5,000-$25,000

Estimated Total: $11,000-$46,000

Ongoing Costs:

Monthly rent

Utilities (if not included)

Renter's insurance

Minor maintenance

Decision Factors:

Available capital

Long-term business plans

Market conditions

Desire for stability vs. flexibility

Risk tolerance

Local real estate market

3. Office Equipment and Furniture:

Essential Equipment:

Computer Systems:

Desktop computers (3-5 stations): $2,500-$5,000

Laptop computers (for mobile agents): $1,500-$3,000

Monitors and peripherals: $1,000-$2,000

Server or cloud infrastructure: $2,000-$5,000

Subtotal: $7,000-$15,000

Office Technology:

Multi-function printer/copier/scanner: $1,500-$5,000

Telephone system (VoIP or traditional): $1,000-$3,000

High-speed internet installation: $500-$1,500

Security system: $1,000-$3,000

Subtotal: $4,000-$12,500

Software Licenses:

Real estate MLS access: $500-$1,500 annually

Transaction management software: $1,000-$3,000 annually

Accounting software: $500-$2,000

Customer relationship management (CRM): $1,000-$3,000 annually

Microsoft Office or equivalent: $500-$1,500

Subtotal: $3,500-$11,000

Furniture:

Broker's desk and chair: $1,000-$3,000

Reception desk and seating: $1,500-$4,000

Conference table and chairs: $2,000-$5,000

Agent desks and chairs (5): $2,500-$7,500

Filing cabinets and storage: $1,000-$2,500

Office dcor and accessories: $1,000-$3,000

Subtotal: $9,000-$25,000

Total Equipment and Furniture: $23,500-$63,500

Lease vs. Purchase Considerations:

Leasing preserves capital

Purchasing provides long-term cost savings

Technology should be updated regularly

Consider 3-5 year replacement cycle

4. Signs and Lock Boxes:

Signage:

Office entrance sign (required): $300-$1,500

Monument sign (if permitted): $2,000-$8,000

Yard signs (50-100): $500-$1,500

Sign posts and hardware: $500-$1,000

Vehicle lettering/wraps: $500-$3,000 per vehicle

Subtotal: $3,800-$15,000

Lock Boxes:

Electronic lock boxes (10-20): $1,500-$3,000

Lock box keys/programming: $200-$500

Subtotal: $1,700-$3,500

Total Signs and Lock Boxes: $5,500-$18,500

5. Board of Realtors and MLS Fees:

Initial Membership Fees:

Local board of Realtors application: $200-$500
