Closing is when ownership transfers and the transaction is finalized.

Before closing:
- Final walkthrough to verify property condition
- Review closing disclosure for accuracy
- Confirm wire instructions directly with the title company

At closing:
- Sign all required documents
- Provide identification as required
- Deliver certified funds or wire transfer

The closing agent (often a title company or attorney) will:
- Collect and disburse all funds
- Record the deed
- Issue title insurance policies
- Distribute closing documents to all parties

lessons.title: Post-Closing Responsibilities
lessons.content:
After closing, several tasks remain:

For the buyer:
- Transfer utilities to their name
- File homestead exemption if applicable
- Change locks and security codes
- Update address with relevant parties

For the seller:
- Cancel utilities and redirect mail
- Keep copies of closing documents
- Maintain records for tax purposes

For the agents:
- Provide copies of all documents to clients
- Ensure all commission payments are properly distributed
- Maintain transaction files as required by law
- Follow up with clients for feedback and referrals

Record retention:
Florida law requires brokers to maintain transaction records for at least five years. This includes contracts, disclosures, correspondence, and financial records.

bankQuestions.questionText: The primary purpose of Florida real estate license law is to
bankQuestions.options: ["increase the income of real estate licensees","protect the public by regulating real estate brokers and sales associates","create a standard form of real estate contract","regulate interest rates"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Consumer protection is the primary purpose of real estate license law.

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker's fiduciary duties include all of the following EXCEPT
bankQuestions.options: ["loyalty to the client","confidentiality of client information","disclosure of material facts","guaranteeing the sale of the property"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Brokers cannot guarantee a sale. Fiduciary duties include loyalty, confidentiality, and disclosure.

bankQuestions.questionText: Which type of estate provides the highest degree of ownership
bankQuestions.options: ["Fee simple absolute","Life estate","Estate for years","Estate at will"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Fee simple absolute provides the most complete form of ownership with unlimited duration.

bankQuestions.questionText: A metes and bounds legal description typically begins at the
bankQuestions.options: ["principal meridian","point of beginning","baseline","section corner"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Metes and bounds descriptions start and return to a point of beginning.

bankQuestions.questionText: The Fair Housing Act prohibits discrimination based on all EXCEPT
bankQuestions.options: ["race","religion","marital status","national origin"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Federal Fair Housing Act does not include marital status as a protected class.

bankQuestions.questionText: An easement appurtenant requires
bankQuestions.options: ["a dominant and servient estate","a written lease agreement","government approval","payment of annual fees"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Easement appurtenant involves two properties: dominant (benefiting) and servient (burdened).

bankQuestions.questionText: The loan-to-value ratio is calculated by
bankQuestions.options: ["dividing the loan amount by the property value","multiplying the loan amount by the interest rate","dividing the property value by the loan amount","subtracting the down payment from the value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: LTV = Loan Amount / Property Value x 100

bankQuestions.questionText: The cost approach to value is most appropriate for
bankQuestions.options: ["residential properties","income properties","special-purpose properties","vacant land"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Cost approach is best for special-purpose properties with limited comparable sales.

bankQuestions.questionText: Which agency enforces the Fair Housing Act
bankQuestions.options: ["FBI","HUD","EPA","OSHA"]
bankQuestions.explanation: HUD (Housing and Urban Development) enforces the Fair Housing Act.

bankQuestions.questionText: The bundle of legal rights includes all EXCEPT
bankQuestions.options: ["right of possession","right of control","right of guaranteed value appreciation","right of disposition"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The bundle of rights does not include guaranteed appreciation.

bankQuestions.questionText: Eminent domain is the government's right to
bankQuestions.options: ["control land use through zoning","take private property for public use with compensation","impose property taxes","regulate building codes"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Eminent domain allows government to take property for public use with just compensation.

bankQuestions.questionText: Which of the following is a lien that affects all property owned
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgage lien","Mechanic's lien","Judgment lien","Property tax lien"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Judgment liens attach to all real property owned by the debtor in the county.

bankQuestions.questionText: In Florida, a written listing agreement is required
bankQuestions.options: ["for all types of listings","only for exclusive right of sale listings","to collect a commission when there's a dispute","only for commercial properties"]
bankQuestions.explanation: A written agreement is required to collect a commission when disputed.

bankQuestions.questionText: The statute of frauds requires that real estate contracts be
bankQuestions.options: ["verbal only","witnessed by two people","in writing to be enforceable","approved by an attorney"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The statute of frauds requires real estate contracts to be in writing to be enforceable.

bankQuestions.questionText: The gross rent multiplier is used to estimate
bankQuestions.options: ["property operating expenses","property value based on rental income","cap rate","net operating income"]
bankQuestions.explanation: GRM = Price / Gross Monthly Rent, used to estimate property value.

bankQuestions.questionText: Which activity is part of the scope of a real estate professional?
bankQuestions.options: ["Providing legal advice","Real property valuation (CMA)","Offering mortgage underwriting","Conducting environmental testing"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Real estate professionals may perform CMAs, which estimate value without producing an appraisal. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A licensee specializing in leasing office buildings works in:
bankQuestions.options: ["Industrial","Agricultural","Commercial real estate","Investment advisory"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Office, retail, and shopping centers fall under commercial specialization. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A real estate professional who sells businesses is a:
bankQuestions.options: ["Commercial broker","Property manager","Business broker","Mortgage lender"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Business brokerage involves selling going concerns, sometimes with real property. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A real estate professional who conducts valuation for a fee must be:
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgage officer","Property inspector","Licensed or certified appraiser","Title agent"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Only appraisers may collect compensation for formal valuation. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Developers who improve land and construct buildings are involved in:
bankQuestions.options: ["Property management","Development and construction","Residential brokerage","Government planning"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Developers convert raw land into residential or commercial property. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A property manager's primary goal is to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Minimize tenant turnover at all costs","Reduce gross rent","Protect the owner's investment and maximize NOI","Sell property quickly"]
bankQuestions.explanation: NOI and property preservation are central duties. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which specialization includes leasing industrial properties?
bankQuestions.options: ["Residential","Agricultural","Industrial real estate","Appraisal"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Industrial specialization includes plants, warehouses, and distribution centers. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which professional evaluates property condition?
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgage broker","Home inspector","Title agent","Sales associate"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Inspectors report on structure, systems, and conditions. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A tract development typically offers:
bankQuestions.options: ["Only custom-built homes","Model homes with standardized designs","Multi-family buildings only","Agricultural improvements"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Tract builders create uniform homes for large subdivisions. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A real estate licensee selling a business that includes inventory is working in:
bankQuestions.options: ["Residential","Commercial","Agricultural","Business brokerage"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Business brokerage involves personal property, contracts, goodwill, and sometimes real estate. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Property management involves:
bankQuestions.options: ["Representing both buyer and seller in a transaction","Selling agricultural land","Overseeing operations of income-producing property","Conducting commercial appraisals"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Property managers maximize NOI and preserve property value for owners. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A subdivision developer working with brokers to sell new homes is involved in:
bankQuestions.options: ["Appraisal","Residential tract sales","Business brokerage","Property management"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Tract sales involve new construction marketed through brokers. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which activity does not require a real estate license?
bankQuestions.options: ["Selling your own property","Selling property for a commission","Leasing property for a friend","Advertising a rental for pay"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Owners selling their own property are exempt from licensure. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which field involves selling large tracts of land used for production?
bankQuestions.options: ["Industrial","Commercial","Agricultural real estate","Professional appraisal"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Farms, groves, and ranches fall under agricultural specialization. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A real estate licensee preparing a CMA is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Acting as an appraiser","Violating USPAP","Providing an estimate of value for listing purposes","Performing illegal value work"]
bankQuestions.explanation: CMAs assist with pricing but do not constitute appraisals. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which party typically prepares deed instruments?
bankQuestions.options: ["Broker","Inspector","Attorney","Lender"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Drafting legal instruments is considered legal practice. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A comparative market analysis uses:
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgage ratios","Loan amortization","Recent comparable sales","Revised cost schedules"]
bankQuestions.explanation: CMAs rely on sales comparison to estimate price ranges. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A developer who both prepares the land and builds homes is a:
bankQuestions.options: ["Land planner","Architect","Builder-developer","Subdivider only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Builder-developers perform both subdividing and construction. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which party may conduct appraisals for federally related transactions?
bankQuestions.options: ["Sales associate","Broker","State-licensed or certified appraiser","Mortgage broker"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Federal law requires licensed/certified appraisers for such valuations. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The three phases of development and construction include:
bankQuestions.options: ["Planning, excavation, flipping","Acquisition, zoning, demolition","Land acquisition, subdividing, development","Leasing, marketing, sale"]
bankQuestions.explanation: These steps take land from raw form to a finished project. (Unit 1 - Subunit 1.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The entity that oversees all Florida professional licenses, including real estate, is:
bankQuestions.options: ["FREC","HUD","DBPR","NAR"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The Department of Business and Professional Regulation regulates and enforces professional licensing in Florida. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: To apply for a Florida sales associate license, an applicant must:
bankQuestions.options: ["Be a Florida resident","Have prior real estate experience","Have completed high school or equivalent","Pass a broker interview"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida requires only: age 18+, Social Security number, and a high-school diploma or equivalent. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: FREC's main purpose is to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Issue mortgages","Enforce federal fair-housing law","Enforce Chapter 475 and administer real estate license law","Train licensees"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The Florida Real Estate Commission enforces and interprets real estate law. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Nonresident applicants must complete which requirement?
bankQuestions.options: ["Florida residency within six months","Local broker sponsorship","Irrevocable Consent to Service of Process","Additional coursework"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This document allows Florida courts to accept legal service on the applicant's behalf. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A license becomes involuntary inactive when the licensee:
bankQuestions.options: ["Is disciplined by FREC","Chooses not to work","Fails to renew before expiration","Changes brokers"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Failure to renew on time triggers involuntary inactive status automatically. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: A license that has been involuntary inactive for more than 24 months becomes:
bankQuestions.options: ["Suspended","Probationary","Null and void","Expired but renewable"]
bankQuestions.explanation: After two years involuntary inactive, the license cannot be reinstated. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which activity requires a real estate license?
bankQuestions.options: ["Selling your own home","Receiving a referral fee from a friend","Managing your own rental property","Leasing property for another for compensation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Services for another + for compensation require licensure. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which type of license allows an individual to work for multiple entities?
bankQuestions.options: ["Inactive license","Group license","Multiple license","Temporary license"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Brokers may hold multiple licenses for different brokerage entities. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: A licensee who wishes to remain inactive must:
bankQuestions.options: ["Retake the exam","Complete post-licensing annually","Renew their inactive license each renewal cycle","Pay no fees"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Inactive licensees still must renew and pay fees to avoid expiration. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: FREC members are appointed by the:
bankQuestions.options: ["DBPR secretary","Supreme Court","Governor and confirmed by the Senate","Legislature"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The Governor appoints; Senate confirms. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A Florida licensee moving out of state must notify the DBPR within:
bankQuestions.options: ["48 hours","5 days","60 days","Next renewal period"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Licensees must file a change of residency within 60 days. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A sales associate applicant must submit fingerprints:
bankQuestions.options: ["After passing the course","Before activating their license","Before taking the state exam","Only if requested"]
bankQuestions.explanation: DBPR requires fingerprinting for background screening before state examination eligibility. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which is NOT a qualification for licensure?
bankQuestions.options: ["Age 18 or older","High school diploma","Social Security number","U.S. citizenship"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Citizenship is not required; only legal work eligibility and SSN are required. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A licensee who does not complete post-licensing before the first renewal:
bankQuestions.options: ["Must pay a late fee","Goes voluntary inactive","Must take extra CE","Has their license become null and void"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Post-licensing is mandatory; failure results in automatic nullification. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker must complete how many hours of post-licensing education?
bankQuestions.explanation: Brokers must complete 60 hours post-license before first renewal. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: Attorneys are exempt from which requirement?
bankQuestions.options: ["Taking the state exam","Fingerprinting","The 63-hour sales associate course","Paying license fees"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Attorneys in good standing are exempt from the pre-license course but must take the exam. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A group license is issued to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Attorneys","Sales associates","Nonresidents","Owner-developers with multiple affiliated project sites"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Sales associates working for an owner-developer receive group licenses covering all affiliated projects. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: FREC is composed of how many members?
bankQuestions.explanation: FREC consists of: 4 brokers, 1 sales associate/broker with 2+ years experience, 2 consumer (unlicensed) members. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A temporary license may be issued to:
bankQuestions.options: ["A broker with inactive status","A sales associate requesting reciprocity","The spouse of a military member relocated to Florida","A licensee who failed the exam once"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Military spouses may receive temporary licenses valid for 6 months. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The purpose of continuing education (CE) is to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Replace post-licensing","Reduce exam attempts","Ensure broker supervision","Maintain current knowledge of laws and practice"]
bankQuestions.explanation: CE ensures updated compliance and competency. (Unit 2 - Subunit 2.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which entity writes and enforces Florida real estate license law?
bankQuestions.options: ["DBPR","Legislature","FREC","The Governor"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The Florida Real Estate Commission (FREC) enforces and interprets Chapter 475, F.S. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: FREC's authority to adopt rules is considered:
bankQuestions.options: ["Judicial power","Executive power","Quasi-legislative power","Ministerial power"]
bankQuestions.explanation: FREC creates rules to enforce real estate lawsimilar to legislative rule-making. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which FREC action requires a majority vote?
bankQuestions.options: ["Denying an application","Suspending a license","Adopting a rule","Issuing citations"]
bankQuestions.explanation: All rulemaking actions require a majority vote by the Commission. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which statement is TRUE regarding citations?
bankQuestions.options: ["They are issued by the governor","They require a formal hearing","They are fines for minor violations","They suspend a license"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Citations are administrative fines that resolve minor violations quickly. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which penalty may FREC NOT impose?
bankQuestions.options: ["Fine up to $5,000 per violation","Reprimand","Suspension","Imprisonment"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Only criminal courts can impose jail sentences. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: How long must brokers retain records?
bankQuestions.options: ["1 year","3 years from closing","5 years or 2 years after litigation, whichever is longer","7 years always"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Record retention extends if litigation is ongoing. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: What happens if a rental list is found to be fraudulent?
bankQuestions.options: ["Refund only","Civil penalty only","Consumer receives 100% refund and triple damages","No consequences"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Fraudulent rental information carries treble damages. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: A license is revoked without prejudice when:
bankQuestions.options: ["The licensee committed fraud","The licensee fails CE","The licensee fails post-licensing education","The licensee requests a new broker"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This revocation does not involve discipline  it is due to failure to meet education requirements. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Who determines probable cause?
bankQuestions.options: ["Investigators","DBPR","A FREC probable-cause panel","Circuit court"]
bankQuestions.explanation: A panel of current or former FREC members reviews cases for sufficient grounds. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: If a licensee disagrees with an administrative complaint, the next step is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Refuse to appear","Do nothing","Request a formal hearing before an administrative law judge","Appeal immediately"]
bankQuestions.explanation: A formal hearing resolves disputed facts. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which body issues real estate licenses?
bankQuestions.options: ["FREC","DBPR, Division of Real Estate","State Senate","Governor's Office"]
bankQuestions.explanation: DBPR processes applications and issues licenses; FREC handles regulation and discipline. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: FREC's authority to impose disciplinary action is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Ministerial","Legislative","Quasi-judicial","Executive"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Quasi-judicial powers include suspension, revocation, and administrative fines. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A notice of noncompliance is issued for:
bankQuestions.options: ["Fraud","Escrow conversion","Minor first-time violations","Criminal offenses"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Used for quick correction of minor issues without formal discipline. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A summary (emergency) suspension may be issued when a licensee:
bankQuestions.options: ["Forgets to renew","Has low CE hours","Poses an immediate danger to the public","Changes brokers"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Emergency suspensions protect the public pending investigation. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A third-degree felony in real estate includes:
bankQuestions.options: ["False advertising","Practicing real estate without a license","Failure to display the license","Blockbusting"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Unlicensed activity is a serious offense punishable by criminal penalties. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: If an agent provides rental information that is inaccurate, the customer may demand a refund within:
bankQuestions.options: ["30 days","15 days","30 days for inaccuracy; 72 hours if unable to find rental","10 days"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida law requires a refund policy for rental lists. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: An administrative fine imposed by FREC may not exceed:
bankQuestions.options: ["$1,000 per violation","$5,000 per violation","$10,000 per violation","$25,000 per year"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This is the statutory maximum. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: What is the order of steps in the disciplinary process?
bankQuestions.options: ["Investigation  Legal review  Final order","Complaint filed  Investigation  Probable cause  Administrative hearing  Final order","Probable cause  Complaint  Investigation","Hearing  Complaint  Appeal"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This is the formal complaint and discipline sequence under Chapter 475. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which is TRUE of a legally sufficient complaint?
bankQuestions.options: ["Must include proof","Must be notarized","Must allege a possible violation of law or rule","Must be filed by a licensee"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Any person may file a complaint; proof comes later. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Final orders of FREC may be appealed by filing:
bankQuestions.options: ["A new complaint","A petition with the district court of appeal within 30 days","A letter to the governor","A Supreme Court writ"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Appeals go to Florida's District Courts of Appeal. (Unit 3 - Subunit 3.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Most homebuyers use which type of financing?
bankQuestions.options: ["Seller financing","Cash","Private loans","Amortized mortgage loans"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Most residential buyers use long-term amortized mortgages. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The lender in a mortgage is called the:
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgagor","Tenant","Buyer","Mortgagee"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Mortgagor = borrower; Mortgagee = lender. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which clause allows the lender to demand full repayment if the borrower defaults?
bankQuestions.options: ["Prepayment clause","Defeasance clause","Acceleration clause","Alienation clause"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Acceleration = entire balance becomes due. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which loan is insured by the federal government?
bankQuestions.options: ["VA loan","FHA loan","Conventional loan","Adjustable loan"]
bankQuestions.explanation: FHA provides mortgage insurance  NOT guarantees. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: PMI (Private Mortgage Insurance) is required when:
bankQuestions.options: ["LTV <= 80%","Buyer pays cash","Buyer uses FHA","LTV > 80% on conventional loans"]
bankQuestions.explanation: PMI protects the lender against default risk on high-LTV loans. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: A note and mortgage differ because the note:
bankQuestions.options: ["Creates a lien","Conveys property","Is the promise to repay the loan","Is recorded"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The mortgage secures the note; the note is the debt instrument. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which clause requires the borrower to pay off the loan when the property is sold?
bankQuestions.options: ["Acceleration clause","Due-on-sale (alienation) clause","Escalation clause","Subordination clause"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This prevents loan assumption without lender approval. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which loan is guaranteed by the federal government?
bankQuestions.options: ["FHA","Conventional","Adjustable","VA"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The VA guarantees a portion of the loan, allowing zero-down options. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: An ARM (Adjustable-Rate Mortgage) features:
bankQuestions.options: ["Fixed interest for full term","No rate changes ever","Interest rate tied to an index with periodic adjustments","No disclosures"]
bankQuestions.explanation: ARM pricing = index + margin. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: The borrower's monthly PITI includes:
bankQuestions.options: ["Principal only","Property value","Principal, Interest, Taxes, and Insurance","Utilities"]
bankQuestions.explanation: PITI is used to determine qualifying ratios. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: FHA qualifying ratios are:
bankQuestions.explanation: FHA allows higher DTI due to insured risk. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: In a partially amortized loan (balloon mortgage):
bankQuestions.options: ["No interest is paid","Entire balance amortizes fully","Payments reduce principal, but a large final balance remains","It is identical to an ARM"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Balloon payments are typical in commercial financing. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.8)

bankQuestions.questionText: The secondary mortgage market includes all EXCEPT:
bankQuestions.options: ["Fannie Mae","Freddie Mac","Ginnie Mae","HUD"]
bankQuestions.explanation: HUD is a federal agency, not a loan purchaser. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.10)

bankQuestions.questionText: A borrower with little cash but strong income may benefit MOST from:
bankQuestions.options: ["Conventional loan","Jumbo loan","FHA loan","Balloon mortgage"]
bankQuestions.explanation: FHA allows low down payments and more flexible qualifying ratios. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The margin in an ARM is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Adjustable","The lender's fixed markup added to the index","The interest rate cap","The loan amount"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Margin stays constant throughout the loan. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which ratio is used by conventional lenders to qualify borrowers?
bankQuestions.options: ["41% total ratio","50% front-end ratio","28% front-end / 36% back-end","20% DTI"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Conventional loans use 28/36 qualification guidelines. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which mortgage type has interest-only payments for a period?
bankQuestions.options: ["Fully amortized","Partially amortized","Reverse mortgage","Straight-term mortgage"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Interest-only loans require full principal repayment at maturity. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.8)

bankQuestions.questionText: A buyer receives a 5% interest rate on a $400,000 loan. What is the first month's interest?
bankQuestions.explanation: Annual interest = 400,000 x 0.05 = 20,000. Monthly = 20,000 / 12 = 1,666.67. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.9)

bankQuestions.questionText: The purpose of the secondary mortgage market is to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Provide home warranties","Enforce delinquency","Buy loans from lenders to create liquidity","Set property values"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Liquidity allows lenders to issue more loans. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.10)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which act requires lenders to disclose APR to borrowers?
bankQuestions.options: ["RESPA","ECOA","TILA (Truth in Lending Act)","SAFE Act"]
bankQuestions.explanation: TILA ensures borrowers understand the true cost of credit. (Unit 18 - Subunit 18.11)

bankQuestions.questionText: The closing process is primarily coordinated by:
bankQuestions.options: ["Buyer","Seller","Real estate broker","Closing agent (title company or attorney)"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The closing agent prepares documents, prorations, and ensures proper transfer of title. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The closing disclosure (CD) must be received by the borrower at least:
bankQuestions.options: ["1 day before closing","3 business days before closing","7 days before closing","At closing"]
bankQuestions.explanation: TRID requires a 3-day review period. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The purchase price on the closing disclosure is a:
bankQuestions.options: ["Debit to buyer","Debit to seller","Credit to seller","Debit to buyer and credit to seller"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Buyer pays it; seller receives it. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Prepaid rent collected by the seller is handled as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Debit buyer","Debit seller","Debit seller, credit buyer","Credit seller only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The buyer gets the portion of rent for days after closing. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Recording a deed:
bankQuestions.options: ["Is required for validity","Creates title","Provides constructive notice","Guarantees ownership"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Recording protects the buyer by notifying the public. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The lender's title insurance policy:
bankQuestions.options: ["Is optional","Protects the lender for the loan amount","Must be renewed yearly","Covers the owner forever"]
bankQuestions.explanation: It protects only the lender and decreases as the loan is paid down. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Documentary stamp tax on the deed is calculated based on:
bankQuestions.options: ["Loan amount","Appraised value","Square footage","Purchase price"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida rate: $0.70 per $100 of sale price (except Miami-Dade). (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The intangible tax on a mortgage is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Required by title insurance","Based on sale price","Paid by seller","0.002 x loan amount (2 mills)"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida intangible tax = 0.2% of the loan amount. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which party signs the deed?
bankQuestions.options: ["Buyer","Lender","Seller","Broker"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Only the grantor (seller) signs the deed. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which cost is typically paid by the buyer?
bankQuestions.options: ["Documentary stamp tax on deed","Seller's title policy","Intangible tax and note stamps on mortgage","Commission"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Financing-related taxes are buyer expenses. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which document transfers ownership from seller to buyer?
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgage","Note","Lease","Deed"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The deed conveys legal title. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which law requires the lender to provide the Closing Disclosure?
bankQuestions.options: ["ECOA","TRID (TILA-RESPA Integrated Disclosure)","SAFE Act","Dodd-Frank"]
bankQuestions.explanation: TRID combines TILA and RESPA requirements. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Property taxes not yet paid for the year are typically:
bankQuestions.options: ["Credit buyer, debit buyer","Credit buyer, debit seller","Credit seller only","Ignored at closing"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Seller owes taxes up to the day of closing. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A deed becomes effective when it is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Signed","Printed","Delivered by the seller and accepted by the buyer","Reviewed by the lender"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Delivery + acceptance = valid conveyance. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Title insurance protects the:
bankQuestions.options: ["Seller only","Real estate agent only","Buyer and lender from title defects","Appraiser"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Two policies: owner's and lender's. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Who usually pays for the documentary stamp tax on the deed?
bankQuestions.options: ["Buyer","Seller","Broker","Lender"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida custom: seller pays deed stamps, buyer pays note stamps/intangible tax. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Documentary stamp tax on the promissory note is based on:
bankQuestions.options: ["Property value","Loan amount","Commission","Survey cost"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Note stamps apply to financing, not the sale price. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A survey is typically required to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Evaluate insurance","Check market value","Verify property boundaries and encroachments","Estimate taxes"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Lenders require surveys to protect against boundary/title issues. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A closing statement shows:
bankQuestions.options: ["Only buyer credits","Only seller debits","All prorations only","All debits and credits for both parties"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Complete financial accounting for the transaction. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: The purpose of the loan estimate (LE) is to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Act as final closing costs","Replace the contract","Provide deed information","Explain estimated loan terms and costs early in the process"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The LE must be provided within 3 business days of application. (Unit 19 - Subunit 19.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A single agent owes which duties to the principal?
bankQuestions.options: ["Dealing honestly only","Limited disclosure","Fiduciary duties including loyalty, obedience, confidentiality, and full disclosure","No duties beyond transaction completion"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Single agents owe full fiduciary duties to their principal. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: What disclosure form must be given before showing property or entering into a representation agreement?
bankQuestions.options: ["Listing contract","Purchase contract","Brokerage relationship disclosure","HUD-1 form"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Disclosure is required at the first substantive contact. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Dual agency is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Required in Florida","Illegal in Florida residential transactions","Allowed only if both parties consent in writing","Allowed without consent"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida prohibits dual agency in residential transactions. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A single agent representing the seller may tell the buyer:
bankQuestions.options: ["The seller's bottom price","The seller's motivation to sell","Known property defects","Private financial information"]
bankQuestions.explanation: All parties must be told about known material defects. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker must retain transaction records for:
bankQuestions.options: ["3 years","5 years","7 years","2 years"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Brokers must keep records for 5 years from the transaction date. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: A buyer's agent bringing an offer to the listing agent works:
bankQuestions.options: ["As a subagent of the seller","As an agent of the buyer","For the MLS","For both parties equally"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Buyer's agents represent only the buyer's interests. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A seller discloses to their single agent that they are divorcing. What should the agent do?
bankQuestions.options: ["Tell the buyer for transparency","Keep this confidential unless legally required","Share only with the buyer's agent","Report to FREC"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Confidentiality is a fiduciary duty of single agents. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A transaction broker must give all parties:
bankQuestions.options: ["Loyalty","Full confidentiality","Honest and fair dealing, accounting, and skill, care, and diligence","Obedience"]
bankQuestions.explanation: These are the core duties owed under transaction brokerage. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The principal in a real estate relationship is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Always the broker","The party being represented","Always the seller","Always the buyer"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The principal is the party to whom duties are owed. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A licensee's fiduciary duties include all EXCEPT:
bankQuestions.options: ["Loyalty","Confidentiality","Accounting","Price negotiation for the other party"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Fiduciary duties protect the principal, not the other party. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A transaction broker owes which duty to all parties?
bankQuestions.options: ["Loyalty","Full confidentiality","Limited representation with honest and fair dealing","Obedience"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Transaction brokers provide limited representation but owe honesty to all parties. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The default brokerage relationship in Florida (if no other is chosen) is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Single agent","No brokerage relationship","Transaction broker","Dual agent"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Transaction brokerage is the presumed relationship if none is established in writing. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A transaction broker may not disclose:
bankQuestions.options: ["Material property defects","Latent defects","A party's motivation or willingness to negotiate price","Seller's disclosure form"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Transaction brokers have limited confidentiality obligations. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A designated sales associate arrangement is permitted in:
bankQuestions.options: ["All residential transactions","Single-family homes","Nonresidential transactions where both parties meet asset requirements","Rental transactions only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Both parties must have assets of $1 million or more. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: A seller hires a listing agent. The agent represents:
bankQuestions.options: ["Only the buyer","Both buyer and seller","Only the seller","Neither party"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The listing agent works for and represents the seller. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: In which situation is no brokerage relationship appropriate?
bankQuestions.options: ["When showing an in-house listing to a prospect","When helping a customer view listings without representation","When representing a buyer exclusively","When listing property exclusively"]
bankQuestions.explanation: No brokerage applies when simply providing information without representation. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Consent to transition allows:
bankQuestions.options: ["A transaction broker to become a single agent","A single agent to transition to transaction broker","A buyer's agent to represent the seller","Dual agency in residential sales"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Written consent is required before changing representation levels. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A no brokerage relationship means:
bankQuestions.options: ["The broker represents both parties","The broker provides limited services without fiduciary duties","The broker acts solely as a customer assistant","No real estate license is needed"]
bankQuestions.explanation: No brokerage = no fiduciary duties, just dealing honestly. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A licensee acting as a single agent must disclose:
bankQuestions.options: ["Nothing unless asked","Known facts that affect property value","Only defects visible during inspection","Only what the seller authorizes"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Single agents must fully disclose material facts. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: What happens if a broker fails to disclose the type of representation?
bankQuestions.options: ["The transaction is void","The broker may be disciplined","There is no penalty","The transaction broker status is assumed automatically"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Failure to disclose is a violation subject to discipline. (Unit 4 - Subunit 4.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A real estate sale contract becomes binding when:
bankQuestions.options: ["Buyer signs it","Seller signs it","Broker delivers it","The offer is accepted and acceptance is communicated to the offeror"]
bankQuestions.explanation: A contract is formed only when acceptance is communicated back to the party who made the offer. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A contract in which only one party is obligated to perform is a:
bankQuestions.options: ["Bilateral contract","Valid contract","Void contract","Unilateral contract"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Unilateral contracts involve a promise in exchange for an act. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Earnest money is considered:
bankQuestions.options: ["Consideration","Required by law","A down payment","Good-faith deposit"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Deposits demonstrate the buyer's good faith but are not required by law. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which contract clause allows the buyer to cancel if financing cannot be secured?
bankQuestions.options: ["Arbitration clause","Habendum clause","Financing contingency","Due-on-sale clause"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Financing contingencies protect buyers if loans cannot be obtained. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which type of contract is enforceable in court?
bankQuestions.options: ["Oral real estate sale contract","Oral listing","Written real estate sale contract","Promise to make a gift"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Statute of Frauds requires real estate sale contracts to be in writing to be enforceable. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A contract signed by a minor is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Valid","Voidable","Void","Enforceable only by the seller"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Minors lack legal capacity, making the contract voidable by the minor. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A contract that has not yet been fully performed is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Executed","Void","Executory","Unenforceable"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Executory = terms remain to be completed by one or both parties. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: When both parties agree to cancel a contract and return to their original positions, it is called:
bankQuestions.options: ["Breach","Novation","Rescission","Assignment"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Rescission = mutual cancellation. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Assigning a contract means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Rewriting the contract","Cancelling the contract","Terminating the buyer","Transferring rights and obligations to another party"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Assignments transfer contractual rights to a new party unless prohibited. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Specific performance is a remedy that:
bankQuestions.options: ["Awards money only","Cancels the contract","Requires the breaching party to perform as originally agreed","Is prohibited in Florida"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Courts may compel performance in real estate because each parcel is unique. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A contract that is missing an essential element is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Valid","Voidable","Void","Executory"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Missing elements such as consideration or lawful purpose render the contract void. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which listing guarantees the broker a commission no matter who finds the buyer?
bankQuestions.options: ["Open listing","Net listing","Exclusive agency","Exclusive-right-of-sale"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This listing type ensures broker compensation even if the owner finds the buyer. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which contract may be terminated by performance, breach, or impossibility?
bankQuestions.options: ["Listing only","Lease agreement only","Sale contract only","All real estate contracts"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Contract termination rules apply to all types of contracts. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which contract is an example of a unilateral contract?
bankQuestions.options: ["Listing agreement","Option contract","Sale contract","Lease agreement"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Only the seller is boundthe buyer has the right, but not the obligation, to buy. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: If a buyer breaches a contract, the seller may keep the earnest money as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Rescission","Liquidated damages","Punitive damages","Specific performance"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Liquidated damages are predetermined amounts agreed upon in case of breach. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A seller financing arrangement where the seller retains legal title is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Lease-option","Mortgage","Contract for deed (land contract)","Option contract"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Seller keeps title until buyer satisfies the payment terms. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: What type of listing allows the seller to list with multiple brokers?
bankQuestions.options: ["Exclusive-right-of-sale","Exclusive-agency","Open listing","Net listing"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Open listings are non-exclusive; only the broker who produces the buyer earns commission. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A net listing is one in which:
bankQuestions.options: ["Broker receives a salary","Seller earns a fixed amount regardless of price","Broker keeps any amount above the seller's net price","Broker receives a flat fee"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Net listings are legal in Florida but discouraged due to ethical concerns. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Time is of the essence means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Deadlines may be extended","Deadlines are strict and must be met","Only weekends count","Broker controls timeline"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This clause makes contract dates legally critical. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A contract under seal is considered:
bankQuestions.options: ["Invalid","Formal contract","Unenforceable","Executed"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Formal contracts follow statutory format and may use seals. (Unit 10 - Subunit 10.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Most real estate loans are:
bankQuestions.options: ["Unsecured","Personal loans","Secured by a mortgage or deed of trust","Government-issued"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Real estate loans are secured by the property through a mortgage (Florida uses mortgages, not deeds of trust). (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The promissory note creates:
bankQuestions.options: ["A lien on the property","The borrower's personal obligation to repay","An escrow account","Insurance coverage"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The note is the debt instrument; the mortgage secures the debt. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A mortgage lien is released by recording a:
bankQuestions.options: ["New mortgage","Quitclaim deed","Satisfaction of mortgage","Warranty deed"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The satisfaction releases the lien once the loan is paid off. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The alienation (due-on-sale) clause requires:
bankQuestions.options: ["Payment in installments","Prepayment penalty","Full payment when the property is sold","Assumption without qualification"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This clause prevents unauthorized loan assumptions. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A loan where the borrower pays down both principal and interest over time is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Interest-only loan","Balloon loan","Amortized loan","Adjustable loan"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Amortization spreads payments evenly over the term. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: An adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) has:
bankQuestions.options: ["A fixed interest rate for life","An interest rate that varies based on an index","No closing costs","No monthly payments"]
bankQuestions.explanation: ARM rates are tied to indices like LIBOR or SOFR. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A mortgage that allows the borrower to make smaller payments in early years and larger ones later is a:
bankQuestions.options: ["Growing-equity mortgage","Reverse mortgage","Graduated-payment mortgage (GPM)","ARM"]
bankQuestions.explanation: GPM payments start low and increase annually. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The loan-to-value (LTV) ratio is calculated by:
bankQuestions.options: ["Loan  interest","Appraised value  loan","Loan amount  lesser of purchase price or appraised value","Down payment  price"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Lenders base LTV on the lower of price or appraisal. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: One discount point increases the lender's yield by approximately:
bankQuestions.explanation: Each point typically raises the lender's yield by 1/8%. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: The secondary mortgage market:
bankQuestions.options: ["Makes direct loans to borrowers","Buys existing loans from primary lenders","Insures mortgages","Guarantees loans"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The secondary market provides liquidity by purchasing loans. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: The borrower in a mortgage relationship is called the:
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgagee","Trustor","Mortgagor","Beneficiary"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The mortgagor borrows; the mortgagee lends. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A mortgage creates:
bankQuestions.options: ["A personal debt","An unsecured loan","A lien on the property","Title transfer"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The mortgage gives the lender a security interest in the property. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The acceleration clause allows the lender to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Reduce payments","Increase the loan term","Demand full payment upon default","Forgive the debt"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Acceleration makes the entire balance due after default. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A defeasance clause:
bankQuestions.options: ["Prevents foreclosure","Allows the borrower to retain title after satisfaction","Increases interest","Limits payments"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The mortgage is defeated (cancelled) upon full payment. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A balloon mortgage:
bankQuestions.options: ["Has equal monthly payments","Has a large final payment","Reduces principal faster than standard","Has no maturity date"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Balloon payments come due at the end of a short term. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The margin in an ARM is:
bankQuestions.options: ["The same as the index","A variable amount","A fixed percentage added to the index","Determined by the borrower"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The margin is constant throughout the loan and determines the lender's profit. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Negative amortization happens when:
bankQuestions.options: ["Extra payments are made","Monthly payments are less than the interest due","ARM caps adjust downward","Loan is fully amortized"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Unpaid interest is added to the loan principal. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Discount points are used to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Increase the loan term","Reduce closing costs","Increase the lender's upfront yield and reduce the borrower's interest rate","Pay off the principal early"]
bankQuestions.explanation: One point = 1% of loan amount; buying points lowers the interest rate. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: The purpose of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy is to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Underwrite loans","Fund FHA","Regulate appraisers","Control the availability and cost of credit"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The Fed influences interest rates and credit supply through monetary tools. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac operate in the:
bankQuestions.options: ["Primary market","Secondary market","Government guarantee market","Insurance market"]
bankQuestions.explanation: These GSEs purchase conforming loans from lenders. (Unit 11 - Subunit 11.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: Market value is best defined as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Assessed value for tax purposes","Insurance replacement cost","Price the seller demands","Most probable price a property should bring in an open, competitive market"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Market value assumes a knowledgeable buyer and seller, reasonable exposure time, and no undue pressure. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The value added by combining adjacent parcels into a single property is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Regression","Progression","Plottage","Assemblage"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Assemblage = combining parcels; plottage = the increase in value resulting from it. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which cost method estimates cost by breaking the structure into components?
bankQuestions.options: ["Comparative unit method","Square-foot method","Quantity-survey method","Unit-in-place method"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Quantity survey involves pricing each material and labor component individually. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The principle that a buyer will not pay more for a property than the cost of acquiring a similar substitute is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Contribution","Balance","Substitution","Conformity"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Substitution underlies the sales comparison approach and appraisal logic. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The appraisal approach most appropriate for income-producing property is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Cost approach","Sales comparison approach","Income capitalization approach","Gross rent multiplier"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Income approach values property based on net operating income and investor return. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Depreciation from ordinary wear and tear is:
bankQuestions.options: ["External obsolescence","Functional obsolescence","Physical deterioration","Economic obsolescence"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Physical deterioration includes aging, weathering, and deferred maintenance. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A property located next to a noisy airport suffers from:
bankQuestions.options: ["Functional obsolescence","Physical deterioration","External (economic) obsolescence","Normal depreciation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: External obsolescence is caused by negative outside influences beyond the property line. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A four-bedroom house with only one bathroom suffers from:
bankQuestions.options: ["Physical deterioration","Economic obsolescence","Functional obsolescence","Accrued depreciation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Functional obsolescence relates to design flaws or outdated features. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The formula for the income capitalization approach is:
bankQuestions.options: ["GRM x Rent = Value","NOI + Cap Rate = Value","Value = Net Operating Income / Capitalization Rate","Cap Rate x Market Value = NOI"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Capitalization converts annual income into value. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Reproduction cost is the cost to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Remodel the property","Replace the building with modern materials","Demolish and rebuild","Build an exact duplicate using the same materials and design"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Reproduction = exact copy; replacement = similar utility with modern methods. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The principle stating that value is created and maintained when all elements are in proper proportion is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Substitution","Anticipation","Balance","Competition"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Balance occurs when land, labor, capital, and management are properly combined. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The highest and best use of a property must be:
bankQuestions.options: ["The most profitable use only","Any use allowed by current zoning","Legally permissible, physically possible, financially feasible, and maximally productive","The use chosen by the appraiser"]
bankQuestions.explanation: All four criteria must be met for highest and best use. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Progression means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Overimprovement increases value","A lower-valued property benefits from being near higher-valued homes","A luxury home loses value near modest homes","Commercial zoning increases value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Property values 'progress' upward when surrounded by better properties. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The cost-depreciation approach is most suitable for:
bankQuestions.options: ["Condo units","Office parks","Special-purpose properties (schools, churches, government buildings)","Warehouses"]
bankQuestions.explanation: When comparable sales or income data are lacking, the cost method is preferred. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Gross Rent Multiplier (GRM) is typically used for:
bankQuestions.options: ["Warehouses","Office buildings","Residential 1-4 unit rental properties","Retail centers"]
bankQuestions.explanation: GRM applies to small residential rentals with simpler income patterns. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Replacement cost is the cost to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Build an exact replica","Construct with identical materials","Build a similar structure with equivalent utility using today's materials","Restore the property"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Replacement cost is more commonly used because materials may change over time. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The principle stating that value changes due to expected future benefits is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Contribution","Anticipation","Conformity","Balance"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Common in income propertyfuture income drives current value. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A swimming pool in a modest neighborhood is an example of:
bankQuestions.options: ["Balance","Regression","Overimprovement","Contribution"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Overimprovements exceed what the market will support. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Regression means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Homes increase in value near better homes","Higher-valued homes lose value when surrounded by lower-valued homes","Appraisers reduce depreciation","Tax assessments increase"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The opposite of progression; values move downward. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A comparable property recently sold for $500,000. It is superior to the subject property by $20,000. The adjusted sale price is:
bankQuestions.explanation: Superior comps are adjusted downward to match the subject property. (Unit 12 - Subunit 12.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A residential sale is legally defined in Florida as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Any sale under $500,000","Multifamily over 10 units","Commercial property","Improved property of four or fewer units"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida law defines residential as 4 or fewer units, vacant land zoned for 1-4 units, or agricultural property with 10 or fewer acres. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A transaction broker provides:
bankQuestions.options: ["Fiduciary duties","No representation","Limited representation to both parties","Full loyalty to the buyer"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Transaction brokers facilitate the deal without fiduciary duties. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A no-brokerage relationship requires disclosure when:
bankQuestions.options: ["Broker represents buyer","Broker represents seller","Broker is assisting a customer without representation","Broker is hired as a fiduciary"]
bankQuestions.explanation: No-brokerage disclosure clarifies the broker represents neither party. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Designated sales associates are permitted in:
bankQuestions.options: ["Residential transactions only","4 units or fewer only","Non-residential transactions where both parties have $1 million+ in assets","Federally related transactions"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Only available in non-residential transactions with financially qualified parties. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A commercial property is best defined as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Vacant land","Residential property","Income-producing or used for business purposes","Agricultural land"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Commercial real estate includes offices, retail, multifamily over 4 units, and industrial. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which relationship is prohibited in residential sales?
bankQuestions.options: ["Transaction broker","No brokerage","Single agent","Dual agency"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Dual agency is illegal in Floridait violates loyalty and confidentiality duties. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which type of property management task requires a real estate license?
bankQuestions.options: ["Leasing","Collecting rent","Handling deposits","Negotiating leases for others for compensation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Negotiating terms is an activity that requires licensure. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker who represents a buyer as a single agent owes which duty?
bankQuestions.options: ["Limited confidentiality","Neutrality","Loyalty to both parties","Loyalty exclusively to the buyer"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Single agents owe fiduciary duties only to their principal. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: If a single agent wants to transition to a transaction broker, they must obtain:
bankQuestions.options: ["Verbal permission","No permission","Written 'Consent to Transition' signed by the principal","Broker approval only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Without this form, the broker may not change representation type. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: In which relationship does the broker have NO duty of confidentiality?
bankQuestions.options: ["Single agent","Transaction broker","No brokerage relationship","Dual agent"]
bankQuestions.explanation: No brokerage = no confidentiality, loyalty, or obedience duties. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker who acts as a single agent owes the principal which duty?
bankQuestions.options: ["Limited confidentiality","Dealing honestly only","Fiduciary duties (loyalty, obedience, confidentiality, full disclosure)","Limited representation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Single agency = highest duties of loyalty and confidentiality. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which type of brokerage relationship must be in writing?
bankQuestions.options: ["No brokerage","Single agency","Transaction broker","Universal agency"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Single agency requires written disclosure. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The duty of limited confidentiality belongs to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Single agents","No-brokerage brokers","Transaction brokers","Subagents"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Transaction brokers may not disclose price, motivation, or terms unless authorized. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker working as a single agent for the seller may not:
bankQuestions.options: ["Present offers","Disclose known defects","Tell the buyer the seller's bottom price","Show the home"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Loyalty and confidentiality prohibit revealing the seller's motivation or minimum price. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Brokers handling agricultural property must understand that agricultural land is considered residential only if:
bankQuestions.options: ["It has barns","It is leased","It is 10 acres or less","It is fenced"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This fits Florida's definition of residential property. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker must retain brokerage relationship forms for:
bankQuestions.options: ["2 years","3 years","1 year","5 years"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida law requires retaining all relationship disclosures for 5 years, even if the transaction fails. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A rental agent without a real estate license may:
bankQuestions.options: ["Negotiate rent","Sign a lease for the landlord","Show rental property and collect deposits, if paid hourly","Receive commissions"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Unlicensed individuals may perform ministerial tasks but cannot be paid commission. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: In residential transactions, designated sales associates are:
bankQuestions.options: ["Mandatory","Optional","Prohibited","Required for dual agency"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Designated associates are allowed only in non-residential deals. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker's relationship disclosure must be given:
bankQuestions.options: ["At closing","After showing the property","Before showing property or entering a listing agreement","After entering contract"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Disclosure must occur at the first substantive contact. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker assisting a landlord and tenant without representing either party is acting as a:
bankQuestions.options: ["Single agent","Transaction broker","Dual agent","No-brokerage relationship broker"]
bankQuestions.explanation: In this role, the broker deals honestly and handles paperwork but owes no representation. (Unit 13 - Subunit 13.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Market value is best defined as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Assessed value for tax purposes","Insurance replacement cost","Seller's asking price","Most probable price under typical market conditions"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Market value assumes willing parties with no undue pressure. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Highest and best use analysis considers:
bankQuestions.options: ["Only the seller's preference","Only zoning","Legality, physical possibility, financial feasibility, and maximum productivity","Only current use"]
bankQuestions.explanation: All four factors must be evaluated. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Conformity as an appraisal principle means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Nonconforming uses add value","Properties should match neighborhood standards for maximum value","Zoning is ignored","All homes must be identical"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Conformity = homogeneity within a neighborhood. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: The sales comparison approach uses:
bankQuestions.options: ["Depreciation tables","Income data","Replacement cost","Recent comparable sales"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Comps are adjusted to match the subject property. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: If a comparable property is inferior, the appraiser should:
bankQuestions.options: ["Add value","Subtract value","Average all comps","Ignore the comp"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Inferior comp = adjust upward. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: To estimate reproduction cost, appraisers use:
bankQuestions.options: ["Capitalization","GRM","Market extraction","Square-foot, unit-in-place, or quantity-survey methods"]
bankQuestions.explanation: These methods measure cost to build an exact replica. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Functional obsolescence is caused by:
bankQuestions.options: ["High taxes","Location decline","Design or layout problems","Weather"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Example: 5-bedroom home with one bathroom. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which formula determines value using the income approach?
bankQuestions.options: ["Value = GRM x rent","Price = cost - depreciation","Value = NOI / capitalization rate","NOI = cap rate x value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Income approach is used for income-producing property. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: Gross Rent Multiplier (GRM) applies to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Large commercial properties","Hotels","1-4 unit residential investment property","Factories"]
bankQuestions.explanation: GRM uses monthly rent = simple valuation tool. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: Reconciliation is the process of:
bankQuestions.options: ["Averaging the three approaches","Determining depreciation","Adjusting comparables","Weighting each value approach based on reliability"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The appraiser decides which approach deserves more weight. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: The principle of substitution states that:
bankQuestions.options: ["A buyer will pay more for unique features","A buyer will not pay more than the cost of a comparable substitute","Sellers set prices","Location always determines value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Substitution underlies all three appraisal approaches. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The principle of contribution means:
bankQuestions.options: ["All improvements add equal value","Value added by an improvement is measured by its impact on overall value","Overimprovement always pays","Contribution is not relevant to appraisal"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Improvements contribute value only if the market recognizes them. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which appraisal principle describes value created by combining adjacent parcels?
bankQuestions.options: ["Regression","Progression","Anticipation","Assemblage (leading to plottage value)"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Multiple parcels combined = value increases (plottage). (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: If a comparable property is superior, the appraiser should:
bankQuestions.options: ["Add value","Make no adjustment","Subtract value","Ignore the comp"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Superior comp = subtract to estimate what subject would sell for. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The cost approach is MOST appropriate for:
bankQuestions.options: ["Condominiums","Vacant land","Rental homes","Special-purpose properties (schools, churches, government buildings)"]
bankQuestions.explanation: These properties have few or no comparable sales. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Physical deterioration refers to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Outdated design","External economic forces","Functional problems","Wear and tear from age or use"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Example: peeling paint, cracked foundation. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: External obsolescence results from:
bankQuestions.options: ["Poor maintenance","Bad plumbing","Old electrical wiring","Negative outside influences (e.g., factory nearby)"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Caused by location or environment, and always incurable. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: A property's NOI is $45,000, and the market cap rate is 9%. Estimated value?
Using a GRM of 160 and monthly rent of $2,000, value is:
bankQuestions.explanation: Value = Rent x GRM = 2,000 x 160 = 320,000. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: The final step in the appraisal process is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Adjusting comps","Determining cost","Inspecting the property","Reporting the value conclusion"]
bankQuestions.explanation: After reconciliation, the appraiser presents the conclusion in a formal report. (Unit 17 - Subunit 17.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: Real estate investors are primarily concerned with:
bankQuestions.options: ["Property taxes","Mortgage points","Return on investment (ROI)","Seller motivation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Investors evaluate properties based on expected profit relative to investment cost. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which investment provides the greatest leverage?
bankQuestions.options: ["Paying cash","10% down payment","20% down payment","5% down payment"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Leverage increases when less cash is used to control a larger asset. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The formula for net operating income (NOI) is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Gross income - debt service","Effective gross income - operating expenses","Rent x GRM","Capitalization rate x value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: NOI excludes debt service and depreciation. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A higher cap rate generally means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Lower risk","Lower return","Higher risk but higher return","Lower NOI"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Cap rate and risk move together. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Business opportunity brokerage involves the sale of:
bankQuestions.options: ["Residential property","Industrial land","An ongoing business, including assets and goodwill","Mortgages"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Business brokerage transfers business assets, not necessarily real estate. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Working capital refers to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Long-term debt","Equipment value","Current assets minus current liabilities","Total equity"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Working capital measures liquidity and short-term financial health. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Depreciation for tax purposes applies to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Land only","Improvements and some business assets","Land and buildings","Personal residences"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Land cannot be depreciated, but buildings and equipment can. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A business brokerage requires understanding of:
bankQuestions.options: ["CMA preparation","Architectural design","Financial statements and business valuation methods","Construction costs"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Brokers must analyze profit/loss statements and balance sheets. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A positive cash flow occurs when:
bankQuestions.options: ["NOI < expenses","Depreciation increases","Revenue exceeds all operating expenses and debt service","Cap rate increases"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Positive cash flow is essential for long-term investment stability. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which investment factor is not directly controlled by the investor?
bankQuestions.options: ["Operating expenses","Purchase price","Financing terms","Market conditions"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Investors respond to, but cannot control, economic forces. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A tax shelter refers to:
bankQuestions.options: ["A tax refund","Hidden income","Legal reduction of taxable income through depreciation and deductions","Government subsidies"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Depreciation, interest, and expenses reduce taxable income for investors. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Financial leverage allows an investor to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Increase taxes","Avoid interest payments","Reduce risk","Control property with less cash"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Leverage magnifies gains (and potential losses). (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The capitalization rate (cap rate) is used to:
