bankQuestions.options: ["Determine taxes","Estimate investment property value","Set insurance rates","Determine zoning"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Value = NOI / cap rate. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which metric measures cash return on actual invested dollars?
bankQuestions.options: ["NOI","Cap rate","GRM","Cash-on-cash return"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Cash-on-cash = cash flow / cash invested. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A balance sheet shows:
bankQuestions.options: ["Cash flow","Insurance costs","Assets, liabilities, and equity at a specific moment","Depreciation only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Unlike income statements, balance sheets show financial position at a point in time. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Goodwill in a business sale refers to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Inventory","Equipment","Tangible assets","Intangible value such as reputation and customer loyalty"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Goodwill contributes to business value beyond physical assets. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which property is typically the least risky investment?
bankQuestions.options: ["Vacant land","Rental homes in stable neighborhoods","Hotels","Office towers"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Single-family rentals tend to have stable demand and lower volatility. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Equity in an investment property equals:
bankQuestions.options: ["Income - expenses","NOI - cap rate","Market value - loan balance","Down payment only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Equity increases as property value rises or loan balance decreases. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Liquidity refers to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Leverage","Tax shelter","Ease of converting an asset to cash","NOI growth"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Real estate has low liquidity because selling takes time. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A business broker's role includes:
bankQuestions.options: ["Issuing corporate stock","Performing audits","Analyzing business financials and facilitating the sale of business assets","Conducting structural inspections"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Business brokers transfer ownership of businesses, including tangible and intangible assets. (Unit 15 - Subunit 15.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Property taxes in Florida are based on:
bankQuestions.options: ["Market value only","Sale price","Mortgage balance","Assessed value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The county property appraiser determines assessed value, which is used to calculate taxes. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which office is responsible for establishing the assessed value of real property?
bankQuestions.options: ["County tax collector","Clerk of courts","Department of Revenue","County property appraiser"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The property appraiser assesses all real property annually. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The standard Florida homestead tax exemption is:
bankQuestions.explanation: The exemption provides up to $50,000 off the assessed value, depending on millage categories. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The SOH cap applies to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Rental property","Commercial property","Vacant land","Homesteaded property only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Only Florida homestead properties qualify for SOH protection. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: One mill equals:
bankQuestions.options: ["$10 per $1,000","$100 per $100,000","$1 per $1,000 of taxable value","10% of assessed value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: 1 mill = 0.001. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A Florida homeowner may claim the homestead exemption if the property is:
bankQuestions.options: ["A rental","A vacation home","Owned by a corporation","Their primary residence"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Homestead applies only to an owner's permanent primary residence. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: What is the purpose of the Save Our Homes (SOH) cap?
bankQuestions.options: ["Limit mortgage rates","Limit closing costs","Reduce insurance premiums","Limit annual increases in assessed value to 3%"]
bankQuestions.explanation: SOH caps assessed value increases to 3% or CPI, whichever is lower. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Property taxes are calculated by:
bankQuestions.options: ["Market value x assessed value","Millage rate / taxable value","Taxable value x millage rate","Millage / assessed value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Taxable value = assessed value - exemptions. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Special assessments are used to pay for:
bankQuestions.options: ["Regular public services","Appraisals","Specific local improvements such as sidewalks or street lighting","Zoning changes"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Special assessments fund improvements that benefit specific properties. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Federal income tax deductions for homeowners include:
bankQuestions.options: ["HOA dues","Home repairs","Mortgage interest and property taxes","Closing costs"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Interest on home mortgages and property taxes ARE deductible; repairs are not. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: To qualify for capital gains exclusion, the homeowner must have lived in the property for:
bankQuestions.options: ["6 months","1 year","2 of the last 5 years","10 consecutive years"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Must meet 2-year ownership AND 2-year occupancy requirements. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: A tax exemption differs from a tax deduction because it:
bankQuestions.options: ["Reduces income tax only","Reduces taxable value directly","Reduces insurance costs","Affects millage rates"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Exemptions reduce taxable value, lowering property taxes. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Special assessments are usually paid:
bankQuestions.options: ["Once at closing","In two equal installments","Monthly","Weekly"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Special assessments typically have two annual payments. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Equitable title transfers to the buyer when:
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgage is paid off","Buyer gets keys","Contract for sale is executed","Deed is recorded"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Equitable title gives the buyer the right to obtain full ownership at closing. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A special assessment for paving a road is usually allocated based on:
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgage balance","Square footage","Credit score","Front footage"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Front foot method is commonly used for improvements like roads and sidewalks. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Capital gains tax on the sale of a principal residence may be excluded up to:
bankQuestions.options: ["$100,000 single / $200,000 married","$150,000 single / $250,000 married","$250,000 single / $500,000 married","Unlimited"]
bankQuestions.explanation: IRS allows exclusion if ownership & use tests are met. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which property is exempt from property taxes?
bankQuestions.options: ["Apartment buildings","Retail centers","Churches and nonprofit organizations","Agricultural land"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Nonprofit, religious, and charitable organizations receive tax exemptions. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Taxable value is calculated as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Market value minus SOH cap","Assessed value x millage","Assessed value - exemptions","Just value + exemptions"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Taxable value is the number used for the tax bill. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which tax is NOT deductible for homeowners?
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgage interest","Property taxes","Special assessments for improvements","Discount points"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Improvement-based assessments increase property value and are NOT deductible. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which factor MOST affects assessed value?
bankQuestions.options: ["Insurance cost","Landscaping","Property appraiser's annual valuation of market trends","HOA rules"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The county appraiser sets assessed values based on market data and statutory requirements. (Unit 14 - Subunit 14.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Investors use leverage primarily to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Increase closing costs","Reduce loan payments","Avoid taxes","Control a large asset with a small amount of cash"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Leverage increases return potential because the investor uses borrowed funds. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Positive leverage occurs when:
bankQuestions.options: ["Loan interest rate is higher than investment yield","Investment return exceeds cost of borrowed funds","Loan term is under 15 years","LTV exceeds 95%"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Positive leverage increases overall return. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Risk of loss due to changes in the business cycle is known as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Environmental risk","Physical risk","Default risk","Economic risk"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Economic cycles impact vacancy rates, rents, and values. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which investment offers the lowest risk?
bankQuestions.options: ["Raw land","Development projects","Office buildings","Residential rental property"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Housing demand is stable; raw land and development carry higher risk. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A business opportunity includes:
bankQuestions.options: ["Only real property","Only personal property","Both tangible and intangible assets","Real property but not goodwill"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Business brokerage involves goodwill, licenses, equipment, inventory, leases, etc. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which is considered a real estate investment disadvantage?
bankQuestions.options: ["Appreciation","Tax benefits","Illiquidity","Income production"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Real estate cannot be quickly converted to cash. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Cash flow is defined as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Gross income minus taxes","Net income minus depreciation","NOI minus debt service","Cap rate divided by value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Cash flow = money left after paying the mortgage. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Equity is calculated as:
bankQuestions.options: ["NOI + debt","Loan amount / LTV","Property value x cap rate","Value minus mortgage balance"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Equity = owner's share of the property value. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Blue Sky Laws regulate:
bankQuestions.options: ["Mortgages","Property taxes","Insurance","The sale of securities and investment contracts"]
bankQuestions.explanation: These protect investors from fraudulent investment schemes. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The value of a business that includes tangible and intangible assets is called:
bankQuestions.options: ["Book value","Salvage value","Land residual value","Going-concern value"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Going-concern value includes goodwill, reputation, and income stream. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which financial document summarizes assets, liabilities, and equity?
bankQuestions.options: ["Income statement","Balance sheet","Capitalization report","Operating ledger"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Balance sheets show a business's financial position at a point in time. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which valuation method is common in business brokerage?
bankQuestions.options: ["Sales comparison approach only","Asset valuation, income capitalization, and market methods","Cost approach only","Blue Sky valuation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Businesses require multiple valuation methods unlike real estate alone. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker analyzing business financials focuses MOST on:
bankQuestions.options: ["Square footage","Cash flow and profitability trends","Return of capital","Cap rate"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Profitability analysis is central to business valuation. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Securities laws apply to real estate syndications because:
bankQuestions.options: ["They involve land only","Investors pool money expecting profits from others' efforts","The SEC regulates all real estate","Syndications avoid taxes"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The Howey Test defines investment contracts subject to SEC rules. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: A business broker must understand the concept of going concern, which means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Only goodwill","Only inventory","Market value minus depreciation","The business will continue operating after the sale"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Going concern includes the business's ability to generate income. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which financial document shows profits and losses over time?
bankQuestions.options: ["Balance sheet","Cash flow statement","Income statement","Equity Sheet"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The income statement measures performance over a period. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Net working capital is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Gross revenue minus expenses","Depreciation minus taxes","Current assets minus current liabilities","Equity minus debt"]
bankQuestions.explanation: It measures short-term financial health. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Goodwill refers to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Office equipment value","Inventory on hand","Real estate value","Intangible business value such as reputation or loyal customers"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Goodwill enhances the value of the business beyond tangible assets. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A syndication is:
bankQuestions.options: ["A single investor","A partnership between neighbors","A group investment vehicle pooling funds from multiple investors","A type of mortgage"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Syndications allow investors to participate in larger deals together. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: A real estate investment trust (REIT) is:
bankQuestions.options: ["A type of mortgage","A government program","A company that owns and manages income-producing real estate","A form of land trust"]
bankQuestions.explanation: REITs allow individuals to invest in large-scale real estate portfolios. (Unit 16 - Subunit 16.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which type of notice is achieved by recording a document in the public records?
bankQuestions.options: ["Actual notice","Inquiry notice","Personal notice","Constructive notice"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Recording provides the public with constructive notice of ownership or claims. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which clause in a deed states the type of estate being conveyed?
bankQuestions.options: ["Habendum clause","Granting clause","Consideration clause","Quitclaim clause"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The habendum clause defines ownership type: 'to have and to hold.' (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which deed offers the greatest protection to the grantee?
bankQuestions.options: ["Quitclaim","Special warranty","Bargain-and-sale","General warranty"]
bankQuestions.explanation: General warranty deeds guarantee title before and during the grantor's ownership. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which government right allows property to be taken for public use with just compensation?
bankQuestions.options: ["Police power","Escheat","Taxation","Eminent domain"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Eminent domain is the right; condemnation is the process. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which document proves ownership of real property?
bankQuestions.options: ["Title","Mortgage","Deed","Covenant"]
bankQuestions.explanation: A deed is the instrument used to convey legal title. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: An encumbrance is:
bankQuestions.options: ["A tax exemption","A deed restriction","A claim or liability that affects title","A condemnation action"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Encumbrances include liens, judgments, and easements. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The statute of frauds requires certain contracts to be:
bankQuestions.options: ["Recorded","Notarized","In writing to be enforceable","Signed by a broker"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Real estate sale contracts must be in writing per the statute of frauds. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A buyer who was a minor when signing a contract may:
bankQuestions.options: ["Not cancel","Sue for damages","Assign it freely","Void the contract because it is voidable"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Minors create voidable agreements due to lack of legal capacity. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A deed restriction is a:
bankQuestions.options: ["Zoning ordinance","Government limitation","Lien","Private limitation on property use"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Deed restrictions are imposed by developers or prior owners. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which is required for a valid real estate contract?
bankQuestions.options: ["Earnest money deposit","Witnesses","Notary","Meeting of the minds"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Offer + acceptance = mutual agreement (meeting of the minds). (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which essential element is required for a valid deed?
bankQuestions.options: ["Notary seal","Buyer's signature","Witness signature","Grantor's signature"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Only the grantor must sign a deed for it to be valid. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which deed provides no warranties and conveys only the grantor's interest?
bankQuestions.options: ["General warranty","Special warranty","Bargain-and-sale","Quitclaim deed"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Quitclaim deeds offer zero warrantiesoften used to clear title defects. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Escheat occurs when property transfers to the state because the owner:
bankQuestions.options: ["Loses a lawsuit","Forecloses","Fails to pay taxes","Dies intestate with no heirs"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Escheat prevents land from being ownerless. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Zoning and building codes are examples of:
bankQuestions.options: ["Eminent domain","Police power","Escheat","Taxation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Police power protects public health, safety, and welfare. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Title insurance protects against:
bankQuestions.options: ["Future zoning changes","Eminent domain actions","Property defects known to the buyer","Hidden title defects"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Title insurance covers undiscovered defects such as forged deeds or missing heirs. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: For a contract to be valid, it must include:
bankQuestions.options: ["Earnest money","Legal description","Witnesses","Consideration"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Valid contracts require offer, acceptance, consideration, legal purpose, and competent parties. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A contract that has been fully performed is known as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Executory","Null","Voidable","Executed"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Executed = all terms have been completed. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which lien is always a superior lien?
bankQuestions.options: ["Judgement lien","HOA lien","Mortgage lien","Property tax lien"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Property taxes take priority over all other liens. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which deed contains the covenant of quiet enjoyment?
bankQuestions.options: ["Quitclaim","General warranty","Special warranty","Disclaimer deed"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This covenant ensures the grantee will not be disturbed by superior title claims. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A buyer records their deed. This action provides:
bankQuestions.options: ["Warranty of title","Title insurance","Constructive notice to the public","Actual notice to the seller"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Recording protects the buyer by notifying third parties. (Unit 9 - Subunit 9.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A sales associate must be registered under:
bankQuestions.options: ["DBPR only","An employing broker","Any brokerage of their choice","NAR"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Sales associates must be registered with and supervised by a licensed broker. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Who may receive compensation directly from a buyer or seller?
bankQuestions.options: ["Sales associates","Broker associates","Only the broker","Any licensee"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Compensation flows through the broker. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker must deposit escrow funds within:
bankQuestions.options: ["24 hours","1 business day","3 business days","5 business days"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida law requires deposit within 3 business days of receipt. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Conversion is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Moving escrow between accounts","Using escrow funds for unauthorized purposes","Depositing late","Splitting commission"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Conversion is theft of client funds. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A listing agreement creates:
bankQuestions.options: ["An agency relationship between seller and broker","A lease","Title transfer","A mortgage"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Listings establish agency relationships. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which is a permissible advertising practice?
bankQuestions.options: ["Advertising unlicensed","Advertising under a team name with broker name included","Advertising without broker contact","Advertising under a personal phone only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Team names are allowed if broker identification is present. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which statement is correct about broker offices?
bankQuestions.options: ["No sign is required","The entrance must display the broker's licensed name","Offices can be in private homes only","Offices may not have branch locations"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Signage requirements apply to all broker offices. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker must maintain escrow records for:
bankQuestions.options: ["1 year","3 years","5 years","7 years"]
bankQuestions.explanation: All transaction records, including escrow, must be kept 5 years. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which document must be given to a buyer or seller at signing?
bankQuestions.options: ["The broker's resume","A copy of any signed documents","A tax form","Insurance certificate"]
bankQuestions.explanation: All parties must receive copies of anything they sign. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker's office must:
bankQuestions.options: ["Be located in a bank","Be accessible for inspections","Include a separate escrow vault","Be in a commercial zone only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: FREC may inspect broker offices to verify compliance. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker associate is:
bankQuestions.options: ["A person with an inactive license","A licensed broker working under another broker","A sales associate","An out-of-state licensee"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Broker associates hold broker licenses but work under another broker's supervision. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: An escrow account is also known as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Operating account","Trust account","Business account","Reserve account"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Escrow (trust) accounts hold funds belonging to others. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Commingling occurs when:
bankQuestions.options: ["Funds are lost","Escrow funds are mixed with personal or business funds","Broker deposits escrow late","Commission is split incorrectly"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Commingling is a serious violation. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: An earnest money dispute may be resolved by:
bankQuestions.options: ["FREC order","Police","Escrow disbursement order, mediation, arbitration, or interpleader","Automatic forfeiture"]
bankQuestions.explanation: These are the four legal options for handling disputes. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker advertising property for sale must include:
bankQuestions.options: ["The sales associate's name only","The broker's licensed name","Only the MLS number","Owner contact info"]
bankQuestions.explanation: All advertising must include the broker's licensed name. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: How must escrow records be reconciled?
bankQuestions.options: ["Annually","Monthly","Quarterly","Only if requested"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Monthly reconciliation is required. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A sales associate may pay referral fees to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Unlicensed persons","Out-of-state attorneys","Licensed real estate professionals through their broker","Anyone who brings a client"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Referral fees must be paid to properly licensed persons through brokers. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Interest-bearing escrow accounts:
bankQuestions.options: ["Are prohibited in Florida","Are allowed with written consent of all parties","Must be maintained by the state","May never be used for earnest money"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Interest-bearing accounts require written agreement by all parties. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: An exclusive right of sale listing means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Only one buyer can make an offer","The broker earns a commission regardless of who finds the buyer","The seller may sell without paying commission","The listing cannot be terminated"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This listing type guarantees the broker's commission. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: The Real Estate Recovery Fund pays claims for:
bankQuestions.options: ["Broker bankruptcy","Real estate judgments caused by licensee misconduct","Unpaid referral fees","Insurance losses"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The fund reimburses consumers harmed by licensee violations. (Unit 5 - Subunit 5.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: FREC may impose which penalty?
bankQuestions.options: ["Imprisonment","Fines up to $5,000 per violation","Arrest","Property forfeiture"]
bankQuestions.explanation: FREC can fine, suspend, revoke, or reprimand, but cannot imprison. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A citation is:
bankQuestions.options: ["A formal complaint","A quick resolution for minor violations with a fine","A license suspension","An appeal process"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Citations resolve minor violations without a formal hearing. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Conversion of escrow funds is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Moving funds to another account","Using client funds without authorization","Depositing funds early","Returning funds"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Conversion is theft and subject to severe penalties. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Before receiving money from the Recovery Fund, a claimant must:
bankQuestions.options: ["File a complaint with FREC","Obtain a civil court judgment","Negotiate with the broker","Pay a filing fee"]
bankQuestions.explanation: A court judgment is required and collection efforts must have failed. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Probable cause is determined by:
bankQuestions.options: ["DBPR staff","A FREC panel","The courts","The complainant"]
bankQuestions.explanation: A panel of FREC members reviews evidence for probable cause. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: An informal hearing is appropriate when:
bankQuestions.options: ["Facts are disputed","The licensee admits the violation but wants to be heard on penalties","Criminal charges are pending","The case involves fraud"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Informal hearings address penalty, not facts. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Culpable negligence is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Minor oversight","Gross carelessness that harms others","Intentional fraud","Breach of contract"]
bankQuestions.explanation: It shows reckless disregard for the consequences. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: License revocation means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Temporary suspension","Permanent loss unless reinstated","Automatic renewal","Probation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Revocation is the most severe penalty. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Misrepresentation includes:
bankQuestions.options: ["Honest mistakes","Knowingly giving false information","Forgetting details","Legal disclaimers"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Deliberate false statements are grounds for discipline. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Appeals of FREC final orders go to:
bankQuestions.options: ["U.S. Supreme Court","Local circuit court","District Court of Appeal","DBPR Board"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida appeals are filed with the DCA within 30 days. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which action is considered unlicensed activity?
bankQuestions.options: ["Selling your own property","Performing real estate services for another for compensation without a license","Giving free advice to a friend","Marketing your own rental"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Unlicensed activity is a third-degree felony. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which is NOT grounds for license denial?
bankQuestions.options: ["Felony conviction","Bankruptcy","Fraud","Moral turpitude crime"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Bankruptcy alone is not grounds for denial. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A notice of noncompliance is issued for:
bankQuestions.options: ["Fraud","Repeated violations","A minor first-time violation","Felony charges"]
bankQuestions.explanation: It gives the licensee a chance to correct without penalty. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: The Real Estate Recovery Fund maximum payout per transaction is:
bankQuestions.explanation: $50,000 per transaction, $150,000 per licensee lifetime. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: If the Recovery Fund pays on behalf of a licensee, the licensee:
bankQuestions.options: ["Receives a warning","Has their license automatically suspended until repayment","Is unaffected","Must appeal"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The license remains suspended until the fund is repaid with interest. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: A formal hearing is conducted by:
bankQuestions.options: ["FREC","DBPR","An administrative law judge (ALJ)","Local court"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Disputed facts are resolved in formal hearings before an ALJ. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Fraud in real estate may result in:
bankQuestions.options: ["CE requirement","Criminal prosecution","Probation only","Warning letter"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Fraud can lead to criminal charges plus license revocation. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A final order is issued by:
bankQuestions.options: ["ALJ","FREC","Governor","Complainant"]
bankQuestions.explanation: FREC issues final orders after hearings or consent orders. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Suspension of a license means:
bankQuestions.options: ["Permanent revocation","Temporary inability to practice","Automatic null and void","Probation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Suspension is temporary; the license can be reinstated after serving the period. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Failure to account for funds is a violation because:
bankQuestions.options: ["Records are optional","Brokers must account for all client funds entrusted to them","Only cash must be tracked","FREC does not require accounting"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Proper accounting is a fiduciary duty. (Unit 6 - Subunit 6.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The Civil Rights Act of 1866 prohibits discrimination based on:
bankQuestions.options: ["Sex only","Race only, with no exceptions","Religion only","All federal protected classes"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The 1866 Act covers race with no exceptions. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Blockbusting is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Building new developments","Encouraging sales by claiming a protected class is moving in","Blocking construction","Refusing a loan"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Blockbusting plays on fear to encourage sales. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) primarily applies to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Private residences","Public accommodations and commercial facilities","Single-family homes","Rental apartments only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: ADA focuses on accessibility in commercial and public spaces. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: A reasonable modification is:
bankQuestions.options: ["A rule change","A physical change to the property to accommodate a disability","A rent reduction","A lease change"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Modifications are physical alterations. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: RESPA prohibits:
bankQuestions.options: ["Disclosure of closing costs","Kickbacks and unearned referral fees","Mortgage applications","Title insurance"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Kickbacks inflate costs and are prohibited. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: The Truth in Lending Act (TILA) requires lenders to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Set interest rates","Disclose the APR and loan terms","Guarantee loan approval","Provide free credit reports"]
bankQuestions.explanation: TILA ensures borrowers understand credit costs. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.7)

bankQuestions.questionText: Market allocation among brokers is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Legal with consent","A violation of antitrust laws","Required for efficiency","Regulated by FREC"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Dividing territories restrains trade illegally. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.8)

bankQuestions.questionText: Florida's Landlord and Tenant Act requires landlords to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Increase rent annually","Maintain the premises in compliance with codes","Pay tenants' utilities","Allow all pets"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Landlords must keep property safe and habitable. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.9)

bankQuestions.questionText: The Do Not Call Registry prohibits:
bankQuestions.options: ["All phone calls","Telemarketing calls to registered numbers without consent","Business calls only","Calls during business hours"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Consumers can opt out of unsolicited calls. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.10)

bankQuestions.questionText: Familial status protects:
bankQuestions.options: ["Married couples only","Households with children under 18","Seniors over 65","Single adults"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Families with children are protected from discrimination. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: The Fair Housing Act prohibits discrimination based on:
bankQuestions.options: ["Income level","Race, color, religion, sex, national origin, familial status, handicap","Credit score","Occupation"]
bankQuestions.explanation: These are the seven protected classes under federal law. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Steering is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Encouraging sales in certain areas","Directing buyers toward or away from areas based on protected class","Setting high prices","Refusing to negotiate"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Steering limits housing choices based on protected status. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: Redlining refers to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Drawing boundaries on a map","Refusing loans or insurance based on neighborhood demographics","Pricing strategies","Advertising guidelines"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Redlining is discriminatory denial of services by area. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A reasonable accommodation is:
bankQuestions.options: ["A physical modification","A change in rules or policies for a person with a disability","An exemption from rent","A waiver of deposit"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Reasonable accommodations adjust policies, not structures. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: RESPA applies to:
bankQuestions.options: ["All cash transactions","Federally related residential mortgage loans","Commercial loans only","Private loans only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: RESPA covers residential loans involving federal connections. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: The Equal Credit Opportunity Act prohibits discrimination based on:
bankQuestions.options: ["Loan amount","Marital status and public assistance income","Property value","Neighborhood"]
bankQuestions.explanation: ECOA protects borrowers from credit discrimination. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.6)

bankQuestions.questionText: Price fixing among brokers is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Encouraged by FREC","A violation of antitrust laws","Legal if disclosed","Required by the MLS"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Fixing commission rates violates the Sherman Act. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.8)

bankQuestions.questionText: Group boycotts by brokers are:
bankQuestions.options: ["Legal","A violation of antitrust laws","Encouraged","Required in some areas"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Refusing to deal with competitors is illegal. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.8)

bankQuestions.questionText: Security deposit notice must be given to tenants within:
bankQuestions.options: ["10 days","30 days","60 days","90 days"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Landlords must notify tenants in writing within 30 days. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.9)

bankQuestions.questionText: CAN-SPAM Act requires commercial emails to include:
bankQuestions.options: ["Sender's Social Security number","A valid physical address and opt-out option","Recipient's income","Notarized signature"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Commercial emails must allow recipients to unsubscribe. (Unit 7 - Subunit 7.10)

bankQuestions.questionText: Tenancy by the entireties is available to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Business partners","Siblings","Friends","Married couples"]
bankQuestions.explanation: This special form includes unities + marriage + survivorship. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: A tenancy for years:
bankQuestions.options: ["Has no definite end date","Is month-to-month","Arises automatically after expiration","Has a fixed start and end date"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Tenancy for years must specify a beginning and ending date. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A tenancy at sufferance occurs when a tenant:
bankQuestions.options: ["Pays late","Holds over after the lease expires without permission","Damages property","Terminates early"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Holdover without landlord consent = tenancy at sufferance. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: A cooperative buyer receives:
bankQuestions.options: ["Fee simple title","Deed","Shares of stock and a proprietary lease","Assignable land contract"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Co-ops convey stock, not real property title. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which is a required disclosure for resale of a condominium?
bankQuestions.options: ["Home warranty","Flood certificate","Most recent year's financial report","Insurance binder"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida law requires delivery of financial and governing documents. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: The bundle of rights does NOT include:
bankQuestions.options: ["Disposition","Exclusion","Possession","Eminent domain"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Eminent domain is a government right, not an owner right. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Littoral rights apply to property bordering:
bankQuestions.options: ["Rivers","Streams","Oceans, lakes, and seas","Marshlands"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Littoral = large, nonmoving bodies of water. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Trade fixtures:
bankQuestions.options: ["Become real property","Must remain with the building","Are removable by commercial tenants","Are common elements"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Trade fixtures belong to the tenant and may be removed before lease end. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A tenancy at will may be terminated by:
bankQuestions.options: ["Automatic renewal","Court order only","Either party with proper notice","Only the landlord"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Tenancy at will has no definite end date and is terminable at will. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.3)

bankQuestions.questionText: In a condominium, the owner holds:
bankQuestions.options: ["Fee simple interest in the common areas","Fee simple interest in the unit + undivided share of common elements","Leasehold interest","Timeshare only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Common areas are owned as undivided fractional shares. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which document governs operation of a condominium association?
bankQuestions.options: ["Warranty deed","Bylaws alone","Listing contract","Declaration of condominium"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The declaration establishes the condominium's legal structure. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Timeshare ownership that provides fixed, recurring intervals each year is a:
bankQuestions.options: ["Cooperative","Condo lease","Interval ownership timeshare","Floating unit"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Interval ownership grants deeded rights for specific recurring time periods. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.5)

bankQuestions.questionText: Riparian rights apply to:
bankQuestions.options: ["Oceans","Natural lakes","Rivers and flowing waterways","Groundwater"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Riparian = moving water; littoral = standing water. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: A fixture is legally determined by:
bankQuestions.options: ["Color","Whether it's new","Intent of the parties + method of attachment","Cost"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Intent + attachment + adaptation determine fixture status. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: In a cooperative, property taxes are:
bankQuestions.options: ["Paid by each unit owner","Included in HOA fees only","Paid by the corporation, then passed to shareholders","Not required"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Shareholders pay their proportionate share through maintenance fees. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.4)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which item is considered a fixture?
bankQuestions.options: ["Furniture","Built-in dishwasher","Area rug","Window curtains"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Fixtures are permanently attached and transfer with the property. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Appurtenances include:
bankQuestions.options: ["Personal belongings","Rights that run with the land, such as easements","Furniture","Vehicles"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Appurtenances transfer with ownership. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Which tenancy includes the right of survivorship?
bankQuestions.options: ["Tenancy in common","Joint tenancy","Tenancy at will","Tenancy for years"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Joint tenants acquire equal interests at the same time with survivorship. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.2)

bankQuestions.questionText: Personal property is also known as:
bankQuestions.options: ["Real estate","Chattel","Fixtures","Appurtenances"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Chattel = movable personal property. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText: Real property includes:
bankQuestions.options: ["Personal belongings","Land and anything permanently attached","Vehicles only","Cash and securities"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Real property = land + improvements + rights. (Unit 8 - Subunit 8.1)

bankQuestions.questionText:
Select the best answer for each question.

A new broker should maintain working capital sufficient to cover operating expenses for approximately:
bankQuestions.options: ["1-3 months","3-6 months","6-12 months","18-24 months"]
bankQuestions.explanation: 6-12 months Explanation: Segment 1: Capital Requirements under "Working Capital" states brokers should maintain "Funds to cover operating expenses during ramp-up period" and specifies "Typically need 6-12 months of operating expenses." This provides a cushion during the period before commission income becomes consistent.

bankQuestions.questionText:
Tax benefits of ownership

Initial investment in office equipment, furniture, and technology typically ranges from:
bankQuestions.explanation: $6,000-$21,000 total Explanation: Segment 1: Capital Requirements under "Attorney and Accountant Fees" provides detailed ranges: Attorney services "Estimated Total: $3,500-$14,000" and Accountant services "Estimated Total: $2,500-$7,000," which totals $6,000-$21,000.

bankQuestions.questionText:
Proximity to coffee shops

A brokerage needs to generate $48,000 monthly in gross commission income to break even. If the average commission to the brokerage is 3% of sales price, approximately what monthly sales volume is required?
bankQuestions.options: ["$1.2 million","$1.6 million","$2.4 million","$4.8 million"]
bankQuestions.explanation: $23,500-$63,500 Explanation: Segment 1: Capital Requirements under "Office Equipment and Furniture" provides detailed breakdowns and concludes with "Total Equipment and Furniture: $23,500-$63,500."

bankQuestions.questionText: Typical monthly marketing budget for an established brokerage should be approximately:
bankQuestions.options: ["$500-$1,000","$1,000-$2,000","10-15% of gross commission income","25-30% of gross commission income"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Number and productivity of sales associates Explanation: Segment 2: Business Planning under "Income Projections - Factors Affecting Income Projections" identifies "Number and Projected Productivity of Sales Associates" as a major factor and provides the formula showing income is directly calculated from number of associates multiplied by their production.

bankQuestions.questionText:
Marketing strategy

Which income source provides recurring, predictable monthly revenue?
bankQuestions.options: ["Sales commissions","Property management fees","Referral fees","Transaction coordination fees"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Office manager's salary Explanation: Segment 2: Business Planning under "Typical Fixed Expenses" lists "Salaries and Employer Contributions for Employees" including "Office manager: $35,000-$55,000 annually" as a fixed expense. Fixed expenses are defined as "Costs that remain relatively constant regardless of sales volume."

bankQuestions.questionText:
Technology and software

Attorney and accountant fees for establishing a new brokerage typically range from:
bankQuestions.explanation: Office rental or mortgage payments Explanation: Segment 1: Capital Requirements under "Office Space - Lease Payments" identifies monthly rent as "Typically largest fixed expense." The segment on Typical Fixed Expenses lists "Office rental or mortgage payments" first among fixed expenses, ranging from $2,000-$8,000+ monthly.

bankQuestions.questionText: A brokerage projects $500,000 in annual gross commission income with an average 70/30 split (associate receives 70%). The "company dollar" will be:
bankQuestions.explanation: Much lower initial capital requirement Explanation: Segment 1: Capital Requirements under "Office Space - Option B: Lease Office Space - Advantages" lists "Much lower initial capital requirement" as the first advantage, with estimated total initial costs of $11,000-$46,000 versus $49,000-$215,000+ for purchasing.

bankQuestions.questionText:
Annual business license

Professional liability (errors and omissions) insurance for a broker typically costs:
bankQuestions.explanation: $150,000 Explanation: Segment 2: Business Planning under "Sales Commissions - Company Dollar Explained" defines company dollar as "Portion of commission retained by brokerage" after "paying associate's split." The calculation: $500,000  30% (broker's share) = $150,000. This is the broker's gross income before expenses.

bankQuestions.questionText: What is the total capital needed?
bankQuestions.explanation: $1.6 million Explanation: Segment 2: Business Planning provides the calculation method. If the brokerage needs $48,000 in gross commission and receives 3% commission, the required sales volume is $48,000  0.03 = $1,600,000 monthly.

bankQuestions.questionText: NOI $84,000, cap rate 7%. Value is:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: Monthly rent $2,400, GRM 125. Value is:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: NOI $110,000, debt service $82,000. DSCR is:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: Purchase $1,200,000, land $300,000, residential. Annual depreciation is:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.options: ["40 acres","80 acres","160 acres","320 acres"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

A broker must notify FREC of conflicting demands within:
bankQuestions.options: ["3 days","10 days","15 business days","30 days"]

bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.options: ["7 days","15 days","30 days","45 days"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

Soil sampling b. Groundwater testingc. Records review without sampling d. Contamination cleanup

Lead-based paint disclosure applies to properties built before:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

One FREC member b. Two FREC membersc. Three FREC members d. The entire FREC

bankQuestions.questionText:
Select the best answer for each question.

What is the minimum active sales associate experience required to apply for a broker license in Florida?
bankQuestions.options: ["12 months during the preceding two years","18 months during the preceding three years","24 months during the preceding five years","36 months during the preceding seven years"]
bankQuestions.explanation: 24 months during the preceding five years Explanation: Section 475.17, F.S. requires applicants to hold an active sales associate license for at least 24 months during the five-year period preceding application. This is explicitly covered in Segment 3: Education and Experience Requirements under the "Basic Experience Requirement" heading, which states: "Must hold active sales associate license for 24 months during preceding five years." The time must be in active status - inactive periods do not

bankQuestions.questionText:
Active, inactive, or null and void status

The broker license examination consists of how many questions?
bankQuestions.options: ["75 questions","100 questions","120 questions","150 questions"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Denial based on failure to disclose Explanation: Failure to disclose any conviction (regardless of how old) constitutes grounds for denial under s. 475.17, F.S. Segment 1: Broker License Application Requirements under "Consequences of Failing to Disclose" explicitly states: "Automatic denial of application" and "Permanent bar from licensure for fraudulent applications" as penalties. The Important Note in that section emphasizes: "Even minor offenses must be disclosed. The DBPR considers honesty

bankQuestions.questionText: If a candidate fails the broker examination, how long must they wait before retaking it?
bankQuestions.options: ["24 hours","7 days","30 days","90 days"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Consent to service of process Explanation: Section 475.180, F.S. requires nonresident applicants to file a consent to service of process with the DBPR, designating the Secretary of State as agent for service of legal documents in any disciplinary proceedings. This is covered in Segment 2: Nonresident Applicants and Mutual Recognition under "Additional Nonresident Requirements - Consent to Service of Process," which states: "Nonresidents must file consent with DBPR" and "Designates Florida Secret

bankQuestions.questionText:
Background check

How many hours of broker pre-license education are required in Florida?
bankQuestions.options: ["45 hours","63 hours","72 hours","90 hours"]
bankQuestions.explanation: An active-duty military spouse stationed in Florida Explanation: Florida law (s. 455.213, F.S.) provides application fee waivers for active-duty military members, their spouses, honorably discharged veterans within 60 months of discharge, and their spouses. This is taught in Segment 1: Broker License Application Requirements under "Fee Waivers for Specific Groups - Military Personnel and Spouses," which specifically lists "Spouses of active duty military members" as qualifying for fee waivers. A

bankQuestions.questionText: What is the passing score for the Florida broker license examination?
bankQuestions.explanation: Anyone who has resided in Florida for four consecutive months Explanation: Section 475.01, F.S. defines a Florida resident for licensing purposes as someone who has resided in Florida for at least four consecutive months. This definition appears in Segment 2: Nonresident Applicants and Mutual Recognition under "Florida Resident Defined," which states: "A person is considered a Florida resident for licensing purposes if they have resided in Florida for at least four consecutive months within the

bankQuestions.questionText:
Five years

Which statement about the broker examination is TRUE?
bankQuestions.options: ["Reference materials are allowed during the test","Results are mailed within 10 business days","The exam is given only at DBPR offices","Candidates may challenge defective questions"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Waiver of pre-license education requirement Explanation: Mutual recognition agreements waive the 72-hour broker pre-license course requirement but do NOT waive the Florida law course, the examination, background check, or experience requirement. Segment 2: Nonresident Applicants and Mutual Recognition under "Benefits of Mutual Recognition" lists "Waiver of pre-license education requirement" as the first benefit, but the "Important Limitations" section clarifies that it "does NOT waive the Florid

bankQuestions.questionText:
Sales associate must reapply for license

A broker fails to update the DBPR within 10 days of an address change. The broker misses important correspondence regarding a complaint. What is the likely outcome?
bankQuestions.options: ["Complaint dismissed because broker didn't receive notice","Broker given additional time to respond","Correspondence deemed delivered; broker sanctioned for failure to update","DBPR must resend correspondence to new address"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Licensure grants authority to practice; registration establishes employment/business relationship Explanation: Segment 6: Registration, Multiple Licenses, and Exemptions under "Registration vs. Licensure" clearly distinguishes the two concepts. "Licensure" is defined as: "The process by which DBPR grants authority to practice real estate to qualified individuals" and "Creates legal right to practice real estate." "Registration" is defined as: "The process of associating with an employing broker

bankQuestions.questionText:
Management structure

For a corporation to qualify for S Corporation tax status, it must have no more than:
bankQuestions.options: ["50 shareholders","75 shareholders","100 shareholders","150 shareholders"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Limited liability company Explanation: Segment 1: Business Structures under "Limited Liability Company - Characteristics" explains that LLCs provide "Limited Liability: Members not personally liable for company debts" and "Taxation: Default: Pass-through taxation like partnership." This combination is the defining characteristic of LLCs. The segment states: "The limited liability company combines the liability protection of a corporation with the taxation benefits and flexibility of a partnershi

bankQuestions.questionText:
Can only be managed by non-members

A sales associate may own stock in their employing corporate brokerage if:
bankQuestions.options: ["They are a minority shareholder without management control","They own at least 51% of the shares","They serve on the board of directors","This is never permitted under any circumstances"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The broker for all debts with unlimited personal liability Explanation: Segment 1: Business Structures under "Sole Proprietorship - Characteristics" clearly states: "Unlimited Personal Liability: Owner personally liable for all business debts," "No legal separation between personal and business assets," and "Creditors can pursue owner's personal property." This unlimited liability is one of the primary disadvantages of operating as a sole proprietorship.

bankQuestions.questionText:
PMI for life of loan

PMI can be cancelled by borrower request at:
bankQuestions.explanation: Government-sponsored enterprises - Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are GSEs.

bankQuestions.questionText:
Sets interest rates

The conforming loan limit for 2024 in most areas is approximately:
bankQuestions.explanation: Buys and sells existing loans - The secondary market deals in existing mortgages.

bankQuestions.questionText:
Negative amortization

The secondary market benefits borrowers by:
bankQuestions.options: ["Increasing interest rates","Ensuring continuous availability of mortgage funds","Eliminating down payments","Removing credit requirements"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Guarantees securities backed by government loans - Ginnie Mae guarantees FHA/VA/USDA loan securities.

bankQuestions.questionText:
No personal funds permitted

The maximum amount of personal funds a broker may keep in a property management escrow account is:
bankQuestions.explanation: Hold funds belonging to others separate from broker's funds Explanation: Segment 1: Establishing Escrow Accounts under "Purpose of Escrow Accounts - Primary Purposes" lists "Protect Client Funds: Keep client money safe and separate" and "Prevent mixing with broker's funds" as the primary purposes. The account holds "funds belonging to others" and keeps them separate from the broker's personal and business funds.

bankQuestions.questionText:
Must be used for deposits over $10,000

A broker holds an earnest money deposit in the office safe instead of depositing it. This is:
bankQuestions.options: ["Always prohibited","Permitted if all parties agree in writing","Permitted for up to 30 days","A best practice for security"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Sales escrow and rental escrow Explanation: Segment 1: Establishing Escrow Accounts under "Types of Monies to be Placed in Escrow - Important Distinction" states: "Florida law requires separate escrow accounts for: Sales escrow (purchase transactions) [and] Rental/security deposit escrow (landlord-tenant)" and explicitly notes: "Cannot commingle rental and sales escrow funds."

bankQuestions.questionText:
Sales associate registration documents

If a broker refuses to cooperate with a DBPR office inspection:
bankQuestions.options: ["The inspector must leave immediately","The broker may face administrative discipline","The inspection is automatically cancelled","No consequences result"]
bankQuestions.explanation: The brokerage name and "Licensed Real Estate Broker" Explanation: Segment 1: Office Inspections under "Office Entrance Sign - Required Elements" states: "Brokerage name as registered with DBPR" and "Words 'Licensed Real Estate Broker' or abbreviation."

bankQuestions.questionText:
Conversion

The fine for operating with an expired license for less than 60 days through the citation process is typically:
bankQuestions.explanation: Broker's personal credit score Explanation: Segment 1: Office Inspections under "What Inspectors Review" lists: physical office, entrance sign, licenses and registrations, and brokerage relationship disclosures. Personal credit scores are not reviewed during office inspections as they are not relevant to regulatory compliance.

bankQuestions.questionText: Intangible tax on a $275,000 mortgage is:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: A broker earned $21,600 at 6%. The sale price was:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: Documentary stamps on a $385,000 sale are:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: A property sells for $525,000 at 5.5% commission. The commission is:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: Commission was $33,000 on a $600,000 sale. The rate was:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: Doc stamps on a $295,000 note are:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: A seller wants to net $275,000 after 6% commission. The sale price must be:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText: Total commission is 6%. Listing broker gets 60%, pays agent 75%. On $400,000 sale, agent receives:
bankQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option A.

bankQuestions.questionText:
Only comply if building is over 5,000 square feet

Under the ADA, a real estate brokerage with 15 or more employees must:
bankQuestions.options: ["Provide reasonable accommodations for employees with disabilities","Hire a specific percentage of workers with disabilities","Rebuild the entire office to be accessible","Obtain special licensing from the Department of Justice"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Joint venture Explanation: Segment 2: Business Forms That Cannot Register lists joint ventures (joint adventures) as prohibited business structures. The segment explains: "A joint venture is a business relationship created for a single transaction or limited series of transactions" and states it's prohibited because "Temporary nature incompatible with ongoing brokerage operations" and "Broker supervision requires continuity."

bankQuestions.questionText: A proration is best described as:
bankQuestions.options: ["A commission split between agents","Division of ongoing expenses between buyer and seller","A discount on closing costs","A type of mortgage payment"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Prorations divide expenses fairly between buyer and seller based on the closing date.

bankQuestions.questionText: Documentary stamp tax on a deed in Florida (outside Miami-Dade) is:
bankQuestions.explanation: The standard Florida documentary stamp tax rate on deeds is $0.70 per $100 of consideration.

bankQuestions.questionText: Title insurance protects against:
bankQuestions.options: ["Future events only","Past defects in title","Property damage","Mortgage default"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Title insurance protects against existing but undiscovered defects in title that occurred before the policy date.

bankQuestions.questionText: In Florida, property taxes are paid:
bankQuestions.options: ["In advance for the coming year","In arrears for the prior year","Monthly with mortgage payments","At the time of purchase only"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida property taxes are paid in arrears, covering the prior year's taxes.

bankQuestions.questionText: The intangible tax on a new mortgage in Florida is:
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida's intangible tax is $2.00 per $1,000 of new mortgage (equal to 2 mills or $0.002 per dollar).

bankQuestions.questionText:
DBPR must dismiss the case

A final order may be appealed to:
bankQuestions.options: ["FREC for reconsideration","The circuit court/district court of appeal","The local real estate board","The Governor"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Any person, including anonymous complainants if in writing Explanation: Segment 2: The Complaint Process under "Filing a Complaint - Who May File" lists: "Any person, Consumer, Licensee, Government agency, Anonymous complainant (in writing)."

bankQuestions.questionText:
Pay a penalty fee and get an automatic extension

How many hours of continuing education must brokers complete for each renewal period?
bankQuestions.options: ["14 hours","28 hours","45 hours","60 hours"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Within the first renewal period Explanation: The 60-hour post-licensing education must be completed before the first renewal of the license. Segment 4: Post-Licensing and Continuing Education under "Post-License Course Requirements" states: "Must be completed within first renewal period (typically 18-24 months)." The "Completion Requirements" section further clarifies: "Must complete within first renewal period."

bankQuestions.questionText:
Complete 60 hours of post-licensing education

A license has been null and void for three years. What is required for reinstatement?
bankQuestions.options: ["Complete 28 hours of continuing education","Complete 14 hours of continuing education and retake the examination","Pay a reinstatement fee only","Reapply as a new applicant and retake pre-license course"]
bankQuestions.explanation: 14 hours Explanation: Florida requires 14 hours of continuing education for each two-year renewal period. Segment 4: Post-Licensing and Continuing Education under "Basic Continuing Education Requirement" clearly states: "14 hours every two years." The section notes this "applies equally to sales associates, broker associates, and brokers."

bankQuestions.questionText:
Select the best answer for each question.

How many hours of post-licensing education must a newly licensed broker complete?
bankQuestions.options: ["28 hours","45 hours","60 hours","72 hours"]
bankQuestions.explanation: 60 hours Explanation: Section 475.17, F.S. requires all newly licensed brokers to complete 60 hours of post-licensing education during their first renewal period. Segment 4: Post-Licensing and Continuing Education under "Post-License Course Requirements" explicitly states: "60 hours of approved post-licensing education" and "Must be completed within first renewal period (typically 18-24 months)." This is in addition to any continuing education requirements and focuses on practical application of

bankQuestions.questionText: The continuing education requirement includes how many hours of Core Law?
bankQuestions.options: ["None - it's optional","3 hours","7 hours","14 hours"]
bankQuestions.explanation: Request a hardship extension from FREC Explanation: FREC may grant extensions for post-licensing education completion in cases of legitimate hardship. Segment 4: Post-Licensing and Continuing Education under "Hardship Cases" lists "Serious illness or medical condition" as a qualifying hardship and provides the "Hardship Application Process" which includes: "Submit written request to FREC before deadline" and "FREC reviews and approves/denies."

bankQuestions.questionText: In Florida, a person who leases property on behalf of others for compensation must possess:
bankQuestions.options: {"A property management certification","An active real estate license","A community association manager license","No license is required"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida statutes require that individuals who lease, rent, or manage real property for others for compensation hold a valid real estate license. This requirement ensures that property managers have the education and oversight necessary to protect property owners and tenants.

bankQuestions.questionText: A property manager's primary objectives include all of the following EXCEPT:
bankQuestions.options: {"Generating maximum rental income","Preserving property value","Guaranteeing the owner against all losses","Achieving the owner's investment goals"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Property managers cannot and should not guarantee owners against all losses, as many factors affecting property performance lie beyond management control. The manager's proper objectives include maximizing income, preserving value, and working to achieve the owner's specific goals.

bankQuestions.questionText: Under Florida law, landlords must maintain which of the following in reasonable working condition?
bankQuestions.options: {"Swimming pool filtration","Plumbing systems","Landscaping irrigation","Decorative lighting"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida's landlord-tenant statute specifically requires landlords to maintain plumbing in reasonable working condition. This represents a core habitability requirement.

bankQuestions.questionText: Security deposits in Florida must be held in:
bankQuestions.options: {"Any convenient bank account","A Florida banking institution","A safe deposit box","The manager's business account"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida law specifically requires that security deposits be held in a banking institution located in Florida. The landlord may choose between non-interest-bearing accounts, interest-bearing accounts, or surety bonds.

bankQuestions.questionText: If a landlord intends to claim against a security deposit, notice must be sent within:
bankQuestions.options: {"7 days","15 days","30 days","45 days"}
bankQuestions.explanation: When claiming amounts from the security deposit, the landlord has thirty days from the tenant's departure to send itemized written notice by certified mail. This notice must describe each claimed item specifically.

bankQuestions.questionText: Landlords must disclose security deposit account information within how many days of receiving the deposit?
bankQuestions.options: {"7 days","15 days","30 days","60 days"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Landlords must provide written disclosure of security deposit account information within thirty days of receiving the deposit. This disclosure must include the depository's name and address and whether the account earns interest.

bankQuestions.questionText: Reasonable advance notice before entering an occupied rental unit in Florida is presumed to be:
bankQuestions.options: {"6 hours","12 hours","24 hours","48 hours"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida law provides that twelve hours constitutes presumptively reasonable advance notice before landlord entry into an occupied rental unit. The notice should specify the date, approximate time, and purpose of entry.

bankQuestions.questionText: The management agreement should specify all of the following EXCEPT:
bankQuestions.options: {"Manager's compensation","Property description","Names of future tenants","Term of the agreement"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Management agreements establish the terms between owner and manager but cannot identify future tenants who haven't yet applied or been selected. Tenant identification occurs later through the leasing process.

bankQuestions.questionText: Which document establishes the relationship between a property owner and the property manager?
bankQuestions.options: {"Listing agreement","Lease agreement","Management agreement","Purchase contract"}
bankQuestions.explanation: The management agreement is the contract that creates the agency relationship between the property owner and the property manager. This document specifies the manager's duties, compensation, authority limits, and other essential terms.

bankQuestions.questionText: Management fees for residential properties typically range from:
bankQuestions.options: {"1% to 3% of gross rent","8% to 12% of gross rent","20% to 25% of gross rent","15% to 18% of gross rent"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Residential property management fees typically fall within the 8-12% range, though actual fees vary based on property type, size, location, and services provided. Commercial properties typically command lower percentages (3-6%) due to larger rent amounts.

bankQuestions.questionText: Which action constitutes illegal self-help eviction in Florida?
bankQuestions.options: {"Serving a three-day notice","Changing locks while tenant is away","Filing an eviction lawsuit","Charging late fees"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Changing locks to exclude a tenant constitutes illegal self-help eviction under Florida law. Landlords must pursue formal legal eviction procedures through the courts rather than taking matters into their own hands.

bankQuestions.questionText: When a landlord makes no claim against a security deposit, it must be returned within:
bankQuestions.options: {"7 days","15 days","30 days","45 days"}
bankQuestions.explanation: When the landlord intends no claim against the security deposit, the full amount must be returned within fifteen days after the tenant vacates. Missing this deadline can result in forfeiture of the landlord's right to later impose claims.

bankQuestions.questionText: Which is a statutory obligation of tenants under Florida law?
bankQuestions.options: {"Making structural repairs","Painting interior walls annually","Maintaining the unit in clean condition","Replacing worn appliances"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida statute specifically obligates tenants to keep their dwelling unit in a clean and sanitary condition. Structural repairs and appliance replacement are typically landlord responsibilities.

bankQuestions.questionText: After receiving notice of a landlord's security deposit claim, a tenant has how many days to object?
bankQuestions.options: {"7 days","15 days","30 days","45 days"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Upon receiving the landlord's notice of intent to claim against the security deposit, the tenant has fifteen days to object in writing. If the tenant fails to timely object, the landlord may deduct the claimed amounts.

bankQuestions.questionText: A landlord who interrupts essential services to force a tenant to vacate has committed:
bankQuestions.options: {"A permitted collection tactic","An illegal self-help eviction","A lease modification","An acceleration of rent"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Interrupting essential serviceselectricity, gas, water, or heatto force a tenant to leave constitutes prohibited self-help eviction under Florida law. Service interruption exposes landlords to tenant lawsuits and potential damages.

bankQuestions.questionText: A tenancy with specified commencement and termination dates is called:
bankQuestions.options: {"Estate at will","Estate for years","Periodic estate","Estate at sufferance"}
bankQuestions.explanation: An estate for years has definite, specified beginning and ending dates. The key characteristic is the definite termination date, after which the tenancy ends automatically without requiring notice from either party.

bankQuestions.questionText: Florida law requires how many days notice to terminate a month-to-month tenancy?
bankQuestions.options: {"7 days","15 days","30 days","60 days"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Florida statute specifies that month-to-month tenancies require fifteen days advance notice for termination. Week-to-week requires seven days, while year-to-year requires sixty days.

bankQuestions.questionText: In a gross lease, who pays operating expenses?
bankQuestions.options: {"The tenant","The landlord","Expenses are shared equally","A third-party management company"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Under a gross lease structure, the tenant pays a fixed rent amount while the landlord assumes responsibility for paying all operating expenses including property taxes, insurance, utilities, and maintenance.

bankQuestions.questionText: Percentage leases are most commonly used for:
bankQuestions.options: {"Residential apartment units","Industrial warehouse space","Retail commercial properties","Professional office buildings"}
bankQuestions.explanation: Percentage leases are standard in retail settings where landlords share in tenant business success. The structure typically combines base rent with additional rent calculated as a percentage of gross sales.

bankQuestions.questionText: An assignment of a lease involves:
bankQuestions.options: {"Transfer of a portion of the space","Transfer for less than the remaining term","Transfer of the entire remaining interest","Return of the security deposit"}
bankQuestions.explanation: An assignment transfers the tenant's complete remaining lease interest to another party. The assignee steps into the original tenant's position and deals directly with the landlord.

bankQuestions.questionText: A month-to-month rental arrangement is classified as:
bankQuestions.options: {"Estate for years","Estate at will","Periodic estate","Estate at sufferance"}
bankQuestions.explanation: A month-to-month tenancy exemplifies the periodic estate, which automatically renews for successive periods until either party provides proper termination notice.

bankQuestions.questionText: A tenant remaining after lease expiration without landlord consent has:
bankQuestions.options: {"Estate for years","Estate at will","Periodic estate","Estate at sufferance"}
bankQuestions.explanation: When a tenant remains in possession after lease expiration without the landlord's permission, an estate at sufferance results. This represents the most limited form of tenancy interest.

bankQuestions.questionText: Under a triple net lease, the tenant pays rent plus:
bankQuestions.options: {"Property taxes only","Property taxes and insurance only","Property taxes, insurance, and maintenance","Three months rent in advance"}
bankQuestions.explanation: A triple net (NNN) lease requires the tenant to pay base rent plus property taxes, insurance premiums, and maintenance costs. This shifts virtually all operating expenses to the tenant.

bankQuestions.questionText: The sales threshold at which percentage rent begins is called the:
bankQuestions.options: {"Base rent","Breakpoint","Overage","Escalation"}
bankQuestions.explanation: The breakpoint is the gross sales level at which percentage rent begins. Sales below the breakpoint incur only base rent; sales above trigger additional percentage rent.

bankQuestions.questionText: In a sublease arrangement:
bankQuestions.options: {"The original tenant is fully released","The subtenant pays rent directly to the landlord","The original tenant retains some interest","Landlord consent is never required"}
bankQuestions.explanation: In a sublease, the original tenant transfers only a portion of their interest while retaining some rights. The subtenant pays rent to the original tenant, and the original tenant remains primarily liable.

bankQuestions.questionText: An index lease ties rent adjustments to:
bankQuestions.options: {"Property value changes","An economic indicator like CPI","The landlord's operating expenses","Current interest rates"}
