examQuestions.options: ["Vacant land","Singlefamily homes","Apartment buildings","Specialpurpose buildings"]

examQuestions.questionText: A buyer gives the seller consideration in exchange for the right to purchase the property later. This agreement is a:
examQuestions.explanation: An option is unilateralthe seller must sell if exercised, but the buyer is not obligated.
examQuestions.options: ["Bilateral contract","Listing agreement","Sales contract","Option contract"]

examQuestions.questionText: A borrower's monthly payment includes principal, interest, taxes, and insurance. This is a:

examQuestions.options: ["Growing equity mortgage","ARM","Interestonly loan","PITI payment"]

examQuestions.questionText: A house with peeling paint and worn flooring is suffering from:

examQuestions.options: ["Functional obsolescence","Economic obsolescence","Physical deterioration","External depreciation"]

examQuestions.questionText: A licensee who forgets to include a required disclosure has committed:

examQuestions.options: ["Fraud","Culpable negligence","Conspiracy","Misrepresentation"]

examQuestions.questionText: A tenant remains on property after lease expiration without the landlord's consent. This tenancy is called:

examQuestions.options: ["Allowed if disclosed","Allowed for marketing","Prohibited kickbacks or referral fees","Required for title services"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which of the following is a protected class under the Fair Housing Act?

examQuestions.options: ["Smokers","Familial status","Occupation","Students"]

examQuestions.questionText: A variance is granted when:

A lender must provide a Loan Estimate within:

examQuestions.options: ["Title theory","Lien theory","Ownership theory","Mortgageetitle doctrine"]

examQuestions.explanation: The landlord has: 15 days to return deposit if no claim; 30 days to notify of claim.
examQuestions.options: ["7 days","15 days","30 days","45 days"]

examQuestions.questionText: When a tenant pays a fixed rent and the landlord pays all operating expenses, the lease is a:

examQuestions.options: ["Gross lease","Net lease","Percentage lease","Variable lease"]

examQuestions.questionText: The purpose of the defeasance clause in a mortgage is to:

examQuestions.options: ["Trigger foreclosure","Prevent resale","Increase interest","Require the lender to release the lien when debt is paid"]

examQuestions.options: ["Unequal interests","No survivorship","Unity of possession, interest, title, and time","Married owners only"]

examQuestions.questionText: A licensee tells owners that minorities are moving into the neighborhood to encourage them to sell quickly. This is:

examQuestions.options: ["Steering","Redlining","Blockbusting","Canvassing"]

examQuestions.questionText: Economic (external) obsolescence is caused by:

examQuestions.options: ["Chapter 20, Florida Statutes","Chapter 120, Florida Statutes","Chapter 475, Florida Statutes","Rule Chapter 61J2, Florida Administrative Code"]

examQuestions.options: ["high liquidity","low leverage","lack of liquidity","automatic returns"]

examQuestions.options: ["rent minus mortgage","effective gross income minus operating expenses","gross income minus capital expenses","cash flow minus taxes"]

examQuestions.options: ["income times rate equals value","income divided by rate equals value","value divided by income equals rate","rate divided by value equals income"]

examQuestions.options: ["multiply value by cap rate","divide value by cap rate","multiply cash flow by debt service","divide rent by taxes"]

examQuestions.options: ["rent increases only","loan principal reduction","higher taxes","depreciation"]

examQuestions.options: ["only land sales","ongoing enterprises and intangible assets","tenant placement","mortgage underwriting"]

examQuestions.options: ["assets and liabilities","cash reserves","revenue and expenses","depreciation only"]

examQuestions.options: ["businesses are intangible","business sales often involve real property or leases","the IRS requires it","lenders require it"]

examQuestions.options: ["assets only","ownership of the corporation including liabilities","inventory only","goodwill only"]

examQuestions.options: ["married couples only","households with a child under eighteen","senior citizens only","individuals living alone"]

examQuestions.options: ["race only","race and religion","race and sex","all protected classes"]

examQuestions.options: ["commercial loans only","federally related residential mortgage loans","all cash transactions","seller financing only"]

examQuestions.options: ["property value","marital status and receipt of public assistance","loan amount","neighborhood"]

examQuestions.options: ["increase rent annually","maintain the property in compliance with codes","provide free utilities","allow pets in all units"]

examQuestions.options: ["all phone calls to consumers","marketing calls to registered numbers without consent or business relationship","calls from brokers only","calls during business hours"]

examQuestions.options: ["Fair Housing Act","Civil Rights Act of 1866","ADA","RESPA"]

examQuestions.questionText: Constructive notice is provided by

examQuestions.options: ["A. personal delivery of a document","B. verbal disclosure","C. recording documents in the public records","D. mailing a letter"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which deed provides the most warranties
examQuestions.explanation: A general warranty deed provides the most complete warranties of title.
examQuestions.options: ["A. quitclaim deed","B. special warranty deed","C. bargain and sale deed","D. general warranty deed"]

examQuestions.questionText: A quitclaim deed is often used to
examQuestions.explanation: Quitclaim deeds are often used to clear clouds on title because they convey whatever interest exists.
examQuestions.options: ["A. guarantee clear title","B. remove a cloud on title","C. give a lender more security","D. transfer a mortgage"]

examQuestions.questionText: The highest priority lien in Florida is
examQuestions.explanation: Real estate property tax liens always take priority over all other liens regardless of recording date.
examQuestions.options: ["A. first mortgage lien","B. judgment lien","C. real estate property tax lien","D. vendor lien"]

examQuestions.questionText: A special warranty deed protects the grantee
examQuestions.explanation: A special warranty deed limits warranties to defects that occurred during the grantor's ownership.
examQuestions.options: ["A. against all title defects in history","B. only against defects arising during the grantor's ownership","C. against encroachments","D. against zoning violations"]

examQuestions.questionText: A lien for unpaid property taxes is
examQuestions.explanation: Property tax liens are superior liens with the highest priority of all liens.
examQuestions.options: ["A. junior to a first mortgage","B. always the lowest priority lien","C. a superior lien","D. equal to judgment liens"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which type of deed contains the greatest number of warranties and provides the most protection to the grantee?
examQuestions.explanation: A general warranty deed contains all six covenants of title and warrants against defects arising during the grantor's ownership and all prior owners.
examQuestions.options: ["Quitclaim deed","Bargain and sale deed","Special warranty deed","General warranty deed"]

examQuestions.questionText: The granting clause in a deed contains:
examQuestions.explanation: The granting clause contains the words of conveyance such as 'grant' or 'convey' that transfer title.
examQuestions.options: ["Legal description of the property","Words of conveyance","Acknowledgment","Recording information"]

examQuestions.questionText: A deed that transfers whatever interest the grantor has, without any warranties, is called a:
examQuestions.explanation: A quitclaim deed offers no warranties and simply conveys whatever interest the grantor may have.
examQuestions.options: ["General warranty deed","Special warranty deed","Quitclaim deed","Bargain and sale deed"]

examQuestions.questionText: For a deed to be valid, it must be:
examQuestions.explanation: The grantor's signature is essential for a valid deed. Recording provides constructive notice but is not required for validity.
examQuestions.options: ["Recorded","Notarized","Signed by the grantee","Signed by the grantor"]

examQuestions.questionText: Title insurance protects against:
examQuestions.explanation: Title insurance protects against defects in title that existed before the policy was issued but were not discovered.
examQuestions.options: ["Future zoning changes","Physical damage to property","Hidden title defects existing before policy date","Market value decline"]

examQuestions.questionText: A restrictive covenant that prohibits certain uses of property is also called a:
examQuestions.explanation: Deed restrictions (restrictive covenants) limit how property can be used, such as prohibiting commercial activities in residential areas.
examQuestions.options: ["Lien","Deed restriction","Easement appurtenant","License"]

examQuestions.questionText: An owner's title insurance policy protects:
examQuestions.explanation: An owner's policy protects the buyer/owner against title defects. A separate lender's policy protects the mortgage lender.
examQuestions.options: ["The lender","The buyer/owner","The seller","The title company"]

examQuestions.questionText: An encumbrance that affects the physical condition of the property is a:
examQuestions.explanation: Easements are encumbrances that affect the physical use of property by granting rights to others.
examQuestions.options: ["Lien","Deed restriction","Easement","License"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which deed is commonly used to clear a cloud on title?
examQuestions.explanation: Quitclaim deeds are often used to clear clouds on title because they release any interest a person may have without making warranties.
examQuestions.options: ["General warranty deed","Special warranty deed","Quitclaim deed","Bargain and sale deed"]

examQuestions.options: ["mixes escrow funds with personal or business funds","deposits escrow funds in a title company","places a sign on a property without permission","pays commission to a cooperating broker"]

examQuestions.options: ["a minor administrative infraction only","a criminal offense and a violation of license law","allowed if supervised by a broker","permitted for out of state brokers"]

examQuestions.questionText: A formal hearing is conducted by

examQuestions.questionText: Which of the following is a possible administrative penalty that FREC may impose
examQuestions.options: ["incarceration","probation","revocation followed by imprisonment","only a warning, never suspension"]

examQuestions.questionText: The Real Estate Recovery Fund is designed to
examQuestions.options: ["pay commissions to cooperating brokers","reimburse licensees for business losses","reimburse members of the public who suffer monetary damages because of licensee misconduct in certain situations","pay advertising expenses for the Commission"]

examQuestions.options: ["file a complaint with the MLS","obtain a civil judgment and show that collection was attempted and failed","request an informal hearing","apply to the local association of Realtors"]

examQuestions.options: ["Failing to complete continuing education on time one time","Minor record keeping errors","Conversion of escrow funds and serious fraud","Failure to return a phone call"]

examQuestions.options: ["promotion of the licensee","automatic suspension of the license until the Fund is repaid","no effect on the licensee's status","automatic renewal of the license"]

examQuestions.questionText: In the rectangular survey system, a township contains how many square miles?
examQuestions.explanation: A township is 6 miles by 6 miles, containing 36 square miles or 36 sections.

examQuestions.questionText: One section of land contains how many acres?
examQuestions.explanation: One section equals one square mile, which contains 640 acres.

examQuestions.questionText: In the rectangular survey system, principal meridians run:
examQuestions.explanation: Principal meridians run north to south, while base lines run east to west.
examQuestions.options: ["East to west","North to south","Diagonally","In circles"]

examQuestions.explanation: The lot and block (recorded plat) method refers to a recorded plat map that shows lot boundaries within a subdivision.
examQuestions.options: ["Metes and bounds","Rectangular survey","Lot and block","Government survey"]

examQuestions.questionText: The term 'metes' refers to:
examQuestions.explanation: Metes refers to distance and direction measurements, while bounds refers to fixed objects or monuments.
examQuestions.options: ["Corners and monuments","Distance and direction","Boundaries only","Lot numbers"]

examQuestions.questionText: A monument used in a legal description could be:

examQuestions.options: ["A tree or rock","An iron stake","A street intersection","All of the above"]

examQuestions.questionText: How many acres are in the NE 1/4 of the SE 1/4 of a section?

examQuestions.options: ["10 acres","20 acres","40 acres","80 acres"]

examQuestions.questionText: Range lines in the rectangular survey system run:
examQuestions.explanation: Range lines run north to south, parallel to principal meridians, creating columns of townships.
examQuestions.options: ["East to west","North to south","Parallel to base lines","Through townships only"]

examQuestions.questionText: The rectangular survey system is also known as the:
examQuestions.explanation: The rectangular survey system is also called the government survey system, established by the federal government.
examQuestions.options: ["Metes and bounds system","Lot and block system","Government survey system","Plat system"]

examQuestions.questionText: Township lines run:
examQuestions.explanation: Township lines run east to west, parallel to base lines, creating rows of townships.
examQuestions.options: ["North to south","East to west","Diagonally","Parallel to meridians"]

examQuestions.options: ["A zoning map","A long-range guide for community development","A building permit","A subdivision plat"]

examQuestions.options: ["FHA loans only","VA loans only","conventional loans","construction loans"]

examQuestions.options: ["all monthly obligations to gross monthly income","only mortgage interest to income","housing payment plus down payment","interest rate to principal"]

examQuestions.questionText: A fully amortized mortgage

examQuestions.questionText: VA loans are:

examQuestions.options: ["Insured by VA","Guaranteed by VA","Made by VA directly","Only for first-time buyers"]

examQuestions.questionText: Conventional loans are those that are:

examQuestions.questionText: A balloon mortgage has:

examQuestions.options: ["Fully amortized payments","A large final payment","No interest charges","Variable payments only"]

examQuestions.questionText: An adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) has:

examQuestions.options: ["A fixed interest rate","An interest rate that can change","No principal payments","Government guarantees"]

examQuestions.questionText: The secondary mortgage market is where:

examQuestions.questionText: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac operate in the:
examQuestions.explanation: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are government-sponsored enterprises that buy mortgages in the secondary market.
examQuestions.options: ["Primary market","Secondary market","Title insurance industry","Appraisal industry"]

examQuestions.questionText: A purchase money mortgage is one where:
examQuestions.explanation: A purchase money mortgage is seller financing where the seller takes back a mortgage as part of the purchase price.
examQuestions.options: ["The buyer pays cash","The seller provides financing","The bank provides all funds","No down payment is required"]

examQuestions.questionText: For a contract to be valid, there must be:
examQuestions.explanation: Mutual assent (meeting of the minds through offer and acceptance) is essential for a valid contract.
examQuestions.options: ["Recording","Notarization","Mutual assent (offer and acceptance)","A real estate license"]

examQuestions.questionText: Consideration in a contract means:
examQuestions.explanation: Consideration is something of value given by each party, which can be money, property, services, or a promise.
examQuestions.options: ["Thoughtful negotiation","Something of value exchanged","Legal capacity","Written terms"]

examQuestions.questionText: A voidable contract is:
examQuestions.explanation: A voidable contract is valid but may be rescinded by one party due to circumstances like duress, fraud, or minority.
examQuestions.options: ["Valid but can be rescinded by one party","Never enforceable","Always illegal","Void from the beginning"]

examQuestions.questionText: A bilateral contract is one in which:
examQuestions.explanation: In a bilateral contract, both parties exchange promises to perform, creating mutual obligations.
examQuestions.options: ["Only one party makes a promise","Both parties make promises","No promises are made","The contract is optional"]

examQuestions.questionText: An option contract is considered:
examQuestions.explanation: An option is unilateral because only the optionor (seller) is obligated; the optionee (buyer) has a right but no obligation.
examQuestions.options: ["A bilateral contract","A unilateral contract","A void contract","An executory contract only"]

examQuestions.questionText: Liquidated damages in a real estate contract typically refers to:
examQuestions.explanation: Liquidated damages are pre-agreed damages, often allowing the seller to keep the earnest money if the buyer defaults.
examQuestions.options: ["Seller keeping earnest money","Court-ordered damages","Specific performance","Rescission"]

examQuestions.questionText: The time limit to bring a legal action is governed by the:
examQuestions.explanation: The Statute of Limitations sets the time period within which a lawsuit must be filed.
examQuestions.options: ["Statute of Frauds","Statute of Limitations","Statute of Uses","Recording act"]

examQuestions.questionText: A contract made by a minor is generally:
examQuestions.explanation: Contracts made by minors are voidable at the minor's option because they lack full legal capacity.
examQuestions.options: ["Void","Voidable by the minor","Always enforceable","Illegal"]

examQuestions.questionText: An assignment of a contract transfers:
examQuestions.explanation: An assignment transfers the assignor's rights under the contract to the assignee.
examQuestions.options: ["Ownership of property","Rights under the contract","Duties only","Nothing"]

examQuestions.questionText: The Statute of Frauds requires contracts for the sale of real estate to be:
examQuestions.explanation: The Statute of Frauds requires real estate contracts to be in writing to be enforceable.
examQuestions.options: ["Recorded","Notarized","In writing","Witnessed"]

examQuestions.questionText: An executory contract is one that:
examQuestions.explanation: An executory contract has obligations remaining to be performed by one or both parties.
examQuestions.options: ["Has been fully performed","Has not yet been performed","Is void","Is illegal"]

examQuestions.questionText: The remedy of specific performance is most commonly used for:
examQuestions.explanation: Specific performance is used for real estate contracts because each property is unique and monetary damages are inadequate.
examQuestions.options: ["Personal service contracts","Real estate contracts","Employment contracts","Rental agreements"]

examQuestions.questionText: Novation occurs when:
examQuestions.explanation: Novation substitutes a new party for an original party, releasing the original party from obligations.
examQuestions.options: ["A contract is voided","A new party replaces an original party","Terms are modified","A contract is recorded"]

examQuestions.questionText: A counteroffer:
examQuestions.explanation: A counteroffer rejects the original offer and creates a new offer that the original offeror may accept or reject.
examQuestions.options: ["Accepts the original offer","Rejects and replaces the original offer","Keeps the original offer open","Is always illegal"]

examQuestions.questionText: The parol evidence rule prevents:
examQuestions.explanation: The parol evidence rule prevents parties from introducing oral evidence that contradicts a written contract.
examQuestions.options: ["Oral testimony to contradict written contracts","Written modifications","Recording of contracts","Consideration requirements"]

examQuestions.questionText: Earnest money is also known as:
examQuestions.explanation: Earnest money is a good faith deposit showing the buyer's serious intent to complete the purchase.
examQuestions.options: ["Option money","Good faith deposit","Down payment","Closing costs"]

examQuestions.questionText: The document that creates a lien on real property as security for a debt is the:
examQuestions.explanation: The mortgage creates a lien on the property as security for the loan evidenced by the promissory note.
examQuestions.options: ["Promissory note","Mortgage","Deed","Title insurance policy"]

examQuestions.questionText: The mortgagor is the:
examQuestions.explanation: The mortgagor is the borrower who gives the mortgage as security for the loan.
examQuestions.options: ["Lender","Borrower","Trustee","Title company"]

examQuestions.questionText: The due-on-sale clause prevents:
examQuestions.explanation: The due-on-sale (alienation) clause requires full payment or lender approval if the property is sold.
examQuestions.options: ["Early payoff","Loan assumption without lender approval","Recording of the mortgage","Interest rate changes"]

examQuestions.questionText: The loan-to-value ratio (LTV) compares:
examQuestions.explanation: LTV ratio is the loan amount divided by the property's appraised value, expressed as a percentage.
examQuestions.options: ["Loan amount to purchase price","Loan amount to appraised value","Down payment to loan","Interest to principal"]

examQuestions.questionText: The process of gradually paying off a loan through regular payments is called:
examQuestions.explanation: Amortization is the gradual repayment of a loan through scheduled periodic payments of principal and interest.
examQuestions.options: ["Acceleration","Amortization","Subordination","Novation"]

examQuestions.questionText: The borrower's personal promise to repay a loan is evidenced by the:
examQuestions.explanation: The promissory note is the borrower's written promise to repay the debt according to specified terms.
examQuestions.options: ["Mortgage","Promissory note","Deed of trust","Title policy"]

examQuestions.questionText: The clause that allows a lender to demand full payment upon default is the:
examQuestions.explanation: The acceleration clause allows the lender to declare the entire loan balance due immediately upon default.
examQuestions.options: ["Due-on-sale clause","Acceleration clause","Prepayment clause","Subordination clause"]

examQuestions.questionText: Equity in a property is calculated as:
examQuestions.explanation: Equity equals the property's market value minus any outstanding mortgage balance or liens.
examQuestions.options: ["Market value plus debt","Market value minus debt","Purchase price only","Loan balance only"]

examQuestions.questionText: A deficiency judgment may be obtained when:
examQuestions.explanation: If the foreclosure sale proceeds don't cover the debt, the lender may seek a deficiency judgment for the remaining balance.
examQuestions.options: ["The borrower pays off early","The foreclosure sale proceeds are less than the debt owed","The property appreciates","The interest rate changes"]

examQuestions.questionText: The main purpose of the Florida Real Estate Commission is to
examQuestions.options: ["promote the real estate industry","protect the public","regulate mortgage lenders","increase commission rates"]

examQuestions.questionText: How many FREC members must be consumer members
examQuestions.options: ["one","two","three","four"]

examQuestions.questionText: FREC's quasi-legislative powers allow the Commission to
examQuestions.options: ["issue criminal penalties","adopt rules","conduct ministerial tasks only","prosecute licensees"]

examQuestions.questionText: Ministerial powers of FREC include
examQuestions.options: ["adopting rules","imposing fines","maintaining records and certifying licenses","conducting hearings"]

examQuestions.questionText: How often must FREC meet at minimum
examQuestions.options: ["weekly","monthly","quarterly","annually"]

examQuestions.questionText: Prima facie evidence means
examQuestions.options: ["evidence obtained through investigation","evidence that is presumed true on its face unless rebutted","evidence from witness testimony only","evidence from criminal courts"]

examQuestions.questionText: If a licensee fails to renew on time, the license becomes
examQuestions.options: ["null and void","involuntarily inactive","suspended","revoked"]

examQuestions.questionText: Continuing education for renewal must be completed
examQuestions.options: ["only for the first renewal","for every renewal after the first","only by brokers","only for sales associates"]

examQuestions.questionText: Rule Chapter 61J2 contains
examQuestions.options: ["Florida criminal law","detailed rules adopted by FREC","federal fair housing guidelines","mortgage lending regulations"]

examQuestions.questionText: The 28-hour reactivation course is required when
examQuestions.options: ["a license has been involuntarily inactive for too long","a broker wants to become a sales associate","continuing education was completed on time","applying for initial licensure"]

examQuestions.questionText: FREC may impose which of the following penalties
examQuestions.options: ["criminal imprisonment","reprimand, fine, probation, suspension, or revocation","only fines","only license revocation"]

examQuestions.questionText: A current, valid real estate license issued by DBPR is prima facie evidence that
examQuestions.options: ["the licensee has never been disciplined","the licensee is properly licensed","the licensee owns property","the licensee has completed continuing education"]

examQuestions.questionText: How many members sit on the Florida Real Estate Commission
examQuestions.options: ["five","six","seven","nine"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which FREC members must have at least five years of active broker experience
examQuestions.options: ["all licensed members","two members","four members","one member"]

examQuestions.questionText: FREC's quasi-judicial powers include
examQuestions.options: ["appointing DBPR staff","issuing administrative discipline","establishing real estate laws","preparing state exams"]

examQuestions.questionText: FREC members are appointed by the
examQuestions.options: ["Florida House of Representatives","DBPR Secretary","Governor and confirmed by the Senate","Division of Real Estate"]

examQuestions.questionText: A summary suspension may be issued when a licensee
examQuestions.options: ["fails to complete continuing education","poses an immediate, serious danger to the public","makes a minor advertising error","changes brokers without notice"]

examQuestions.questionText: A Florida real estate license must be renewed every
examQuestions.options: ["one year","two years","three years","four years"]

examQuestions.questionText: A license that becomes null and void
examQuestions.options: ["may be renewed with a late fee","no longer exists and must be reapplied for","is automatically reinstated after 6 months","may be reactivated with continuing education"]

examQuestions.questionText: A sales associate may work for
examQuestions.options: ["any number of brokers at the same time","only one employer at a time","up to three brokers simultaneously","any broker who will pay them"]

examQuestions.questionText: In Florida, unless a single agent or no brokerage relationship is established in writing in a residential sale, a licensee is presumed to be
examQuestions.explanation: Florida law presumes transaction brokerage unless a single agent or no brokerage relationship is established in writing.
examQuestions.options: ["A. a dual agent","B. a transaction broker","C. a single agent","D. a designated sales associate"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which brokerage relationship creates a fiduciary relationship with a principal
examQuestions.explanation: A single agent relationship creates a fiduciary relationship with a principal, with full fiduciary duties.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Transaction broker","B. Single agent","C. No brokerage relationship","D. Designated agency"]

examQuestions.questionText: Dual agency in Florida residential sales is
examQuestions.explanation: Dual agency is prohibited in Florida residential transactions.
examQuestions.options: ["A. permitted only if disclosed","B. permitted if both parties consent in writing","C. prohibited","D. required in all listings"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which duty is owed by a single agent but NOT by a transaction broker
examQuestions.explanation: Loyalty is a fiduciary duty owed by single agents but not by transaction brokers.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Accounting for all funds","B. Dealing honestly and fairly","C. Loyalty","D. Disclosing known material facts"]

examQuestions.questionText: In a no brokerage relationship with a residential seller, a licensee owes
examQuestions.explanation: Even with no brokerage relationship, limited duties include dealing honestly and fairly, and accounting for funds.
examQuestions.options: ["A. loyalty and obedience","B. limited confidentiality","C. dealing honestly and fairly and accounting for all funds","D. no duties since there is no representation"]

examQuestions.questionText: The Single Agent Notice must be given
examQuestions.explanation: The Single Agent Notice must be given in writing before or at the time of entering into an agreement or before showing property.
examQuestions.options: ["A. at closing","B. before or at the time of entering into a listing or representation agreement or before showing property","C. after the first offer is presented","D. only if the customer requests it"]

examQuestions.questionText: Limited confidentiality is a characteristic of which brokerage relationship
examQuestions.explanation: Transaction brokers owe limited confidentiality, meaning they cannot disclose information that would harm negotiations.
examQuestions.options: ["A. No brokerage relationship","B. Single agent","C. Transaction broker","D. Designated agency"]

examQuestions.questionText: The No Brokerage Relationship Notice is required in
examQuestions.explanation: The No Brokerage Relationship Notice must be provided in writing before showing property in covered residential transactions.
examQuestions.options: ["A. all real estate transactions","B. all commercial transactions only","C. certain residential transactions when the licensee has no brokerage relationship with a buyer or seller","D. leases only"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which statement about residential sales disclosure requirements is correct
examQuestions.explanation: Disclosure requirements apply to residential property of four or fewer units, unimproved residential property, and agricultural property of ten acres or less.
examQuestions.options: ["A. They apply to all commercial transactions","B. They apply only when more than four residential units are involved","C. They apply to sales of four or fewer residential units, certain residential vacant land, and agricultural property of ten acres or less","D. They apply to leases of any length"]

examQuestions.questionText: A transaction broker owes a buyer all of the following duties EXCEPT
examQuestions.explanation: Loyalty is a fiduciary duty that transaction brokers do not owe to either party.
examQuestions.options: ["A. loyalty","B. accounting for all funds","C. using skill, care, and diligence","D. disclosing known material defects"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which disclosure must be obtained before a single agent may change to a transaction broker relationship
examQuestions.explanation: The Consent to Transition to Transaction Broker must be signed in writing before changing from single agent to transaction broker.
examQuestions.options: ["A. No Brokerage Relationship Notice","B. Consent to Transition to Transaction Broker","C. Designated Agency Consent","D. Transaction Broker Notice for Residential Sales"]

examQuestions.questionText: A transaction broker is best described as
examQuestions.explanation: A transaction broker provides limited representation to one or more parties without fiduciary duties.
examQuestions.options: ["A. a fiduciary for both buyer and seller","B. a limited representative for one or more parties in a transaction","C. a government agent","D. a principal in the transaction"]

examQuestions.questionText: In which situation are relationship disclosures NOT required
examQuestions.explanation: Relationship disclosures are not required in unanticipated casual conversations that do not involve confidential information.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Sale of a single family home","B. Sale of a duplex","C. Unanticipated casual conversations that do not involve confidential information","D. Sale of a four unit residential building"]

examQuestions.questionText: A broker may designate sales associates to act as single agents for different customers in the same transaction when
examQuestions.explanation: Designated sales associates are only permitted in nonresidential transactions where both parties have assets of one million dollars or more.
examQuestions.options: ["A. the transaction is a residential sale of four or fewer units","B. both buyer and seller have assets of one million dollars or more and the transaction is nonresidential","C. the broker has written approval from FREC","D. both customers waive their rights to confidentiality"]

examQuestions.questionText: Designated sales associates must
examQuestions.explanation: Designated sales associates follow all single agent duties, including loyalty and confidentiality to their respective clients.
examQuestions.options: ["A. follow the duties of a transaction broker","B. act as dual agents for both parties","C. follow all single agent duties including loyalty and confidentiality","D. provide no disclosures"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which of the following is a duty that applies to ALL three authorized brokerage relationships in a residential transaction
examQuestions.explanation: Dealing honestly and fairly is a duty owed in all three authorized brokerage relationships.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Loyalty","B. Obedience","C. Limited confidentiality","D. Dealing honestly and fairly"]

examQuestions.questionText: The law that lists authorized brokerage relationships and required disclosures is found primarily in
examQuestions.explanation: Chapter 475.278, Florida Statutes, establishes authorized brokerage relationships and disclosure requirements.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Chapter 475.278, Florida Statutes","B. Chapter 455, Florida Statutes","C. Chapter 61J2, Florida Administrative Code","D. Chapter 713, Florida Statutes"]

examQuestions.questionText: A buyer tells a transaction broker the highest price they are willing to pay. The broker may disclose this information to the seller only
examQuestions.explanation: Limited confidentiality means a transaction broker cannot disclose negotiation information without written permission or legal requirement.
examQuestions.options: ["A. if the buyer gives written permission or disclosure is required by law","B. if it helps get the deal closed","C. if the seller is also a customer of the brokerage","D. under no circumstances"]

examQuestions.questionText: A licensee who has no brokerage relationship with a seller must still
examQuestions.explanation: Even with no brokerage relationship, licensees must deal honestly and fairly and disclose known material defects.
examQuestions.options: ["A. provide loyalty and obedience","B. provide full disclosure of negotiation strategies","C. deal honestly and fairly and disclose known material defects","D. place the seller's interests above all others"]

examQuestions.questionText: In a designated sales associate transaction, the broker must
examQuestions.explanation: In a designated sales associate arrangement, the broker must keep confidential information from each side and not use it to harm either party.
examQuestions.options: ["A. keep confidential information from each side and not use it to the detriment of the other party","B. share all confidential information with both parties","C. act as a dual agent","D. personally represent the party with the higher offer"]

examQuestions.questionText: Assessed value is
examQuestions.options: ["the same as market value","market value minus adjustments","always lower than taxable value","determined by the federal government"]

examQuestions.questionText: The second twenty five thousand dollars of homestead exemption
examQuestions.options: ["applies only to school taxes","applies to non school taxes","applies to federal income tax","applies only when selling"]

examQuestions.questionText: Property taxes equal
examQuestions.options: ["assessed value times land value","taxable value times millage rate","market value times two mills","loan amount times mill rate"]

examQuestions.questionText: Investors may deduct
examQuestions.options: ["principal payments","depreciation","personal expenses","homeowner association fines"]

examQuestions.questionText: Residential rental property is depreciated over
examQuestions.options: ["fifteen years","twenty seven and a half years","thirty nine years","five years"]

examQuestions.questionText: Adjusted basis equals
examQuestions.options: ["purchase price plus improvements minus depreciation","loan amount minus taxes","market value minus land","cash flow minus debt service"]

examQuestions.questionText: A 1031 exchange
examQuestions.options: ["eliminates tax permanently","defers tax on investment property","applies to primary residences","cannot involve real estate"]

examQuestions.questionText: Property taxes in Florida are
examQuestions.options: ["paid monthly","paid in arrears","paid in advance","paid by tenants"]

examQuestions.questionText: Depreciable basis equals
examQuestions.options: ["loan amount minus land","purchase price minus land plus improvements","property taxes minus depreciation","loan interest plus principal"]

examQuestions.questionText: Ad valorem means
examQuestions.options: ["age based","value based","location based","income based"]

examQuestions.questionText: The Florida homestead exemption can be up to
examQuestions.options: ["ten thousand dollars","twenty five thousand dollars","fifty thousand dollars","one hundred thousand dollars"]

examQuestions.questionText: Millage is expressed as
examQuestions.options: ["cents per dollar","dollars per hundred","dollars per thousand dollars of value","percentage of purchase price"]

examQuestions.questionText: Homeowners may deduct
examQuestions.options: ["repairs","improvements","depreciation","mortgage interest and property taxes"]

examQuestions.questionText: Land
examQuestions.options: ["can be depreciated","cannot be depreciated","is depreciated over forty years","is expensed"]

examQuestions.questionText: Capital gain equals
examQuestions.options: ["selling price minus closing costs","selling price minus loan balance","selling price minus adjusted basis","selling price minus depreciation"]

examQuestions.questionText: Homeowners may exclude capital gains up to
examQuestions.options: ["fifty thousand dollars","one hundred thousand dollars","two hundred fifty thousand or five hundred thousand if married","unlimited amount"]

examQuestions.questionText: Save Our Homes limits annual assessed value increases to
examQuestions.options: ["ten percent","five percent","three percent or the increase in CPI","the millage rate"]

examQuestions.questionText: The taxable value of a homesteaded property equals
examQuestions.options: ["market value minus land","assessed value minus exemptions","selling price minus mortgage","market value minus closing costs"]

examQuestions.questionText: An item that is not deductible on a primary residence is
examQuestions.options: ["mortgage interest","property taxes","repairs","points on a new loan"]

examQuestions.questionText: The purpose of depreciation is
examQuestions.options: ["to reduce property taxes","to recover the cost of improvements over time","to calculate market value","to determine millage"]

examQuestions.questionText: Ad valorem taxes are based on:
examQuestions.explanation: Ad valorem means 'according to value' - these property taxes are based on assessed property value.
examQuestions.options: ["Income earned","Property value","Number of rooms","Age of property"]

examQuestions.questionText: One mill equals:
examQuestions.explanation: One mill equals 1/10 of a cent, or $1 per $1,000 of assessed value.

examQuestions.questionText: The Florida homestead exemption can reduce taxable value by up to:
examQuestions.explanation: Florida homestead exemption provides up to $50,000 exemption ($25,000 on all taxes, $25,000 additional on non-school taxes).

examQuestions.questionText: Special assessments are levied for:
examQuestions.explanation: Special assessments pay for specific local improvements like sidewalks, sewers, or street lighting.
examQuestions.options: ["General government operations","Specific local improvements","Federal taxes","Income tax purposes"]

examQuestions.questionText: A tax lien takes priority over:
examQuestions.explanation: Property tax liens generally take priority over most other liens, including mortgages.
examQuestions.options: ["Nothing","Most other liens","Only mortgages","Only judgments"]

examQuestions.questionText: The Save Our Homes (SOH) amendment limits annual increases in assessed value to:
examQuestions.explanation: Save Our Homes caps annual assessment increases at 3% or the Consumer Price Index, whichever is lower.
examQuestions.options: ["5% or CPI","3% or CPI, whichever is lower","10%","No limit"]

examQuestions.questionText: Property taxes become a lien on:
examQuestions.explanation: Property tax liens attach on January 1 of the tax year, even before tax bills are sent.
examQuestions.options: ["December 31 of the prior year","January 1 of the tax year","When the tax bill is mailed","When taxes become delinquent"]

examQuestions.questionText: Capital gains tax applies to:
examQuestions.explanation: Capital gains tax is levied on profit realized from the sale of capital assets like real estate.
examQuestions.options: ["Rental income","Profit from selling property","Property taxes paid","Mortgage interest"]

examQuestions.questionText: Documentary stamp tax in Florida is paid by:
examQuestions.explanation: In Florida, documentary stamp tax on deeds is customarily paid by the seller.
examQuestions.options: ["The buyer only","The seller typically","The lender","The title company"]

examQuestions.questionText: Intangible tax applies to:
examQuestions.explanation: Florida intangible tax is a one-time tax on new mortgages, paid when the mortgage is recorded.
examQuestions.options: ["Deeds only","New mortgages","Property tax bills","Title insurance"]

examQuestions.questionText: Taxable value equals:
examQuestions.explanation: Taxable value is assessed value minus any applicable exemptions like homestead.
examQuestions.options: ["Market value","Assessed value minus exemptions","Just value only","Purchase price"]

examQuestions.questionText: A buyer's market occurs when:
examQuestions.explanation: A buyer's market exists when supply exceeds demand, giving buyers more negotiating power.
examQuestions.options: ["Supply exceeds demand","Demand exceeds supply","Supply equals demand","There are no buyers"]

examQuestions.questionText: A Comparative Market Analysis (CMA) is used to:
examQuestions.explanation: A CMA compares similar recently sold properties to help estimate a property's market value or listing price.
examQuestions.options: ["Determine property taxes","Estimate property value using comparable sales","Calculate mortgage payments","Appraise for lending purposes"]

examQuestions.questionText: Economic factors affecting real estate values include:
examQuestions.explanation: Employment, interest rates, and population growth all significantly impact real estate demand and values.
examQuestions.options: ["Employment rates","Interest rates","Population growth","All of the above"]

examQuestions.questionText: Market value assumes:
examQuestions.explanation: Market value assumes willing, informed buyers and sellers with reasonable market exposure and no undue pressure.
examQuestions.options: ["A distressed sale","A willing buyer and seller","No exposure to market","Forced sale conditions"]

examQuestions.questionText: When supply of homes increases and demand stays the same, prices tend to:
examQuestions.explanation: According to supply and demand principles, increased supply with stable demand leads to lower prices.
examQuestions.options: ["Increase","Decrease","Stay the same","Double"]

examQuestions.questionText: A seller's market occurs when:
examQuestions.explanation: A seller's market exists when demand exceeds supply, allowing sellers to command higher prices.
examQuestions.options: ["Supply exceeds demand","Demand exceeds supply","Supply equals demand","There are no sellers"]

examQuestions.questionText: Absorption rate measures:
examQuestions.explanation: Absorption rate measures how quickly available inventory sells in a market, indicating market conditions.
examQuestions.options: ["Loan payoff speed","Rate at which available properties sell","Interest accumulation","Population growth"]

examQuestions.questionText: Appreciation refers to:
examQuestions.explanation: Appreciation is an increase in property value over time due to market conditions or improvements.
examQuestions.options: ["Decrease in property value","Increase in property value","Stable property value","Tax assessment changes"]

examQuestions.questionText: In a balanced market:
examQuestions.explanation: A balanced market has roughly equal supply and demand, with neither buyers nor sellers having a significant advantage.
examQuestions.options: ["Supply greatly exceeds demand","Demand greatly exceeds supply","Supply roughly equals demand","There are no transactions"]

examQuestions.questionText: Market trends can be identified by analyzing:
examQuestions.explanation: Market trend analysis uses multiple data points including sales history, inventory, and pricing patterns.
examQuestions.options: ["Sales data over time","Listing inventory levels","Price changes","All of the above"]

examQuestions.questionText: Days on market (DOM) indicates:
examQuestions.explanation: Days on market measures how long a property has been actively listed for sale.
examQuestions.options: ["Construction time","How long a property has been listed for sale","Loan processing time","Inspection period"]

examQuestions.questionText: Location is important to value because:
examQuestions.explanation: Location is crucial because it's fixed and significantly impacts property desirability, utility, and value.
examQuestions.options: ["It cannot be changed","It affects desirability and utility","Both A and B","Neither A nor B"]

examQuestions.questionText: A broker license requires how many months as a sales associate?
examQuestions.explanation: To qualify for a Florida broker license, an applicant must have been actively licensed as a sales associate for at least 24 months within the preceding 5 years.

examQuestions.questionText: The Florida broker pre-licensing education requirement is:
examQuestions.explanation: The Florida broker pre-licensing course (FREC Course II) is 72 hours.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 45 hours","B. 63 hours","C. 72 hours","D. 84 hours"]

examQuestions.questionText: Continuing education for Florida brokers requires how many hours per renewal cycle?
examQuestions.explanation: Florida real estate brokers must complete 14 hours of continuing education every two years.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 10 hours","B. 14 hours","C. 21 hours","D. 28 hours"]

examQuestions.questionText: Self-reporting of criminal convictions to DBPR must occur within:
examQuestions.explanation: Licensed brokers must self-report criminal convictions within 30 days.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 10 days","B. 30 days","C. 60 days","D. 90 days"]

examQuestions.questionText: Mutual recognition agreements allow:
examQuestions.explanation: Mutual recognition agreements provide waiver of pre-license education and experience requirements, but still require completing a Florida law course and passing the Florida exam.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Automatic licensure","B. Waiver of pre-license education","C. No examination required","D. No background check"]

examQuestions.questionText: Post-licensing education for new brokers consists of:
examQuestions.explanation: New brokers must complete 60 hours of post-licensing education.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 30 hours","B. 45 hours","C. 60 hours","D. 72 hours"]

examQuestions.questionText: A newly licensed broker must complete post-licensing education:
examQuestions.explanation: Newly licensed brokers must complete 60 hours of post-licensing education before their first license renewal.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Within 6 months","B. Within the first year","C. Before the first license renewal","D. Within 60 days"]

examQuestions.questionText: The mandatory core law portion of continuing education is:
examQuestions.explanation: The core law requirement is 3 hours of the 14 total CE hours required.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 3 hours","B. 4 hours","C. 7 hours","D. 14 hours"]

examQuestions.questionText: A Florida resident for licensing purposes has resided in Florida for:
examQuestions.explanation: A person is considered a Florida resident for licensing purposes if they have resided in Florida for at least 4 consecutive months.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 2 consecutive months","B. 4 consecutive months","C. 6 consecutive months","D. 12 consecutive months"]

examQuestions.questionText: The broker license examination passing score is:
examQuestions.explanation: The passing score for the Florida broker license examination is 75% (75 correct answers out of 100).

examQuestions.questionText: If an applicant fails to disclose a criminal conviction on the application:
examQuestions.explanation: Failure to disclose required information on the application constitutes grounds for denial or disciplinary action.
examQuestions.options: ["A. The application is approved with conditions","B. It constitutes grounds for denial","C. A warning is issued","D. No consequences"]

examQuestions.questionText: Course completion certificates are valid for:
examQuestions.explanation: Course completion certificates are valid for two years from the completion date.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 1 year","B. 2 years","C. 3 years","D. 5 years"]

examQuestions.questionText: Active military personnel stationed in Florida may receive:
examQuestions.explanation: Active duty military members stationed in Florida may receive fee waivers for license applications.
examQuestions.options: ["A. License fee waivers","B. Education exemptions","C. Examination waivers","D. All of the above"]

examQuestions.questionText: The attorney exception for broker pre-license education requires:
examQuestions.explanation: Active members of The Florida Bar must have practiced law in Florida for at least five years to qualify for the attorney exception.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 2 years Florida practice","B. 5 years Florida practice","C. 10 years Florida practice","D. Any Florida Bar membership"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which is NOT a state with mutual recognition with Florida?
examQuestions.explanation: California does not have a mutual recognition agreement with Florida. Florida has mutual recognition with states like Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, and others.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Georgia","B. Alabama","C. California","D. Arkansas"]

examQuestions.questionText: Closing in a real estate transaction refers to:
examQuestions.explanation: Closing is the final step where ownership transfers from seller to buyer and all funds are disbursed.
examQuestions.options: ["The initial contract signing","The point where title transfers and funds are disbursed","The property inspection","The loan application"]

examQuestions.questionText: In Florida, who typically serves as the closing agent?
examQuestions.explanation: Florida is considered an 'attorney state' where attorneys or title companies under attorney supervision conduct closings.
examQuestions.options: ["The real estate agent only","An attorney or title company","The mortgage broker","The property appraiser"]

examQuestions.questionText: RESPA was enacted primarily to:
examQuestions.explanation: RESPA protects consumers by requiring timely disclosures about settlement costs and prohibiting kickbacks.
examQuestions.options: ["Regulate interest rates","Protect consumers in the home buying process","Set property tax rates","License real estate agents"]

examQuestions.questionText: Under RESPA Section 8, which is prohibited?
examQuestions.explanation: RESPA Section 8 prohibits giving or receiving anything of value for referrals of settlement service business.
examQuestions.options: ["Payments for actual services rendered","Kickbacks for referrals of settlement services","Cooperative brokerage arrangements","Affiliated Business Arrangements with proper disclosure"]

examQuestions.questionText: Under TRID, the Loan Estimate must be provided within:
examQuestions.explanation: Lenders must provide the Loan Estimate within 3 business days of receiving a loan application.
examQuestions.options: ["24 hours of application","3 business days of application","7 business days of application","At closing only"]

examQuestions.questionText: The Closing Disclosure must be received by the borrower at least:
examQuestions.explanation: The 3-day rule requires borrowers receive the Closing Disclosure at least 3 business days before closing.
examQuestions.options: ["24 hours before closing","3 business days before closing","7 business days before closing","At the closing table"]

examQuestions.questionText: A proration is best described as:
examQuestions.explanation: Prorations divide expenses fairly between buyer and seller based on the closing date.
examQuestions.options: ["A commission split between agents","Division of ongoing expenses between buyer and seller","A discount on closing costs","A type of mortgage payment"]

examQuestions.questionText: In Florida, property taxes are paid:
examQuestions.explanation: Florida property taxes are paid in arrears, covering the prior year's taxes.
examQuestions.options: ["In advance for the coming year","In arrears for the prior year","Monthly with mortgage payments","At the time of purchase only"]

examQuestions.questionText: Accrued items at closing are:
examQuestions.explanation: Accrued items (expenses incurred but not yet paid) are credited to the buyer who will pay them later.
examQuestions.options: ["Credited to the seller","Credited to the buyer","Paid by the lender","Not included on the settlement statement"]

examQuestions.questionText: Documentary stamp tax on a deed in Florida (outside Miami-Dade) is:
examQuestions.explanation: The standard Florida documentary stamp tax rate on deeds is $0.70 per $100 of consideration.

examQuestions.questionText: Documentary stamps on the deed are typically paid by the:
examQuestions.explanation: In Florida custom, documentary stamps on the deed are typically paid by the seller.
examQuestions.options: ["Buyer","Seller","Lender","Title company"]

examQuestions.questionText: The intangible tax on a new mortgage in Florida is:
examQuestions.explanation: Florida's intangible tax is $2.00 per $1,000 of new mortgage (equal to 2 mills or $0.002 per dollar).

examQuestions.questionText: Title insurance protects against:
examQuestions.explanation: Title insurance protects against existing but undiscovered defects in title that occurred before the policy date.
examQuestions.options: ["Future events only","Past defects in title","Property damage","Mortgage default"]

examQuestions.questionText: An owner's title insurance policy:
examQuestions.explanation: The owner's policy protects the buyer/owner's equity and coverage equals the purchase price.
examQuestions.options: ["Decreases as the loan is paid","Protects the lender","Protects the buyer's equity","Is never needed"]

examQuestions.questionText: For a $400,000 sale, documentary stamps on the deed equal:
examQuestions.explanation: $400,000 / 100 = 4,000 units x $0.70 = $2,800 documentary stamps on deed.

examQuestions.questionText:
Pre-license education b. Florida law course c. Experience requirement d. Background check

How many hours of broker pre-license education are required in Florida?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 45 hours","B. 63 hours","C. 72 hours","D. 90 hours"]

examQuestions.questionText: What is the passing score for the Florida broker license examination?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.

examQuestions.questionText: Which statement about the broker examination is TRUE?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Reference materials are allowed during the test","B. Results are mailed within 10 business days","C. The exam is given only at DBPR offices","D. Candidates may challenge defective questions"]

examQuestions.questionText:
Active status only b. Active or voluntary inactive status c. Any status as long as registered with a broker d. Active, inactive, or null and void status

The broker license examination consists of how many questions?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 75 questions","B. 100 questions","C. 120 questions","D. 150 questions"]

examQuestions.questionText: An applicant's authorization to test (ATT) is valid for how long after completing the broker pre-license course?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Six months","B. One year","C. Two years","D. Five years"]

examQuestions.questionText:
Instructions: Select the best answer for each question.

How many hours of post-licensing education must a newly licensed broker complete?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.

examQuestions.questionText:
Let the license expire and reinstate later b. Place the license on voluntary inactive status c. Request a hardship extension from FREC d. Pay a penalty fee and get an automatic extension

How many hours of continuing education must brokers complete for each renewal period?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 14 hours","B. 28 hours","C. 45 hours","D. 60 hours"]

examQuestions.questionText:
Renewal is rejected b. License placed on involuntarily inactive status c. License revoked d. Broker receives 90-day grace period

Active military members deployed overseas receive what benefit regarding license renewal?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Permanent exemption from renewal","B. Extended renewal deadline upon return","C. Half-price renewal fees","D. No special benefits"]

examQuestions.questionText: When must the broker post-licensing education be completed?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Within six months of initial licensure","B. Within the first renewal period","C. Within two years of initial licensure","D. Before taking first listing"]

examQuestions.questionText: The continuing education requirement includes how many hours of Core Law?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. None - it's optional","B. 3 hours","C. 7 hours","D. 14 hours"]

examQuestions.questionText:
As a broker b. As a broker associate c. As a sales associate d. She cannot work under another broker

An owner-developer who owns and sells only their own properties must: a. Hold a broker license b. Register any employed licensees with DBPR c. Register as a broker with FREC d. No registration required

What must happen within 10 days of a brokerage entity address change?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Notify all clients","B. Notify DBPR","C. Apply for new license","D. Close the old office"]

examQuestions.questionText:
The broker only for business-related debts b. The broker for all debts with unlimited personal liability c. No one - the business is a separate entity d. Only the clients who contracted with the broker

A general partnership automatically dissolves upon: a. The partnership earning its first profit b. Any disagreement between partners c. The death of a partner d. Hiring the first sales associate

What is the primary advantage of a limited partnership for passive investors?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. They can control daily operations","B. Liability is limited to their investment amount","C. They pay no taxes on partnership income","D. They are exempt from partnership debt"]

examQuestions.questionText:
No annual fees required b. Simpler formation process c. Limited liability for all partners d. Exemption from income taxes

Which business structure is a separate legal entity distinct from its owners?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Sole proprietorship","B. General partnership","C. Corporation","D. All of the above"]

examQuestions.questionText: In a limited partnership, which partners have unlimited personal liability?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Limited partners only","B. Both general and limited partners","C. General partners only","D. No partners have unlimited liability"]

examQuestions.questionText:
Limited liability company b. Corporation c. Joint venture d. General partnership

A sole proprietor broker operating as "John Smith, Real Estate Broker" must: a. Register a trade name with DBPR b. Register under the Fictitious Name Act c. Neither - using legal name requires no trade name registration d. Both DBPR and Fictitious Name Act registration

A corporation named "ABC Realty, Inc." wants to advertise as "Premier Properties." What must the corporation do?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Nothing - can use any name in advertising","B. Register \"Premier Properties\" as trade name with DBPR","C. File new articles of incorporation","D. Only register with Division of Corporations"]

examQuestions.questionText:
BR Home for Sale, Great Price! Call 555-1234" b. "Beautiful Home, Must See! Contact John at 555-5678" c. "Luxury Condo for Sale, Sunshine Realty, 555-9999" d. "For Sale By Owner, 3BR/2BA, 555-4321" (when placed by a licensee)

A sales associate creates a "team" with three other associates. In team advertising, the brokerage name must: a. Appear somewhere in small print b. Be equally prominent as the team name c. Not appear at all - team name is sufficient d. Appear only on business cards, not other advertising

Sales associates advertising their personal services must: a. Include brokerage name in all advertising b. Never mention the brokerage c. Only advertise through the broker d. Use only their personal name

A licensee who owns and is selling their personal residence must: a. List it with their brokerage b. Disclose their licensed status in advertising c. Not advertise it at all d. Use only "For Sale By Owner" signs

Real estate office websites must include: a. Only the sales associate's contact information b. Brokerage name, licensed status, and point of contact information c. Photos of all licensees d. Complete financial statements

A broker may use "Realtor" in advertising only if: a. They have been licensed for five years b. They are a member in good standing of the National Association of Realtors c. They have a broker license (sales associates cannot use it) d. They pay an annual fee to DBPR

Under the Fair Housing Act, how many protected classes are there at the federal level?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Five","B. Six","C. Seven","D. Nine"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which is NOT a protected class under the federal Fair Housing Act?
examQuestions.explanation: The correct answer is option C.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Race","B. Religion","C. Familial status","D. Marital status"]

examQuestions.questionText: A broker's office entrance sign must display:
examQuestions.explanation: The sign must display the brokerage name and 'Licensed Real Estate Broker'.
examQuestions.options: ["A. The broker's home address","B. The brokerage name and 'Licensed Real Estate Broker'","C. All sales associates' names","D. The MLS membership number"]

examQuestions.questionText: A broker who wishes to operate under a trade name must:
examQuestions.explanation: Trade names must be registered with DBPR before use.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Simply use the name in advertising","B. Register the name with DBPR before using it","C. File with the county clerk only","D. Obtain MLS approval"]

examQuestions.questionText: A sales associate's license becomes involuntary inactive when:
examQuestions.explanation: When the employing broker's license is suspended or revoked, the sales associate's license becomes involuntary inactive.
examQuestions.options: ["A. The associate fails to complete continuing education","B. The employing broker's license is suspended or revoked","C. The associate moves to another county","D. The brokerage changes its name"]

examQuestions.questionText: A broker associate is:
examQuestions.explanation: A broker associate holds a broker license but works under another broker.
examQuestions.options: ["A. A sales associate with 5 years of experience","B. A person with a broker's license working under another broker","C. A broker who owns 50% of the brokerage","D. An unlicensed assistant to a broker"]

examQuestions.questionText: The probable cause panel of FREC consists of:
examQuestions.explanation: The probable cause panel consists of two FREC members.
examQuestions.options: ["A. One FREC member","B. Two FREC members","C. Three FREC members","D. The entire FREC"]

examQuestions.questionText: The maximum administrative fine FREC may impose per violation is:
examQuestions.explanation: The maximum administrative fine is $5,000 per violation.

examQuestions.questionText: Operating as a real estate broker without a license is a:
examQuestions.explanation: Operating as a broker without a license is a third-degree felony.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Second-degree misdemeanor","B. First-degree misdemeanor","C. Third-degree felony","D. Civil infraction only"]

examQuestions.questionText: To qualify for a Florida broker license, an applicant must have been actively licensed as a sales associate for at least:
examQuestions.explanation: Florida requires 24 months of active sales associate experience within the preceding 5 years.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 12 months within the preceding 3 years","B. 18 months within the preceding 4 years","C. 24 months within the preceding 5 years","D. 36 months within the preceding 7 years"]

examQuestions.questionText: Sales associates must receive compensation:
examQuestions.explanation: Sales associates must receive all compensation from their employing broker.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Directly from the buyer or seller","B. From either party to the transaction","C. Only from their employing broker or brokerage entity owner","D. From the title company at closing"]

examQuestions.questionText: Which license status allows a licensee to perform real estate services?
examQuestions.explanation: Only active status permits performing real estate services.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Inactive","B. Active","C. Suspended","D. Involuntary inactive"]

examQuestions.questionText: Group licenses may be issued to:
examQuestions.explanation: Group licenses are issued to owner-developers selling their own subdivided property.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Any broker with multiple offices","B. Only owner-developers selling their own property","C. All property management companies","D. Any brokerage with more than 10 associates"]

examQuestions.questionText: FREC members are appointed by:
examQuestions.explanation: FREC members are appointed by the Governor.
examQuestions.options: ["A. The DBPR Secretary","B. The Florida Legislature","C. The Governor","D. Popular election"]

examQuestions.questionText: A notice of noncompliance may be issued for:
examQuestions.explanation: Notices of noncompliance are for first-time minor violations.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Conversion of escrow funds","B. First-time minor violations with no prior discipline","C. Fraud","D. Operating without a license"]

examQuestions.questionText: License suspension may be for a maximum of:
examQuestions.explanation: License suspension can be for up to 10 years.
examQuestions.options: ["A. 1 year","B. 5 years","C. 10 years","D. Lifetime"]

Which expense is NOT deducted to calculate NOI?
examQuestions.explanation: Debt service (mortgage payments) is deducted after NOI is calculated.
examQuestions.options: ["A. Property taxes","B. Insurance","C. Mortgage payment","D. Management fees"]
